Indian Affairs Branch,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,
July 3rd, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Attention: Superintendent of Indian Education

The Principal of the R.C. Indian Residential School #659 at Onion Lake requests the discharge of pupil No.360, J. Raymond Waskewitch, aged 16 years.

This boy, besides being 16 years of age, is needed at home as his father died this year.

(J.A. Davis)
Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.
July 11, 1950.

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

Your file 171/25-4-659 of July 3rd

The Department approves the discharge of pupil # 360, J. Edmond Waskewitch from the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
July 24, 1950.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Supt. Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

The Department approves the discharge of the following pupils from the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School:

| No.   | No.   |
|-------|-------|
| 360   | 0432  |
| 386   | 0438  |
| 0348  | 0441  |
| 0358  | 0400  |

MVT/HM

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

The Principal of the Onion Lake Indian Residential School has contacted this office and asked that approval be obtained for the discharge of the following pupils:

Julia Desjarlais
Cold Lake Reserve

Genevieve Ennow
Cold Lake Reserve

Would you please advise this office, at your convenience, whether or not the above discharges are approved so that we may inform the Principal accordingly.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.
July 6th, 1950.

Mr. C.S. Bell,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Battleford, Saskatchewan.

Re: Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, Your File 23-5-105

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, you may advise the Principal of the above school that the Department approves the discharge of the pupils numbered as follows:

No. 386
0400
0432
0441

PP/ST

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
Battleford, Sask.,
July 3, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I have received a letter from Rev. Jules St. Pierre, o.m.i., Principal of the St. Anthony Residential School, Lloydminster, Sask., requesting the discharge of the following pupils:

| No.   | Name               | Tribe       | Age |
|-------|--------------------|-------------|-----|
| 386   | Violet Thomas Wuttunee | Sweet Grass | Off age |
| 0400  | Lillian Bugler     | Red Pheasant| "    |
| 0432  | M. Rose Kapeyesiwan| Moosomin    | "    |
| 0441  | Eliza Kapeyesiwan  |             | "    |

I would recommend that the discharge of the above mentioned pupils be approved.

C. S. Bell,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.
August 15th, 1950.

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan.

Re: Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

Please inform the Principal of the above school that the undermentioned children should be considered discharged as they will attend the Poundmaker Indian Day School which has recently been completed, during the academic year 1950-51:

#404 Gordon Tootoosis #0416 Leona Tootoosis
#399 Simon Tootoosis #400 Austin Tootoosis
#401 Michael Tootoosis #402 Edmond Tootoosis
#421 Kenneth Tootoosis #434 Harvey Tootoosis

PP/ST

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
Meadow Lake, Sask.,
September 18th, 1950.

B.F. Neary, Esq.,
Supt. Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Rev. Jules St. Pierre, O.M.I., Principal of the Onion Lake
R.S. Indian Residential School #659 is requesting the readmission of
the following pupils to his school:

| Pupil No. | Name          | Band       | Father         | Maiden name of Mother |
|-----------|---------------|------------|----------------|-----------------------|
| 354       | Bruce Naistus | Onion Lake #155 | Dec. M. Cecile Watchmaker |                     |
| 364       | Dan Naistus   | #155       |                |                       |
| 363       | Duncan Quinney| #156       | Charles Quinney|                       |
| 365       | John Whitstone| #149       | John Whitstone | Monica John           |

Would recommend the readmittance of these pupils.

J.A. Davis,
Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.
September 26, 1950.

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.

Re: Onion Lake Residential School
Your File 171/25-2-659

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, the Department approves the re-admission of the following pupils to the Onion Lake Residential School:

No. 354 Bruce Naistus
364 Dan Naistus
383 Duncan Quinney
385 John Whitstone

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

The Principal of the Onion Lake Residential School has written to this office and asked re-admission be obtained for the following:

No. 0392 - Emma Jacknife

Would you please advise this office, at your convenience, whether or not the re-admission of the above is approved.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.
October 2nd, 1950.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.

Re: Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.
Your File 118/25-2

With reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, the Department approves the re-admission of Emma Jacknife, No. 0392 to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

PP/ST

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

September 6, 1945.

Sir,—
I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the St. Anthony R.C. Indian Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child:
English name: Herman Littlewolf
Age: Born Dec. 22, 1942
Name of Band: Onion Lake
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: 44
Father's full name and No.: Joe Littlewolf
Mother's full name and No.: Maria Mooswa
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Good
Religion: R.C.
Does applicant speak English?: No
Previously attended: no school for years

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

*Signature of Missionary or other Witness*

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.*

NOTE—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

Admission of Pupils from Cold Lake Reserve to Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School

It is noted that no applications have yet been received for admission of new pupils from the Cold Lake area to Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

As residential school accommodation has been requested for the children of the Cold Lake Reserves, the Department desires that the fullest possible use be made of day schools in the recruiting area and that accommodation thus made available in the residential school be allotted to children from the Cold Lake area.

You are requested, accordingly, to arrange the early admission to a residential school of as many of the Cold Lake children as possible.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Your letter file 659-10 (E.3) dated 7-October-50
and file 659-1(El) of 23-Aug-50.

I interviewed the Rev. Father St. Pierre, O.M.I., Principal
of the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Res. School #659 and at that time he
had just returned from Cold Lake where he had gone to pick up the
thirty children as mentioned in your letter of August 23rd.

He found that the parents opposed to their children going to
the school and was only able to pick up three children.

I am in doubts that there are any possibilities of getting any
further pupils from there.

J.A. Davis
Superintendent
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.

JAD:G

c.c.: W.K. Taylor, Esq.,
Superintendent,
St. Paul, Alberta.

We attach herewith the quarterly returns for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School #659. Father Lessard, Principal of the School has requested that we complete the per capita grant section of this report. We have checked back on previous quarterly returns and note that none of these have been completed and we are at a loss to understand why this has been allowed, nor do we understand how we have missed this item for so long.

Will you please instruct the Rev. Father Lessard in this matter quoting the amount of grant per capita allowed his school, and also any other information pertaining to this report. We would appreciate receiving a copy of your letter to him in order that same may be held for future use.

(J.A. Davis)
Indian Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.

C.C. Rev. J. Lessard, O.M.I.,
Principal, R.C. Indian Res. School #659,
Onion Lake, via Lloydminster, Sask.

Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

This refers to your letter of October 4th, file 1339-171/23-16-659 regarding the September Quarterly Return for the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

The Principals rarely complete the Per Capita Grant section, however we complete this section before making payment of the grant. Many of the Principals, however, do complete this section for their own information to check with the amount of the cheque when issued.

The Per Capita rate for the Onion Lake R.C. School is $288.75 a year.

We are forwarding a copy of this letter to Father Lessard.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
October 17, 1951.

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

The Department approves
the discharge of the following pupils from
the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School:

No. 351
366
390
450
0361
0439

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
October 18, 1951.

Rev. J. Lessard, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Onion Lake R.C. Indian Res. School,
Lloydminster, Sask.,

Dear Father Lessard:

This refers to the September Quarterly Return for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

It is noted that you have claimed sixty-five days grant for pupils who have been discharged and who have not returned during September. You are advised that only sixty-two days are allowed for these pupils. We have amended the return, please amend your copy.

When a pupil is not in residence for the full Quarter, please indicate in the Remarks Column the reason for absence and the date the pupil left the residence or returned to residence or both as the case may be. This information is required by the Treasury Branch and the Auditors.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I would ask that the discharge of the following pupils from St. Anthony's Residential School, Onion Lake be recommended for approval:

Alex Frenchman, #148, Moosomin Band.
Walter Frenchman, #148, Moosomin Band.
Victor Osecap, #224, Moosomin Band.
Hazel Bigear, #172, Moosomin Band.
Josephine Bigear, #172, Moosomin Band.
Allan Gladeau, #175, Moosomin Band.
Ernest Gladeau, #175, Moosomin Band.
Paul Osecap, #190, Moosomin Band.
Theresa Kahpeesewat, #158, Moosomin Band.

The reason that the discharge is requested is that they have been attending Moosomin Indian Day School since September 4th, 1951.

C. S. Bell,
Superintendent,
Battleford Agency.
November 1, 1951

Mr. C.S. Bell,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Battleford, Sask.,

Your file 105/25-2
of October 30

With reference to your letter, the Department approves the discharge of the children listed from the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

Kindly ask the Principal to show the names of these children with their numbers on Form I.A. 411 which he will forward with the next Quarterly Return.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

Your file 1533-171/25-2-659

With reference to your letter of November 6th regarding admissions to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, it is noted that the applications show that the two Heathen and Dillon children are of the Anglican Faith.

Since the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School is a Roman Catholic school, the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of these children to this institution.

It would be appreciated if you would advise Father Lessard that he should not admit these children to the school until their admission is authorized by the Department. If these children are at school already, Father Lessard should not include them on his Quarterly Return until such time as he is authorized to do so.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
November 15, 1952.

Supt. Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

CANADA
January 8, 1952.

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

With reference to the December Quarterly Return for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, you are advised that the Principal has overlooked certain points which should be brought to his attention and which he should follow when preparing future Returns:

1. The Principal has shown on the Return a number of pupils were in residence for less than the prescribed number of days in the Quarter (32), however, he has not indicated in the remarks column the reason for absences nor the dates when the pupils left residence and returned to residence. This information is necessary as it is required by our Treasury officials when making payments on the Return.

2. The Principal has shown pupils 0374, 394 and 395 as having been admitted to hospital on a certain date. He overlooked the fact that in cases of this nature the school is entitled to thirty days hospital grant in addition to the usual number of days the pupil was in residence prior to admission to hospital. We have consequently raised the number of days in residence for each of the three pupils to 30 days.
3. It is noted that a number of pupils who did not return to residence on September 1st have been dropped from the Return. This practice must be discontinued as we are not able to trace the children should they return to residence at a later date. In cases of this nature, the Principal should keep the names on the Return or ask for the discharge of the pupils concerned and when the discharge is approved he may then drop the pupils from the Return.

We are forwarding an extra copy of this letter to you for transmission to the Principal.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Meadow Lake, Sask.,
January 22nd, 1952.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Superintendent - Indian Education,
Ottawa.

With reference to paragraph three of your letter of January 8th, 1952, file 659-10 (E6):

The meaning in this paragraph is not quite clear as the discharge of all pupils was approved by you before their names were deleted from the quarterly report. However, we believe the correct procedure would have been to show all pupils on the quarterly report for the period ending December 31st, 1951, show no days in attendance or in residence, and in the remarks column to show the authority for the discharge of the pupil.

If this is what is required will you please advise so that Father Lessard will know what to do in future.

[Signature]

FOR: J.A. Davis,
Indian Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.

C.C.: Rev. J. Lessard, O.M.I.,
Onion Lake Sask.
Indian Affairs Branch

Meadow Lake, Sask.,
January 22nd, 1952.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Superintendent - Education,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Your file 659-10 (E5) dated 8-January-52.

Please refer to your letter of above noted file wherein you requested that application forms be forwarded for a number of pupils enrolled in the Onion Lake Indian Residential School, #659.

We notified the Principal, the Rev. J. Lessard, of your request as some of the children do not belong to our Agency. Father Lessard informs us that application forms have been previously forwarded for all children mentioned and your authority for their admittance has been given.

With reference to Mathilda Waskewitch, pupil No.0366, this is a readmittance, your approval has been given, and her application form was submitted several years ago and should still be on your files.

If something still appears to be out of order please advise and we will try to straighten it out.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

For: J.A. Davis,
Indian Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.

c.c.: Rev. J. Lessard,
Onion Lake, Sask.
January 31, 1952

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.

Heathen and Dillon Families

With reference to the application for admission to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School for Annie and Dora Heathen, the religious denomination shown on the application form is Anglican.

Please advise the religious denomination of the mother of these two children.

With reference to the application for Mary, James and Rose Dillon, their religious denomination is shown as Anglican. Please advise the religious denomination of the mother of these three children.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Meadow Lake, Sask.,
February 5th, 1952.

Superintendent - Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Attached herewith please find application for the admission to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School #659 of Hector Paul, #177 Keeheewin Band.

This child actually belongs to the Saddle Lake Agency at St. Paul, Alberta, but as this woman and her illegitimate family have been resident on the Onion Lake Reserve for the past ten years Mr. Taylor, Superintendent of the Saddle Lake Agency, advised that it would be in order for us to arrange for the admittance of this child to the said school.

This application is recommended both by myself and Mr. Taylor.

(J.A. Davis)
Indian Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.
February 12, 1952

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

of February 5th

The Department approves
the admission of Hector Paul to the Onion

Philip Phelan,

On December 22, 1951, File 105/25-2, I forwarded an application for the admission of Josephine Jimmy, No. 257, Thunderchild Band, to St. Anthony's Onion Lake Indian Residential School.

Up to the present I do not appear to have received confirmation of this application. I have received a letter from Father Lessard, the Principal, inquiring about this.

Would you please advise regarding this application.

C. S. Bell,
Superintendent,
Battleford Agency.
March 28, 1952.

Mr. C.S. Bell,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Battleford, Sask.,

Your file 105/25-2
of March 24th

The Department approves
the admission of Josephine Jimmy to the
Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

This application was overlooked
on our files.

St. Anthony's Indian School,

May 12th, 1952.

Mr. J. A. Davis, Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency,
MEADOW LAKE, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find Application for Admission Forms
for Julia Opissinow and Mary Florence Whitstone. The prolonged
absence of Dr. Bearden, our Medical Officer, explains the long
delay in sending in the forms after the children were in school.

N. B.

Julia Opissinow is one about whom there should be quite
a few letters in your files. The parents claimed that she was
T.B. Finally I prevailed upon the father to have the child
examined. The doctor reported no sign of T.B. but apparent
signs of malnutrition, and recommended her presence in school.
I took her in on March 30th., and already she has picked up quite
a bit.

Mary Florence Whitstone is only 5, but is clearly a case
of a destitute and neglected child. In January both parents
left the reservation, each going their separate ways. Mrs. Night
Walker took Mary Florence in, then after a quarrel with the father,
who had returned, refused to keep her. David asked me to take
her in. She is a bright little girl and is quite able to follow
the classes for the other beginners.

Yours truly,

(Signed) J. Lessard, O.M.I.
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

I enclose, herewith, Application for Admission Forms in respect of Julia Opissinow, #141 Onion Lake Band and Mary Florence Whitstone, #177 Onion Lake Band, together with copy of a letter from Rev. J. Lessard, O. M. I., Principal of the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School.

J. A. Davis,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
May 20, 1952.

Mr. J.A. Davis,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

Your file 637-171/25-2659
of May 16th

The Department approves the
admission of the following children to the
Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School:

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sept.18,1952.

Mr. S. K. Walker,
Clerk in Charge,
Meadow Lake, Sask.

With reference to your letter of September 10, file 1070-171/25-2 the Department approves the admission of all the children listed to the Onion Lake Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
September 18, 1952.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
304 Post Office Building,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

Re: Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School

With reference to your letter of September 9th regarding the admission of Joseph Dillon and the re-admission of the three Dillon children to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, you are advised that as these children are of the Anglican faith and as the school is a Roman Catholic School, the admission of Joseph and the re-admission of the three Dillon children cannot be considered.

We have noted the contents of Mr. Dillon's statutory declaration and will apply for a ruling on Mr. Dillon's wishes. When a ruling has been received, you will be advised accordingly. In the meantime, no action should be taken to place these children in the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School. If for any reason these children are already in the school, they should be immediately returned to their parents, as the department will not allow any per capita grant for them.

We are forwarding a copy of this letter to Mr. Walker, Clerk-in-Charge of the Meadow Lake Agency.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education
September 18, 1952.

Mr. S.K. Walker,
Clerk-in-Charge,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan.

Re: Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School
Your 171/25-2-659

With reference to your letter of September 4th, it is regretted that the applications forwarded on January 14th, 1952, were overlooked. The department approves the admission of Mary Alma Quinney and Raymond Chocan to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education

St. Anthony's Indian School
Lloydminster, Sask.
September 25th, 1952

Mr. Taylor, Superintendent
Saddle Lake Agency

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find application for admission forms for the three Mountain children.

These children, though living on Onion Lake reserve with their mother, belong to the Keeheewin band.

I was asked by the chief of the reserve, Arsene Cardinal who signs as witness, to take these children, though they are Anglicans. I have accepted pending approval of the Department, under the same conditions as those under which I took Anglican children last year.

The mother does not want her children to go to the Prince Albert Anglican school, the reason given being distance. She wants to take advantage of the privilege of having her children at home every weekend, (Friday evening to Sunday evening). However she is not able to look properly after the children. For the last few years, her own father was doing this, but now he is in ill health, cannot work, and has applied for rations from the Agency for himself and wife. The chief of the reserve feels that these children are truly destitute. He has written in this vein a letter to the acting superintendent of the Agency at Meadow Lake, not knowing that the recommendation for admission would have to go through your office. I expect the clerk at the Meadow Lake Agency will forward the letter to Ottawa.

The children seem in good health, except they were very thin and undernourished.

I hope you will see your way clear to recommend approval of admission by Mr. Phelan.

Yours truly,

J. Lessard O.M.I.
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention:- Superintendent of Education

Please find attached hereto, applications for admission for three children of Mrs. Mary Mountain and a copy of the letter received by this office from the Principal of St. Anthony's Indian Day School.

It is respectfully requested that these applications be given favorable consideration.

Yours truly,

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

F/c.
Encl.
October 23, 1952.

Mr. W.K. Taylor  
Supt. Indian Agency,  
St. Paul, Alta.,

With reference to your letter of October 3rd regarding the admission of the three Mountain children, it is noted that these children are Anglican, consequently their admission to the Onion Lake R.C. School can not be approved.

As this is a Government-owned residential school, please instruct the Principal that these children must be immediately returned to the parents as the Department is not prepared to allow them to remain in the Onion Lake school. Please advise when these children actually leave the school.

Philip Phelan,  
Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Reference the attached Application for Admission of Bert Dillon to the Onion Lake Indian Residential School the following report is submitted for consideration. The child Bert (Alvin) Dillon #118 Onion Lake Band belongs to an Anglican family, the parents Douglas and Margaret Dillon having been married at the former Anglican Indian Residential School at Onion Lake. The boy himself was baptized in the Anglican faith by the Reverend John Jefferies a copy of the Baptismal Certificate is enclosed.

It will be seen from the Baptismal Certificate that this child is not yet 6 years old and therefore we have not signed the Admission form. We would be glad to receive your instructions on this matter at your convenience.

Also enclosed is a statement by the parents stating their reason why they wish the child to attend this Residential School.

A.N. Wark,
Superintendent.

Encl.
SKW/jk
Indian Affairs Branch, Regina, January 27, 1953.

Department of Citizenship & Immigration, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I am enclosing herewith a letter from Indian Superintendent A. N. Wark of the Meadow Lake Agency and other enclosures he mentions in connection with the application for admission of Bert Alvin Dillon, #118, Onion Lake Band, to the St. Anthony's Indian Residential School.

Mr. Wark has not signed the application, as the religious denomination status of this child is in question, and he is only six years old.

My only comment in this connection is that this residential school is over-crowded, and for that reason I cannot see much excuse in endeavouring to admit to this school a child who is under age, and who was baptized Anglican.

J. P. B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Enclosure.
My reason for wanting my son, Gordon, to attend the R.C. Residential School is:

I live almost six miles from the present Day School and have no way of getting him there.

Father Lessard asked me to allow him to Baptise Gordon, which I agreed to.

Signed

Witness

Reference the attached Applications for Admission for Gordon Cook to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, the following report is submitted for consideration.

The child Gordon Cook #206 Onion Lake Band belongs to an Anglican family and was baptized in the Anglican faith, see Baptismal Certificate enclosed, however, his mother Catherine Cook has now agreed to allow him to be baptized into the R.C. church this apparently for the reason only that he may attend the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. It is noted in the enclosed statement that the Principal of the school asked the parents for permission to baptize the boy, it was not the parent who requested the Principal.

Before dealing further with the application we would be glad to receive your instructions on the matter.

A.N. Wark,
Superintendent.

Department of Citizenship & Immigration, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I am enclosing herewith a letter from Indian Superintendent A. N. Wark of the Meadow Lake Agency, and other documents to which he refers, in connection with the request to admit to the St. Anthony's Indian Residential School Gordon Cook, #206, Onion Lake Band, who has been baptized Anglican.

This residential school is overcrowded, and has a waiting list of bona fide Roman Catholic prospective pupils. I can see no reason for admitting to that school children of the Anglican faith.

J. F. B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Mr. W.K. Taylor,
Supt. Indian Agency,
St. Paul, Alta.,

This refers to your letter of January 27th regarding the three Mountain children who are now in the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

On my recent visit to Regina, this matter was discussed with Father Lessard, Major MacKay and myself. It was learned from Father Lessard that this family was originally from the Saddle Lake Reserve and were temporarily residing on the Onion Lake Reserve when it was necessary to provide the children with institutional care.

Father Lessard admits that this family is of the Anglican Faith and when questioned as to why he admitted these children to the Onion Lake R.C. School he stated that as a Priest he could not see the children suffer and thought it in the children's interest to place them in the school.

As this family is Anglican and it is not possible to allow them to remain in the Onion Lake R.C. School, please arrange to have these children placed immediately in a Protestant school in Alberta. You should advise this office when this is done.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
February 16, 1953

Mr. N. Wark,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

With reference to your letters of January 20th regarding the admission of Gordon Cook and Bert Dillon to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, please be advised that as these families are of the Anglican Faith, it is not possible to approve the admission of these children to a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices.

Gordon Cook and Bert Dillon's admission to the Onion Lake R.C. School is, therefore, denied.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

The request for the admission of the above-mentioned children to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School has been received and carefully considered.

The following ruling has been made:

"Except if the mother is of the Roman Catholic faith, children who it is assumed are of the same religion as their father should attend Protestant school". In your letter of February 5 you stated that the mother in each case was Anglican.

In view of the above ruling these children must be discharged from the Onion Lake R.C. school at the end of the present academic year but the Department is prepared to allow grant for them from the date they entered the school to the end of the present academic year.

Please advise the Principal in this regard asking him to claim retroactive grant for these children on the March Quarterly Return and advise this office when the children were admitted to the school.

MFT/HM
Director.

Re: Your file 659-10, 150-7, (E6) dated 31-Jan-52.
Heathen and Dillon children.

Mrs. Heathen, the mother of Dora and Annie, was a Moyah of Frog Lake and on their marriage registration was stated to be of the Anglican faith. Her husband, Frank Heathen is also Anglican. Their children have been brought up as Anglicans as much as anything.

With regards to the Dillons, Mrs. Dillon was Mary Ann Kuyuckoooss of Loon Lake. Her grandfather is pagan, her mother is deceased, and she herself is either Anglican or pagan. We cannot locate a copy of their marriage registration.

Although neither family is very particular about the religion taught their children they are quite liable, in order to have their children admitted to the Onion Lake School, to have their children baptized R.C. They definitely wish them to attend the school on their home reserve, will not allow them to leave to go to a protestant school many miles away where they cannot see them only during summer holidays, and as the Indian Act states they can authorize their children to attend any school of any faith they are really causing a lot of disturbance.

Should the Department for its own reasons refuse to authorize the admittance of these children because they are Anglicans, then we believe we may soon receive the certificates of baptism of these children into the R.C. Faith.

(J.A. Davis)
Indian Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.

INFORMATION AFFAIRS

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Re: Your File 659-10 (E6) dated 15-Nov-51.

In connection with the attendance at the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School #659 of the Heathen and Dillon children who are of the Anglican faith:

These families live too far from the Day School to attend it and they have no transportation. The parents wish to keep them on their home reserve and in the residential school there they are able to visit them on the week ends.

These parents state they have every right to put their children in this school as Chapter 29, Section 117, of the new Indian Act states in ending "...except by written consent of the parent". The parents state that by signing the admission forms they have given their written consent to the child attending the school.

We would ask that the Department reconsider their decision and give the authority for these children to continue to attend. Should you wish a letter from these parents stating their desire for their children to attend this school we can obtain same and forward it to you.

(J.A. Davis)
Indian Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.
I, Frank Heathen hereby state that I have instructed my children to attend the R.C. residential school, Onion Lake Reserve.

Signed: Frank Heathen.

November 25, 1952.

The Superintendent-in-Charge,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.

Dear Sir:

I have been consulted by Ernest Dillon of the Onion Lake Indian Reserve and Father Lessard, Principal of St. Anthony's Indian School at Onion Lake, regarding the children of Ernest Dillon who have been ordered to attend the Protestant Day School on the Indian Reserve.

I am advised that these children attended St. Anthony's Catholic School on the Reserve last year and were permitted to do so until the end of the school term. At the commencement of the new term this fall Mr. Dillon completed a statutory declaration in accordance with Section 117 of the Indian Act in which he stated that he desired his children to attend the Catholic School despite the fact that he himself is a Protestant. According to Mr. Dillon the main reason he did this was because he and his wife are away a good deal of the time and as the St. Anthony's Indian School is the only residential school on the reserve it is the only place where he can be sure they will be properly looked after. He also informs me that the day school on the reserve is over 2½ miles from his home and that it will be impossible for the children to go to school unless they are permitted to attend at St. Anthony's.

It would appear that Section 117 of the Indian Act was designed to take care of cases similar to the present one and I can see no reason why the request should not be granted. There are four children ranging in age from 7 to 11 and unless they are permitted to attend St. Anthony's School it would work an undue hardship on the parents and in all probability result in the children not attending any school as I understand that they are not required to do so if the school is more than 2½ miles from their home.

I understand from Father Lessard that a ruling on Section 117 of the Indian Act was requested through the office of the Superintendent on August 29th, 1952, but that no reply was received to the request. On behalf of Mr. Dillon I am requesting that this matter be reviewed with a view to permitting his children to attend St. Anthony's School and I would be pleased if you would advise me after it has received your consideration.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

JOHN H. MAHER

Regina, Sask.

Dear Mr. Maher:

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant, I regret that Section 117 of the Indian Act was not properly quoted in my communication of November 29th. The contents of Section 117 are as follows:

"Every Indian child who is required to attend school shall attend such school as the Minister may designate, but no child whose parent is a Protestant shall be assigned to a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices and no child whose parent is a Roman Catholic shall be assigned to a school conducted under Protestant auspices, except by written direction of the parent."

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
October 21, 1952 - The father, Frank Heathen completed applications for the admission of these two children to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School. The applications stated that the family was Anglican. Superintendent Davis recommended the admission of these children to this school.

January 19, 1952 - This information was forwarded to the Deputy Minister for a ruling. It was ruled "except if the mother is of the Roman Catholic Faith, the children who I assume are the same religion as their father should attend a Protestant school".

January 31, 1952 - Superintendent Davis was requested to advise the religious denomination of the mother of these children.

February 5, 1952 - Superintendent Davis advised that according to the marriage registration of the parents of these children they are Anglican. The children have been brought up Anglican.

February 29, 1952 - Superintendent Davis was advised of the ruling and instructed that the children may remain in the Onion Lake R.C. School to the end of June but must be returned to their parents at the end of the academic year 1951-52.
October 26, 1951 - The father completed applications for the admission of these children to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School. The application stated that the family was Anglican. ATTENTION: Supt. of Education,

Re: Mountain Children at Onion Lake,
attending St. Anthony School.

Acknowledging your letter of February 16th, and even File, I wish to advise as follows:

It was not possible to reach this school for about ten days after receiving your letter. However, on the 9th instant, I proceeded to Onion Lake in company with Assist. Agent Nissen of the Keeheewin Indian Reserve. Father Lessard the principal was interviewed concerning the removal of the children, and stated they were still in the School, but could be taken away at any time.

Previous arrangements were made to place them in the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

Before taking the children from Onion Lake Res. School, I wished to contact the mother and have her sign admission Forms for the Edmonton School. I contacted four Indian Families in an endeavour to obtain a team to drive six miles to the home where the mother was staying, but without results. Arrangements were made to meet the mother at the School on Friday the 13th instant, and at this time I had to return to the Frog Lake Reserve for a scheduled Band Meeting.

On Friday Mar. 13th, Assistant Agent Nissen proceeded to Onion Lake in an endeavour to bring the Children back to St. Paul, and to Edmonton. Mr. Nissen waited at the School until 4:00 p.m., and when the mother did not show up for her children he highered a team and drove to her home with the Chief.

The mother absolutely refused to let her children go, stating she would not let them go to Edmonton, and refused to sign admission Forms. She stated she would send her children Cont'd.
to a Day School on the Onion Lake Reserve, and take them out of the Residential School. She wished to know why she had to remove her children from the Onion Lake School, stating that there were fourteen other children besides hers of the Anglican Faith attending this school. She gave the names of the following families:

Ernest DILLON - 3 children.
Douglas Dillon - 5 children.
? COOK - 3 Children.
Edward CHIEF - 3 Children.

The names listed above were all confirmed by the Chief Arsene CARDINAL, who was in company with Asst. Agent Nissen.

The home where Mrs. Mountain is staying is about one and a half miles from the New Days School, which we were informed is not yet open, and about five miles from the present Day School in operation.

As the only alternative to removed the Children would be by force Mr. Nissen returned without them, and reported accordingly.

From all appearances this family is hard up, and to have the children attend a Day School, there is no doubt that a form of relief will be required to assist in the maintenance of this family.

This report is being submitted for your further instructions, and should they be removed by force, the Services of the R.C.M. Police will be required.

Yours truly,

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

Enc.l.
In interpreting Section 117 of the Indian Act,
Chapter 29, Statutes of Canada 1951, it must be kept in mind that
it gives the minister power to designate the school which every
Indian child should attend. In this connection I quote " Every
Indian child who is required to attend school shall attend such
school as the Minister may designate ".

The next section " No child whose parent is Protestant
shall be designated to a school conducted under Roman Catholic
auspices and no child whose parent is Roman Catholic shall be
designated to a school conducted under Protestant auspices. "
This part of Section 117 requires the minister to ascertain the
religion of the parent and if the parent is Protestant the child
must be placed in a school conducted under Protestant auspices
and on the other hand if the parent is Roman Catholic the child
must be placed in a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices.

The phrase " except by written direction of the
parent " only applies if the minister ruled that a child whose
parent is a Roman Catholic should be placed in a Protestant school.
This would require the parent's consent. The same applies if the
minister rules that a child whose parent is Protestant should be
placed in a Roman Catholic School.

Suggested but not sent

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Rose Dillon,
James Roy Dillon,
Mary Dillon

The father, Ernest Dillon completed applications for the admission of these three children to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School. In answer to the question on the application form regarding "Religion" the information was "Anglican". Superintendent Davis recommended the admission of these children to the Onion Lake R.C. School.

On January 19, 1952, the above information was forwarded to you for a ruling. Your decision was "except if the mother is of the Roman Catholic faith, the children who I assume are of the same religion as their father should attend a Protestant school".

From subsequent correspondence between the Superintendent of Education and Superintendent Davis it was learned that Mrs. Dillon's grandfather is Pagan, her mother is deceased and she herself is either Anglican or Pagan.

Superintendent Davis was then informed of the ruling and instructed that the children should remain in the Onion Lake R.C. School to the end of June 1952 but must be returned to their parents at the end of the academic year.
The children remained in the Onion Lake School to June 30, 1952. When they returned home the parents consulted John H. Maher, B.A., LL.B., Barrister, Solicitor and Notary Public, North Battleford, Saskatchewan. In a letter to the Department, Mr. Maher writes:

"In view of the fact that Section 117 of the Indian Act contains a provision that a Protestant child may be assigned to a school under Roman Catholic auspices under written direct of a parent and as Mr. Dillon has complied with this requirement by filing a statutory declaration with the Department, I would be pleased if you would now advise me why the admission of his children to St. Anthony's School cannot be approved".

I would appreciate being advised what answer should be given to Mr. Maher.

H. M. JONES

Acting Director.

MEMORANDUM FOR:

THE A/DIRECTOR OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Reference your memorandum of June 12 concerning the case of Rose, James Roy and Mary Dillon. According to information available, the father would be of the Anglican faith and the mother either Anglican or Pagan. I note that Mr. John H. Maher has questioned the ruling made and his attention should be drawn to section 117, which states that Indian children required to attend school shall attend such school as the Minister may designate. A child of Protestant parent should attend a Protestant school, while a child of Roman Catholic parent should attend a Roman Catholic school. Mr. Maher should further be informed that the directions of the parents are only required if the Minister decided to direct a Protestant to a Roman Catholic school or vice versa.

After reviewing the facts, I see no reason for changing the ruling already made in this case on January 19, 1952.

Laval Fortier.
June 20, 1953.

MR. John H. Maher, B.A., LL.B.,
Barrister, Solicitor and Notary Public,
Suite 9, Miller Block,
North Battleford, Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of March 6th, requesting an official interpretation of Section 117 of the Indian Act, was received and I regret that a reply was not forwarded to you sooner.

When completing applications for the admission of these children to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School, the father, Ernest Dillon, stated his religion to be "Anglican".

In interpreting Section 117 of the Indian Act it must be kept in mind that it gives the minister the power to designate the school which every child should attend. A child of a Protestant parent should attend a Protestant school while a child of a Roman Catholic parent should attend a Roman Catholic school. The direction of the parent is only required if the minister decided to direct a Protestant child to a Roman Catholic school or vice versa.

In view of the above, there does not appear to be any reason for changing the ruling already made refusing the admission of the Dillon children to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

With reference to Miss Hoey's memorandum of June 22nd, enclosing the attached letter from Mr. John H. Maher, B.A., LL.B., you were forwarded on June 12th a memorandum regarding the three Dillon children.

You replied in a memorandum dated June 15th and on June 20th Mr. Maher was written. A copy of this letter is attached for your information.

[Signature]

Ottawa, July 23, 1953.

John H. Baker, Esq., B.A., LL.B.,
Barrister, Solicitor and Notary Public,
Suite 9, Miller Block,
North Battleford, Saskatchewan.

Re: Ernest Millon, Onion Lake, Sask.

Dear Mr. Baker:

I received your letter of June 19th with reference to departmental refusal to approve the admission of the children of Ernest Millon to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

I understand that the Superintendent of Education forwarded to you a letter dated June 20th. This communication contained an official ruling of the interpretation of section 117 of the Indian Act.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6326, file 659-10, part 5)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, July 27, 1953.

John H. Maher, Esq., B.A., LL.B.,
Barrister, Solicitor and Notary Public,
Suite 9, Miller Block,
North Battleford, Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Maher:

In the absence of the Minister, I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 19th with reference to departmental refusal to approve the admission of the children of Ernest Dillon to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

You must have received since the letter from the Superintendent of Education explaining the interpretation given to Section 117 of the Indian Act. Under that section the Minister has the authority to decide what school should be attended by the Indian children. In deciding what school a child should attend he must, of course, be guided by the religion of the parents, and if he were deciding to send a child of Protestant faith to a Catholic school, or vice versa, then the direction of the parents is required.

The decision reached in the case of Ernest Dillon's children and which has been communicated to you has been made according to the above interpretation.

Yours sincerely,

Laval Fortier

NOTE:
Please return to Indian Affairs Branch

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6326, file 659-10, part 5)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
JOHN H. MAHER, B.A., LL.B.
Barrister, Solicitor and Notary Public
SUITE D, MILLER BLOCK
NORTH BATTLEFORD, SASK.

June 19th, 1953.

The Minister of Citizenship & Immigration,
Government of Canada,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re: Ernest Dillon, Onion Lake, Sask.

In November of last year I wrote Mr. Phillip Phelan, Superintendent of Indian Schools in the Indian Affairs Branch of your Department requesting consideration of an Application by Ernest Dillon of Onion Lake, Saskatchewan, a Treaty Indian, for the admission of his child to St. Anthony's Indian School.

I was informed by Mr. Phelan that the application could not be approved because the admission of a Protestant child to a Roman Catholic School was prohibited. I pointed out to him that Section 117 of the Indian Act provided for an exception in the case where there was a written direction by the parent approving of the child entry to the school and advising him that this direction had already been filed with the Indian Department. Since that date I have written numerous letters to Mr. Phelan but have failed to even receive a reply.

I would be pleased if you would investigate this matter and determine if the application can be approved and also some explanation as to why the Departmental Official would not bother to reply to my letters. I would be pleased to hear from you as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

JOHN H. MAHER

Mr. A.N. Wark,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Meadow Lake, Sask.,

With reference to the June Quarterly Return for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, the Department approves the discharge of the following:

Donald Cardinal
David Yellowmud
Olivine Fox
Mathilda Waskewitch
Florestine Lewis

On checking the Quarterly Return it is noted that many of the pupils were sick during the quarter. The Principal has indicated in the Remarks Column that these children were ill and he has given the dates of their absence, however, he has neglected to indicate whether these children remained in the school, were placed in hospital or were returned to their homes during the convalescence. It was presumed that they all remained in the school. Please confirm.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: June Quarterly Return, Onion Lake
R.C. Indian Residential School.

With reference to your letter file #659-10(E6) dated July 21, 1953, we have been advised by the Principal that all children that were sick during the quarter remained at school with the exception of pupil #034 Olivia Fox who was in the hospital at Paradise Hill from June 12th to 15th, and pupil #442 Allan Jimmy who was at home from June 15 to the 25th.

A.M. Wark,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
MEMORANDUM DIRECTOR OF INDIAN AFFAIRS:

Referring to the attached correspondence from Mr. John H. Maher of North Battleford, Sask., together with copy of my reply in the absence of the Minister, I note that Mr. Maher states in his letter of June 19th that since last November he has written numerous letters to Mr. Phalen but he has failed to even receive a reply.

Would you please let me have an explanation as to why Mr. Maher's letters were not answered or at least acknowledged and how many letters Mr. Maher wrote.

Laval Fortier.
MEMO TO THE DIRECTOR

Do you wish me to take any action with regard to the Deputy Minister's memorandum of July 27th?

R.F. Davey,
A/Superintendent of Education
1. November 25, 1952 - Letter directed to Mr. Phelan from Mr. Maher.
   Reply sent on November 29th, 1952, signed by Mr. Phelan.

2. December 8, 1952 - Letter directed to Mr. Phelan from Mr. Maher.
   Reply sent on December 15th, 1952, signed by Mr. Phelan.

3. December 22nd, 1952 - Letter directed to Mr. Phelan from Mr. Maher.
   Interim reply signed by Mr. Davey in Mr. Phelan's absence sent on January 21st, 1953.

4. March 6th, 1953 - Letter directed to Mr. Phelan received from Mr. Maher.
   Reply sent on June 20th signed by Mr. Phelan.

5. June 19th, 1953 - Letter directed to the Minister signed by Mr. Maher.
   Reply sent July 27th, signed by the Deputy Minister in the absence of the Minister.
MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

I refer to your memorandum of July 27th concerning correspondence between the department and Mr. John H. Maher. The following list advises the dates of the letters directed to the department and the dates of the replies:

November 25th, 1952 - Letter addressed to the Superintendent of Education from Mr. Maher.

This letter was replied to on November 29th, 1952, signed by the Superintendent of Education.

December 8th, 1952 - Letter addressed to the Superintendent of Education from Mr. Maher.

This letter was replied to on December 15th, 1952, signed by the Superintendent of Education.

December 22nd, 1952 - Letter addressed to the Superintendent of Education from Mr. Maher.

Interim reply signed by Mr. Davey in the absence of the Superintendent of Education sent on January 21st, 1953.

March 6th, 1953 - Letter addressed to the Superintendent of Education from Mr. Maher.

This letter was replied to on June 20th, 1953, signed by the Superintendent of Education.

June 19th, 1953 - Letter addressed to the Minister from Mr. Maher.

This letter was replied to on July 27th, 1953, signed by the Deputy Minister in the absence of the Minister.
Although all letters from Mr. Maher apparently received replies, there was a lengthy delay in answering several of them. This is regretted and steps have been taken to prevent a recurrence of such delays.

H. M. JONES

H.M. Jones,
Director.

Requisition for St. Anthony's Ind. Res. School,
Cedar Lake, Sask.

BLACKSMITH SHOP

This requisition is made for the purpose of equipping, on a limited scale, a Blacksmith shop. Our Farm-Instructor is a very handy man in the shop; and under the circumstances the School being at a considerable distance from shops, in case of accident or breaks in the Machinery, plough implements, wagons, etc., etc., these repairs can easily be attended to at the school, if the necessary equipment be granted, thus avoiding great inconveniences and delay if an outside mechanic has to be called in, or repairs have to be sent for.

Moreover, this Blacksmith Shop would be of great advantage to some of the older boys who will be able to take useful lessons in that line of work.

Hence the Requisition for a limited quantity of the most necessary equipment and tools as specified here below.

The building for that purpose will be supplied by the School Management.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith a requisition received from Rev. Father Balter, Principal at the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School here, asking for farming equipment, etc., for the new Roman Catholic Residential School in course of erection here.

With regard to the bracketed remark against the horses and harness; I understand that Mr. Balduc is going to work for the school as Farming Instructor and that the Principal has promised to buy his horses and harness from him when he commences work. With respect to the truck asked for, the Sisters have on various occasions spoken to me about this. If the Department can see its way to supply the school with one, it would be very useful, as the school is situated more than thirty miles from its nearest railway point; and, I am sure, would be greatly appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, March 22, 1928.

Sir:

I am enclosing requisition for stock and farm equipment, which has been received from the Rev. Principal of the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. I should be grateful if you would ascertain just what stock and equipment this institution now possesses and let me have a recommendation as to what should be supplied. It appears that the Rev. Principal has entered into an agreement with Mr. Bolduc in connection with his horses. This Mr. Bolduc is to be the school farm instructor and the Principal has promised to buy his horses and harness from him. The Department is favourably disposed towards this arrangement, if you find that the horses in question are satisfactory for Indian residential school purposes; but I am not at all satisfied that six additional animals are required. When you are forwarding your recommendation, with estimate of the cost, please return the Rev. Principal's requisition.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

W. REGINA, SASK., March 31st, 1928.

Sir,

Referring to your letter No. 115-9-14, dated the 16th instant, with which you enclosed a requisition for stock and farm equipment received from the Reverend Principal of the Onion Lake Roman Catholic Residential School. I am returning the requisition, as requested, together with a list showing the stock and equipment which I think are necessary. I am, also, giving an estimate of the cost of same.

With reference to the horses, I consider that six horses are quite sufficient to operate this farm. At other schools we have only provided four horses, but in view of this school being so far from the railway I think that an extra pair should be provided, as there will, no doubt, be a considerable amount of freighting to do.

I consider the land packer is not necessary.

With regard to the truck asked for, I do not think that we should be called upon to pay for this. The Anglican School at Onion Lake are using a truck, but it was paid for by the Church Missionary Society and I think that the Roman Catholic Church, if they desire a truck, should pay for it themselves.

I may say that I am including in my estimate the cost of horses and harness asked for, in the event that the deal with Mr. Balduc does not go through. I have no information as to whether the horses are satisfactory or as to how much he is asking for them.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 659-14, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir:

I have your 309-11A of the 31st ultimo, with reference to stock and agricultural implements at the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School. The proposed expenditure in this connection amounts to over $3,000, and I hesitate before authorizing such a large amount until I know what stock and implements the institution already possesses. The equipment which you recommend is, apparently, complete. Surely, the school has some equipment that would be satisfactory for a few years, at least. Further, I think that six horses are more than the Department should allow to a school that has been in operation. I have examined the most recent report concerning stock at this institution, and I find that they already have eight cows. Are you satisfied that six more are required?

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:—

I have your letter of the 12th instant, 115-8-14, with reference to the live stock and agricultural implements for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. I note that the proposed expenditure will amount to over $3000.00, and that you hesitate to spend such a large amount until you know what stock and implements the institution already possesses. I regret that I have not this information at hand. When I made this recommendation I was governed by what was supplied to other schools, and I am quite sure that the request for six cows at this school is reasonable, even though they already may have eight. I have not the slightest doubt that they have some equipment, and I shall take steps to find out what it is, and will also make inquiry regarding the number of cows and horses on hand. I note you think six horses more than the Department should allow to a school that has been in operation. If the school have horses on hand, six is perhaps too many to ask for but they may have sold whatever horses they had, considering that they belonged to the Mission, and if such is the case they would have to be supplied with six; four to work on the plow, and a team of lighter horses with which to haul supplies from the railroad, a distance of forty miles. If they only have four they could not take two of them off the plow to haul these supplies.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir:

With reference to Department No. 115-8-14 of the 12th ultimo, concerning stock and agricultural implements for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, I have to advise you that I am in receipt of information from the Agent, Mr. Lang Turner, stating that this institution has nothing of any value in the way of farm equipment, as they have always borrowed from the Agency anything required in that line. They have only seven cows of mixed grade quality, and one old horse, seventeen years of age.

I have gone carefully through the list of farm equipment and stock, which accompanied my letter to you of the 31st March last, and have made one or two changes which will reduce the amount of the suggested expenditure, and the items which I would eliminate now are as follow:

| Item                  | Quantity | Cost   |
|-----------------------|----------|--------|
| Logging chain         | 1        | $4.00  |
| Potatoe cultivator     | 1        | $14.00 |
| Walking plow          | 1        | $36.00 |
| Binder                | 1        | $260.00|
| Fanning mill          | 1        | $55.00 |
| Bull                  | 1        | $200.00|

With reference to these reductions, I think that one logging chain should be sufficient and they should be able to cultivate their potatoes by hand. If we procure a combination Sulky plow, the Walking plow can well be struck out. With regard to a binder, it will not be required until the result of the crop is seen, and, in any event, as they have only seventy-five acres ready for seed-

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
ing, any cutting of the crop that may be required could be done by a hired binder. I have struck the farming mill off, because the acreage they have is comparatively small. If they wish to breed their cows, I think they could make use of the Department bull for a time at least.

I have allowed the item of six milk cows to stand, as the school only possess seven cows, and the new school provides for a pupilage of eighty. It is possible that the number might be reduced to four, but I am of the opinion that it would be better to let them have the larger number.

In regard to horses, I think they should be allowed six, as at least four will be required on the farm for seeding and plowing etc., and an extra team for wagon work and hauling to town will be of great use to them.

In his letter in reply to mine, the Agent states that the Sister Superior expresses the opinion that the Department should supply seed to sow sixty acres of oats, which would require 150 bushels. I have informed the Agent that the Department can not consider this and the request is a most unusual one.

I shall be prepared to take any action to purchase the equipment allowed, if the Department will advise me.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, May 8, 1928.

Sir:

I have your 309-11A R.C. of the 3rd instant, with reference to stock and agricultural implements to supplement what is already owned by the authorities at the new Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. You may make purchase of the stock and implements listed under cover of your letter of March 31st, as amended by the communication I am now answering. You might bear in mind the reference to Mr. Bolduc in my letter of March 22nd. The Department relies on you to purchase from the best sources of supply and to keep the expenditure as low as is consistent with efficiency.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Jan. 24th, 1929.

Lang Turner, Agent,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the Farm Report herewith attached I would call your attention to the following facts.

The Dept. has been to considerable expense to make this a self-supporting, modern industrial school, where the main industry taught is farming.

This land is practically all covered with heavy brush and small timber which must be cleared for farming operations.

We have not been supplied with sufficient tractive power to break brush land properly.

All machinery supplied by the Dept. is of the standard four horse type, and we have not enough power to operate two of those implements simultaneously.

Modern farming methods, to be successfully taught to the coming generation of farmers, requires modern implements, and the modern power plant for the farm is the Tractor.

This land is eminently suitable to Tractor operation.

I request therefore, more power, either in the form of an additional team of horses, or a small tractor, and I especially request the serious consideration of the Dept. in the matter of the tractor, as I believe it to be the best, cheapest, and most modern equipment for the delivery of the necessary power.

Finally, our belief is that some more power is essential to good farming, and good teaching of farming, and to give the older boys here, good boys, a better chance.

Respectfully,

(Sgd) Sister St. Ferdinand.
Superior.
Sir,

I have received a letter from Mr. Lang Turner, Indian Agent at Onion Lake, forwarding a request from the Sister Superior at the Onion Lake R.C. School, asking that an Ayrshire bull be purchased to enable them to breed the Ayrshire cows which were bought for the use of the school last year. On enquiry I find that a registered bull, between two years and three years old, can be bought from Mr. H. Thomas, of Lloydminster, at the price of $175.00, F.O.B. Lloydminster, and, if the Department will sanction the purchase, I can arrange with the Agent to buy the animal.

A request was also submitted to buy a binder. The purchase of this was deferred last year, in view of the fact that only a small area was cultivated. The Agent informs me, however, that this yielded 1550 bus. of oats, 4000 sheaves, and 575 bus. of wheat. The school proposes to seed 115 acres this coming spring and later on in the year they will need a binder. If the Department will sanction the purchase, I can inform the Agent that one can be purchased when the time comes.

I enclose a copy of a letter addressed to the Agent by the Sister Superior, with a view to securing more power to operate the farm. You will note the Sister wishes to purchase a tractor. I am not in favor of purchasing this type of equipment, however; and, as the instruction the boys get should be of use to them when they branch out for themselves and tractors are not in use on Indian Reserves, I cannot recommend the purchase. If the Department feels disposed, however, they might be furnished with an additional team of horses. Some months ago authority

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
was given to purchase six horses and, although the Agent was instructed accordingly, I find no record of any vouchers having passed through this office, and it is possible they may have gone direct to Ottawa.

In this connection, however, I would like to ask the Department if it is its intention and practice to furnish these schools with all the equipment they need, or whether its policy has not been to furnish a reasonable amount and expect the school to carry on with this end, from time to time, supplement it out of the Government grant or from other sources.

I shall be glad if the Department will advise me in regard to the matters referred to herein.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner
Ottawa, February 8, 1929.

Sir:

I have your 309-11A R.C. of the 31st ultimo, relative to the request of the Onion Lake R. C. School authorities to be supplied with an Ayrshire bull. In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging for the purchase of the registered bull referred to by you, the price of which should not exceed the sum of $175. It should first be ascertained that this animal is free from tuberculosis.

Relative to the request for a binder, I have to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of this equipment, and you may arrange with the Agent, when timely, to obtain same. The binder should be purchased on the best possible terms.

Relative to the copy of a letter which you enclosed from the Rev. Sister Superior requesting that a tractor be supplied, I have to say that the Department is not prepared to authorize the expenditure required in the purchase of this equipment. Six horses were purchased for this school in June, last, the account in payment having been forwarded to the Department through Mr. Agent Turner. We are not disposed to authorize the supplying of an additional team of horses. It is the policy of the Department to furnish a reasonable amount of equipment, stock and farm implements, but it is expected that all replacements will be made by the school authorities from their per capita grant earnings or other receipts.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir:—

Sometimes ago I received a communication from Mr. R.G. Ferguson, M.D., of the Saskatchewan Anti-Tuberculosis League, Regina, requesting me to have my herd tested for tuberculosis.

I enclosed to you my answer to his request and also the special form to be filled.

Before doing so, I like to submit to your department this affair, because if I am obliged to slaughter some of my cattle I will be short of milk for the coming school year.

I am not in a position to make any extra expenses as our grant being cut down again.

I fear much that if I sign the special form without your knowledge I will be the sole responsible for the result whatever it will be.

Therefore, dear Mr. McGill, whatever you decide upon this question will be law with me, and I am sure that your department will help me in case I have to slaughter some cattle having reacted to the test.

Your opinion and decision on this subject will be received with much appreciation.

Believe me always,

Yours very truly,

ST. ANTHONY'S SCHOOL

The Deputy Attorney-General  
REGINA, Saskatchewan  

Dear Sir:  

Re: Caroline ARGUS - Sudden Death - Natural Causes - Onion Lake I.R., Sask.  

1. Attached hereto is a copy of Onion Lake Detachment report of the 24th ultimo covering the results of an enquiry into the death of the captionally named Treaty Indian girl, age 16 ½ years.

2. The report discloses that this girl who was an orphan, had been ill for some time suffering from tuberculosis and that she was a student in the Indian School at Onion Lake, Sask. On June 20 she was permitted to visit her sister on the Onion Lake reserve and on June 22 she died. The facts were reported to Dr. G.L. Cooke, Coroner who is also the doctor for the Indian Affairs branch, and he stated that he would forward the necessary certificate so that burial could proceed.

3. Enquiries are continuing and further report may be expected.

The Commissioner, R.C.M.P.  
OTTAWA, Ont.  

Yours truly,

Forwarded in duplicate for your information with copies of Onion Lake Detachment report of June 24 attached.

T.W. Chard, Supt.  
In Charge, C.I.B.

Regina: T.W. Chard, Supt.  
5-7-48 In Charge, C.I.B.
In the a.m. of this date Wilfred CARTER, Treaty Indian, Onion Lake Indian Reserve, called at this detachment and stated that the captioned-name had died at the house of his brother, Fred CARTER, on the Reserve, that same morning. It had been some months since Caroline had seen a Doctor.

As this girl was a student at the Roman Catholic Indian School, Onion Lake, Saskatchewan, Father CABANE and the Sisters of the school were interviewed. The following statement of one of the teachers, Sister Rose-Melene, sums up the information they were able to give:

Caroline ANGUS, Treaty Indian girl, aged 16 years, from Thunder Child Reserve, Treaty #0342, had been attending our school since Nov. 20th, 1941. She was an orphan. She was always a sickly, nervous child. On June 10th she became ill, ran a high temperature of 101 or 102. On June 16th she became normal and on June 20th her sister, who lived on the Onion Lake Reserve visited her for a visit we allowed her to go. Early this morning, about 7:00 a.m., Fred CARTER, Treaty Indian, of the Reserve, came to the school and stated CAROLINE was dying. Father CABANE and we Sisters went to the CARTER house, arriving about 7:30 a.m. The girl was dead upon arrival. There were two basins of pus indicating that her lungs were totally diseased from tuberculosis. She had been under the care of Dr. C.L. COOKE, of the Indian Affairs Branch, since 1941. *(Signed) Sister Rose-Melene A.S.V.*

The Coroner, Dr. C.L. COOKE, of Lloydminster was contacted by telephone. The girl was well known to Dr. COOKE as he is also the Indian Affairs Branch Doctor for this district. In view of this he stated that he would issue the necessary certificate from Lloydminster and forward it to this detachment. The writer was to contact the Doctor if it appeared from the investigation that the death was caused by other than tuberculosis.

The patrol continued to the house of Fred CARTER. A careful examination was made of the body and no signs of violence or foul play but none could be found. Due to the heat the two basins of pus had been disposed of.

The following statement was taken from Alice (Mrs. Wilfred) CARTER, Treaty Indian, aged 16 years, Onion Lake Reserve.

My sister, Caroline, and I were born on Thunderchild Indian Reserve. Modest ANGUS was our father, both he and mother died when we were small. Since 1941 my sister and I have lived at the Roman Catholic Mission School, Onion Lake Reserve. My sister was always sickly. Her nose would bleed and she was always coughing and spitting. When we asked what was wrong with
WHEN WE ASKED WHAT WAS WRONG WITH HER SHE WOULD NEVER ANSWER. SHE CRIED A LOT. I LEFT THE SCHOOL TO GET MARRIED ON MAY 10TH, 1948. I SAW CAROLINE EVERY WEEK AND SHE CAME TO STAY WITH US LAST SUNDAY (JUNE 20TH). SHE WAS FEELING SICK BUT NO WORSE THAN USUAL. WE CAME TO FRED CARTER'S YESTERDAY NIGHT AND I LEFT FOR HOME ABOUT 9:00 PM. CAROLINE STAYED. ABOUT 1:30 THIS MORNING FRED CAME OVER AND TOLD US CAROLINE WAS SICK. I CAME AND MARION CARTER AND I STAYED UP ALL NIGHT WITH CAROLINE UNTIL SHE DIED ABOUT 7:15 THIS MORNING. SHE WAS NEVER CONSCIOUS ALL NIGHT. HER BREATHING WAS HARD AND SHE PUDED PUS. HER BREATH BECAME SHORTER AND SHORTER BEFORE SHE DIED."

(Signed) Mrs. Wilfred CARTER.

6. Statement of Marion (Mrs. Fred) CARTER (Treaty Indian) aged 31 years, Onion Lake Indian Reserve.

"About noon yesterday Caroline ANGUS and her sister, Mrs. Wilfred CARTER came to our house for a visit. Caroline was going to stay with us for the holidays as she was an orphan. She was 10 years old last December. She was a cousin of mine. We spent the afternoon at housework and had a late supper about 8:00 PM. After supper we baked bread and Caroline helped me. We curled each other hair and went to bed about 11:30 PM. During this time Caroline was feeling fine. She coughed a lot but she had been coughing for a long time now. She was nervous and ever since she was a baby she has been unable to sit still. About midnight Caroline started to cry. She sat up and then fell onto the floor. She rolled around on the floor. She was crying but did not say anything. I just rubbed her stomach to indicate it was painful. I picked her up and put her back into bed. My husband, Fred, went to Wilfred CARTER's to get Alice. They arrived about 1:30 AM. We stayed up all night with Caroline. Caroline was not conscious; she was breathing hard and pus kept coming away from her nose and mouth. About 2 basins full of pus came away. This morning about 6:30 AM my husband went to the Roman Catholic Mission for help. Caroline died about 7:15 AM (before my husband returned). Her breathing had been getting shorter and shorter, then stopped. We did not know until the Roman Catholic Sisters told us this morning that Caroline had tuberculosis."

(Signed) Mrs. F. CARTER.

7. A similar statement was taken from Fred CARTER. A copy of this report is being forwarded direct to Lloydminster Detachment in order that the medical history of this case be obtained from Doctor COOKS.

8. This girl had no property other than the Treaty money which was held for her by the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa. In view of the season an speedy burial was necessary; permission was given and on 23-6-48 the body was buried at the Roman Catholic Cemetery, Onion Lake Indian Reserve. The cemetery is not lotted or plotted. Further report will be submitted when the necessary papers have been received from Dr. COOKS. Extra copies attached for Indian Affairs Branch.

[Signature]
Expo Mil.

[Signature]
F.J.Burke #12862
1/c Onion La c Detach.
