DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Caroline Angus, Pupil No. 0293, of the St. Anthony Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, who died at Onion Lake Indian Residential School on June 22, 1948.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

FORM No. 414.

A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? June 12th
2. At what time of day? In the morning on rising
3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? The same day she reported to an experienced surgeon.
4. What means were taken to afford relief? Doctor's prescriptions
5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? Ointment, plaster
6. When was the doctor called? June 19th
7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? She was not taken because it was not necessary.
8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school? We did what we could for her.
9. Add any other useful information here.

June 13th she got out of bed; she had more fever and seemed better. June 20th she was visited by her married sister Mrs. W. Brown (Carter) who came to stay with her and bring in 21st they were visiting their cousin, their next-door neighbour where she died June 22nd in the morning.

Principal.

B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED
THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Caroline Angus from September 1941
to June 1942. The immediate cause of death was
Pulmonary Tuberculosis.

The contributory cause of death was influenza.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes.

Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes.

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

This pupil was never looked after at all when she was at the R.E. School. I had occasion to examine her on many occasions from 1941 until just prior to death. She had an attack of tuberculosis, which caused an acute attack of influenza.

C. L. Carter M.D.

May 1, 1950

Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Canada

Dear Sirs:

It is with regret that we report the death of Alfred Bear, age 7, and son of Augustin Bear from Meadow Lake, Sask. His register number was 405.

This child has been in the infirmary under the special care of the nurse since December 12, 1949. The Lloydminster Doctor has seen him and diagnosed intestinal tuberculosis, so medicine was given and a little improvement was shown for some time, but at the beginning of April his condition changed and the doctor was called again. After having made a report of his condition we were advised to take him to the Lloydminster Hospital, this was done the next morning, April 6. The diagnosis proved that meningitis had developed.

He died on April 28 and arrangements were made with our Indian Agent so that the body would be taken to Meadow Lake for the burial, but at the last moment a phone call was received telling us to have him buried here in Onion Lake. The Agent could not locate the father as he had gone north to work.

Under these circumstances it is impossible for us to have the usual inquiry, prescribed by the Department of Indian Affairs in case of a child's death, to be made. This child's mother is dead, his father being absent, the Agent being at Meadow Lake makes it difficult to fulfill this obligation.

Hoping that the given information will prove satisfactory, I remain,

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

FORWARDED FOR THE INFORMATION OF THE DEPARTMENT.

REGINA, 14th June, 1894.

To the Assistant Indian Commissioner.

I have the honour to submit on attached sheets A, B, C, the result of his audit of the accounts and books of the Fort Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

The audit proper is up to the 31st March, to which date all accounts were audited, and moneys expended were checked with vouchers for the same.

Sheet A. is a statement (1) showing the stock and goods taken over by the school from the Department on July 1st and classified into different accounts, and (2) the goods purchased and other expenditure from the per capita grant from that date to 31st March.

Sheet B. is a first trial balance of the ledger taken on 30th April; the sum shown there to the credit of the Department ($16,197.15) is made up of the value of goods taken over from it July 1st ($14,068.14) and the per capita allowance ($2,129.01) for the quarter ending 30th June, and not yet earned.

Sheet C. is an interim balance sheet made up to 31st March (without closing the books): Stock was taken in the different Departments of the school and valued, and is an asset against liabilities and expenditures.

The expenditure over income up to March 31st is therein shown to be $1,063.40.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 660-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
The system which now obtains for the book-keeping is perfectly satisfactory. An official account has been opened in the local bank wherein the per capita grant and all other moneys received are deposited, and all the accounts are paid by official cheque.

The discipline of the institution is well kept up, the children are well clothed and fed. There was little or no sickness, excepting one child in the last stages of consumption. The sick rooms were empty.

Building operations on the gymnasium were being rapidly pushed.

The Farmer, with his staff of boys, was engaged at spring seeding.

Respectfully submitted,

(Sgd) T. P. Wallsworth
Chief Inspector of Indian Agencies.
On behalf of the English speaking portion of the parish of Qu'Appelle, we beg to extend our cordial welcome.

The large number present here today from all parts of the district amply testifies the interest which has been taken by the Superior General of the great order over which you preside.

It is with pleasure and pride, Rev. Fathers, that we greet you and members of the order of Mary Immaculate in Qu'Appelle. We are worthy followers of the great order founded by St. Stanislaus, ever witnesses of their untiring energy, and zealous labors in the cause of God. It will come as adequate compensation for the effort made by the members of this order to see them in their missionary labors among the Indians.

While pleased to see so many of your able assistants with you, we regret that illness prevented His Excellency the Bishop from being present here today; we are sure he would have wished to be present to see the magnificent results of the foundation of his order. In 1869, thirty-three years ago he opened the mission of Qu'Appelle. The result of his wisdom and prudence was most satisfactory. Under his charge are, Rev. Father, appointed on every hand.

Wishing you a pleasant journey, and assuring you of our prayers, we remain your Father, with the most profound feelings of respect and esteem.

On behalf of the congregation,

M. M. Seyberts,
Treasurer.

The distinguished visitor not being very well versed in the English language, replies to both of the communications in French.

A little later in the day a reception was held at the Institute. Salads, which are always such delightful entertainments, were presented, as well as a number of visitors from Fort Qu'Appelle. Addresses were delivered by the boys and girls of the school, one of which is given below. The Very Rev. gentlemen present also addressed the natives in French in very felicitous terms, and Rev. F. Langeron also addressed the auditorium elegantly in English. After a brief interval of the orator's remarks, and telling the young natives how thankful they should be for the care and attention they were receiving from the Government, and also of the kindness of the H.H.C., in times past. Mr. A. Macdonald also made a few complimentary remarks concerning the school and the good work being done there.

To the Very Rev. Fr. Soulire, Superior General O. M. I.

Vary Rev. Fathers,

We the pupils of the Institute of Qu'Appelle, do hereby address you, as your humble servants, and as children of the Holy Catholic Church. We come to you, Perdue us, in doing thus, to tell you how grateful we are for the kindness shown to us by the Holy Father, and by the Order of Our Lord Jesus Christ. We are grateful for this favor.

We desire to express our thanks with feelings of profound veneration, a high dignity, the order of Mary Immaculate, and of the Sisters of Mary Immaculate.

Especially do we meet with happiness, your fatherly developments and affection, the ruler of our good and devoted missionaries who have been sent out to labor for our spiritual and temporal welfare.

No words can express the fact with gratitude and praise, that it was principally through the zeal and energy of these noble missionaries came into our vast territories.

No effort has been spared on their part to bring the Indians to the knowledge of God and civilization. For the space of half a century they have been engaged in the accomplishment of this most charitable object. They have been engaged in the education of the Indians, and have built many schools, churches, and bridges. They have not hesitated to give even their lives in their holy and charitable calling.

Above all, how grateful ought we, the hapless Indians, be to you, dear Fathers! We are continually the object of the benevolence and kindness of your dear good Fathers. Indeed, we may say that the Holy Father has reserved for us their greatest work of charity.

For these reasons we will be ever grateful to you, dear Fathers, for the gift of joy we will come in your venerable person the highest distinction of the order of Mary Immaculate.

Standing your age and fatigue of a long and painful journey, your devotion has been manifested in order that you undertake a visit to all the missions.

Rev Sir,

I was informed yesterday by the Rev Father Magnan that it was your intention to invite the parents of your pupils and the Roman Catholic Indians of the adjoining reserves to come to the school on the occasion of the visit of the Rev Father Soulier, General Superior of your religious order on the 18th proximo.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of Inspector Wadsworth's report of his audit of the books of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. The result of the year's work as presented in these statements is not highly satisfactory, as the year will, from all that can be gathered from them, close with a deficit. This is unfortunate, as the school, commencing the year favourably, should have been able at least to pay its way and end the year with an even balance sheet. In conducting an institution of this kind so much depends upon economy in purchases and in salaries paid that any presentation of the accounts is necessarily incomplete without a report upon this most important point. It is presumed that Mr. Wadsworth's audit included an examination of all vouchers and accounts, in order that he might ascertain whether the prices paid for supplies of all kinds were fair and whether the manner of making purchases would naturally result in the lowest rates being obtained.

Again, there should be an examination into the stock accounts, with special reference to the needs of the school, as it would be easy to overstock the institution. The amounts paid in salaries should also

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, No. 1886, of July 3rd, asking for details of the issue of rations to the Indians who attended the three days' festivities in May, on the occasion of Rev. Father Soulier's visit.

I can state from what records the Indians came, and the approximate numbers, but it was found impossible to take down the names of every individual Indian present; an attempt was made the first morning, but the Indians have such an aversion to giving their names, some objecting on the ground that they would be made to pay for their rations, and some were found to be giving fictitious names, or such names which would have rendered the list useless; so that the taking of names was dropped. It could not be expected that I would find time myself personally attend to the giving of rations, to the indisposition and

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
and to the issuing of tickets, though I went to inspect the rationing as often as I could, and am confident that everything was done carefully and conscientiously. The tickets were issued only to the heads of families, the number of rations marked on each ticket, and as the tickets were presented every morning or evening, the date of receiving the ration was entered against the corresponding number in the book, so that no ticket could draw rations more than once on the same day.

The Indians who came were nearly, or quite all the File Hills reserve, the O'Soup reserve, the Pasqua reserve, a large number from Touchwood, including many of the Protestant Half-breed, the biggest part of Muscowequay and Bigfoot's bands, many from Yellow Calf and Newbigan reserves, several from Indian Head, Ochapaives and Pelly reserves, and all the Sioux in the vicinity.

"The Manitoba" estimates the number at one thousand.
The meat was bought from the contractor, and at a low rate for the season of the year, and quality of the beef.

The Department asked me to issue the rations to the Indians attending these festivities, I have done so, as instructed, and did it in the best way I could, in my report for May, referred to the matter.

(Sgd.) J. Rigomard,
Principal
Ottawa 6th August, 1894.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that the addition now under construction and which has to be completed by the end of next June, will give us room for the accommodation of about 30 more pupils.

As no estimate was made as to the number of pupils for next year, I would ask that the authorized number of grant earners be raised to 230 from 1st July next.

Probably the new Indian Act, when put in force, will bring applications which we would have to refuse unless provision is made for an increased number here.

I would refer here to statements I have made on former occasions that I believed the grant of $115.00 per capita would be sufficient if the attendance could be 225, and it would require even more than 230, - besides the number authorized to be hired out, - on the roll, to give an attendance of 225.

It might be time, before the Dominion House meets, to estimate for 230.

I have, &c.,

(Sgd) J. Hugonnard
Principal.

Regina.

QU'APPÈLLE INDIAN SCHOOL.

Entertainment Given by the Pupils
—A Great Transformation.

Fort Qu'Appelle, Jan. 24.—An entertain-
ment was given here Saturday by the pupils of the Indian Industrial school. The Rev. Principal issued a general invi-
tation to the public, who responded to such an extent that the large hall of the gymnasium was well filled. A drama in three acts was given by the boys in a very creditable manner; the greater number of them that an amount of pa-
tience must be required of these children to play a difficult piece so well. In the absence of a piano, which would have been no discredit to a regular com-
pany, the boys sang a very pretty drama called "The Clear Sighted Fairy," which was acted by the boys, all nicely dressed, speaking English clearly and distinctly. They sang very well, but a very short time ago, they were run-
ning about the school like wild savage. Truly great is the transformation produced by the influence of the school. A band composed of Indian boys of the school, conducted by Mr. Greenaway, was much appreciated, especially by the ladies while the boys sang. A very funny laughable farce was then put on by the students, which, though not very amusing, created a great deal of amusement, and was enjoyed by all. It was favored to suit all tastes, some with something to suit those who were fond of music, with others who were fond of dancing. The noble art of self defense was then demonstrated from a Canadian and German point of view. Mr. Greenaway, a former student educated from Germany, did the honors for his countrymen. A song was then repre-
sented by one of Glengarry's rustic sons, and the boys and girls of the school sang "God Save the Queen" in a very pretty style. This brought to a close one of the most interesting entertainments given in Qu'Appelle. Those present were mun-
icipal officers, members of the council, being done by those in charge of the school, Mr. Greenaway, Mr. Hugmanard, Father Hugmanard, the principal, being there throughout the entertainment.

The recently built gymnasium is a very fine addition to the school. It affords not only a means of procuring healthful exercise for the pupils in the winter, but also makes the school hall for concerts and entertainments.
Dear Father Hugonnard,

I was very much pleased to receive your little note attached to the programme of an entertainment held at the school on the 19th ultimo.

Such entertainments, as you yourself say, have a strong tendency to bring the students out of their shell and make them more confident not only among themselves but in approaching white people. We cannot do too much in the direction of getting their shyness out of them, because if they are to continue in that feeling of remaining aloof from white people they will never successfully cope with them. Therefore, I trust your efforts will meet with every success. The work of getting up the programme is particularly creditable, and I wish you would kindly convey my feelings to the boy. It certainly shows how he has progressed.

Yours very truly,

Industrial School,

Qu'Appelle, Assiniboia

QU'APPELLE INDIAN SCHOOL.

Entertainment Given by the Pupils

A Great Transformation.

FORT QU'APPELLE, Jan. 31.—An entertainment was given here on Saturday by the pupils of the school, which was most successful. The Rev. Principal issued a general invitation to the public, which was responded to so cordially that the entire hall of the gymnasium was well filled. A drama in three acts was given by the boys in a very creditable manner. It is a general consensus that an amount of patience must be required to see children play a difficult piece so well. In fact, the performance would have been no discredit to a regular company. The title of the piece was a pretty drama called "The Clear-Sighted Fairy." The performers were all neatly dressed, speaking English clearly and distinctly. They were not all that but a very short time ago, they were run- ning about the school grounds. Truly great is the transformation produced by the school. The audience was composed of Indian boys of the school, families from the district, and was most appreciated, especially by the ladies while the boys were enjoying themselves. A laughable farce was then put on by the girls. The performances, however, created a great deal of amusement, and satisfied the varied tastes of the crowd. All ages, some with sourkraut to eat, others with candy, were there to enjoy those who were not satisfied with the performances. The art of self defense was then illustrated from Canada's point of view. Mr. Ufroesser (professor of boxing) came over. He received the honors for his country, while Canadian boys gave him a hearty hand. The library's rustic scene was then presented by Miss McCauley and one McDonald. The boys sang "God Save the Queen," and the school sang "God Save the Queen," and the girls sang "God Save the Queen." This was the most enjoyable part of the evening. Fort Qu'Appelle. These present were unanimous in their praise of the entertainments done by those in charge of the school. The Rev. Principal, Mr. Hugonnard, the principal, being away at the time, was represented by Mr. McCauley. The recently built gymnasium is in a very valuable condition. It not only affords not only a means of procuring athletic exercises during the summer and winter, but also makes a capital hall for concerts and entertainments.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. IIS, of April 24th, and in reply to submit my answer to your letter of February 19th, with regard to reducing the cost of maintaining this Institution.

The delay in my reply is due to correspondence necessitated by the reduction of the Matrons salary, which reduction had to be agreed to by the Superioress of the Grey Nuns of Montreal, in order not to have the unpleasantness of seeing the Sisters called in by their Superior General.

Your third paragraph states that no effort has been made to manage the Institution more economically. Among the different articles of diet we have chosen the cheapest, substituting prunes and currants, for apples, which were very high.

If some articles of diet were bought, although not included in the Departments scale, such articles were bought in very small quantities, and were partly to give instruction to girls going out to service, as to the proper manner of preparing them, and in any case any luxuries

The Indian Commissioner.

Regina.
luxuries that were bought with the Departments money were used for the sick.

As soon as we found out the cheapest markets we bought our supplies there, and have favoured no one in buying of a single article.

As to clothing, besides the brown duck suits for the boys for summer, which as under the Departments management were bought all the rest of the clothes were made here as usual, and you will notice that we economized considerably in the purchase of material.

We purchased a hay scale, which was a necessity to ascertain the weight of coal, hay, and freight received.

We also bought a Binder, as the hiring of one every year represented more than the interest of the cost price besides the inconvenience and loss we have experienced from not having one at the right time.

We also bought a seeder which is acknowledged to be a necessary article on a farm of over 50 acres, and is especially so for us, as our soil is very light and high winds are prevalent.

No money was spent on childrens travelling expenses except when they first came from their homes, or went out to service.

As to the reduction in the salaries of the Employees proposed in your letter, I have done as follows which I consider to be all I can do, consistent with the sound management of the school, and without making any reduction that would be at the expense of efficiency, or that would drive away a good Employee.

The
The Farmer was reduced his board and lodging, valued at $15.00, and of $5.00 per month making a reduction of $20.00.

The Carpenter was reduced his board except dinner, and lodging valued at $12.00, and $3.00 cash, making a reduction of $15.00.

The Blacksmith was reduced his board and lodging valued at $15.00, and $3.00 cash, making a reduction of $13.00.

The Shoemaker was reduced his lodging $5.00, and $5.00 cash, making a reduction of $10.00.

The Furnacesman's salary was reduced $5.00 per month.

The Mason's salary was reduced $3.33 per month, making a total reduction of $76.33.

With regard to dispensing with the services of the Blacksmith with a view to economy, I beg to say there would be no saving, but probably an increased expenditure to cover the work done by him now, as every time a pump or pipe would require repairing we would have to send ten miles for a tradesman to do the work. The Blacksmith shop takes in quite a little money and it is a trade very useful for the boys to know.

A reduction of more than $5.00 in the salary of Mr Miles would certainly drive him away, and the work that he does here during the summer as mason, plasterer, painter and general repairer would cost twice the amount paid him as salary, if tradesmen had to be hired to do it.

A reduction in the salaries of the Clerk or Teachers would be at the expense of efficiency and necessitate a change.
I would state that the duties of these three employees especially increases with the number of inmates, and is therefore heavier here than in other schools.

The reduction of salaries will not represent the whole deficit, but several articles bought last year will last for a long time, and will be a saving of expense while they last, such as scale, binder, seeder, team of horses to replace those dead.

With regard to the reduction of the Matrons salary I would say that we have here now two Sisters, not salaried. In order to keep them, and with so many girls we need them I gave the Superioress hope that when the number of pupils is increased to 235 or 280, I may be in a position to make more satisfactory arrangements.

I have, etc.,

Sir,

I enclose herewith letters from the Rev. Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School and Messrs. McCarthy & Co., of Regina, which have been handed me by Mr. Rudolph Bocz, together with some samples of felt manufactured by himself. The letter from Principal Hugonnard sets forth fully what is proposed by Mr. Bocz, and it is only necessary to add that for a beginning and to conduct the manufacture of the article on a moderate scale, an outlay of only about $50.00 is required for the necessary plant. The material being wholly wool can easily and readily be procured and present prices therefor are very low, material sufficient to make as much felt as would sell for $1.40, costing only about .7¢ to .10¢. The work is done entirely by hand and will give employment to children of all ages from 10 years upwards. In a course of 2 1/2 to 3 years' training they will, with ordinary intelligence, be able to manufacture for themselves. Harness felt, which is of a cheaper grade, can also be made and Mr. Bocz is competent to make the stiff felt from which "Cowboy" hats are made - the material of which is rabbit's hair and an article easily and cheaply obtainable here and which when manufactured commands a good price.

There is said to be a ready demand for all these wares at the prices marked on the samples, the prices being high

Sir:

I beg to submit for your consideration the following report re the advisability of starting a tannery in connection with the school.

Tanning is an industry that has been neglected in this Country and one here would fill a much felt want in this district as the raw material, viz., hides are here and can be procured far cheaper than the tanneries situated in the east can buy them for.

Hides are sold here at an average of 3 cents a pound and leather costs from 25 cents to one dollar a pound.

All the leather turned out could be made into boots or sold.

The tanning is done with extract of bark and japonica at the Winnipeg tannery, which is a great success. There they finish from 75 to 100 sides every week and turn all the leather into boots and cannot fill all their orders.

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
orders.

The tan and japonica have to be imported but the freight on it is nothing as compared with the freight on the hides when sent down and the finished leather when sent back.

1st Tanning would be a particularly suitable industry here for the following reasons:

1st Tanning is nearly all hand work and could be done by our pupils and ex-pupils with great advantage to the school and themselves.

2nd Water - a large quantity is required for tanning, this we have in a convenient place.

3rd Hides - more hides are procurable round here than in the ranching districts where cattle are mostly shipped and not killed on the spot.

4th Leather - The leather would be required for our shoe shop, and for felt boots, and would probably all be turned into boots.

5th Sheep Skins. These would have to be bought to be clipped to supply the wool for the felt, and would almost be lost unless tanned on the spot, but when tanned they could be used for boot lining, gloves, mitts &c.

6th Hair from Hides, this would also be used for the felt.

7th The same shoe shop would do for making felt and leather boots.
A tannery without a shoe shop would not be a success, as the leather made could hardly compete in appearance with that of eastern manufacture, though it can all be made up into boots and harness with great advantage.

The tannery and felt factory would work into each other to great advantage - leaving no waste and ensuring success.

If the Department would supply the plant I would run the tannery on the grant with profit to the pupils, to the Institution, and probably to a certain number of ex-pupils.

Two thousand five hundred dollars ($2500.00) would buy the plant consisting of a building 20 x 40 with vats and one splitting machine.

I would beg the Department to give this industry its careful consideration, as we have the natural facilities here, the necessary labour, and the raw material in the district if the tannery were started in conjunction with the felt factory. I am sure we could run it on the grant with profit to the Institution, pupils and district.

sgd. J. Hugonnard,
Principal.
Indian Commissioner,

Qu'Appelle, 29th June, 1896.

Sir:

I beg to submit a report re the proposed felt factory.

Your letter of June 17th states that the Department will bear the cost of the plant, estimated at about $50.00. Mr. Boz says $50.00 will only cover the cost of the several special appliances and tools which have to be made here by him or under his direction.

These consist of (I do not know the English names):

- Felting Shelters $6.00
- 50 ft. 54" Strings at 5¢ $2.50
- 5 Large Tables at $2.00 $10.00
- 5 Smaller Tables $8.00
- 3 prs Scissors, 2 ft. $6.00
- Fachbogen $1.00 $5.00
- 1 Sheet Iron 1/4" x 2 1/2" x 4' $4.00
- 7 Schlagholzars $3.50
- 1 Large Tub $2.00
- 12 Lead Weights $2.00
- 3 Frames, with heavy linen 5' x 8' $2.00

The Indian Commissioner,

Regina.
and as per list will cost $51.00

One month's work to Mr. Boss, making or superintending the plant and fixings $45.00

3 Agricultural Boilers, (to boil and dye the felt) $96.00

1 Tailor's heater for ironing the felt, $15.00

The combing machine already ordered from Austria?

1 Sewing machine, Blocks and Tools, to manufacture the felt into Boots and Hats, $75.00

and the necessary accommodation, which can be provided by adding one story to the building above the root house which is 20' x 70', the cost is estimated at about $700.00

As nothing can be done before suitable accommodation is provided it is important that the building should be put up at once, as if left till after the session the building could not be completed much before Fall, which would deprive us of the benefit of one year's trade, as all felt is ordered at the commencement of the winter and customers who in view of our manufacturing for this fall's trade are holding their orders over for our benefit will have to order elsewhere; thus if the manufacture of the felt could not be started some time early in September, it would mean a year lost to us and that the running expenses would be without return for over a year or until the fall
fall of next year—which would be a very heavy drain on the per capita grant.

Mr. Booz has already made 3 trips here from Regina and is very anxious to commence as soon as possible as part of his salary is dependent upon the profits from the felt.

On these grounds I would therefore suggest that the building be commenced at once, and that authority be given for the purchase or manufacture of the articles enumerated above so that we may catch this fall and winter's trade, get some experience of the best paying lines and obtain some return this year for the expense incurred.

As to the advisability of starting the factory, although it has already met with the approval of the Department, I may add here my own reasons in favour of it.

In the first place it will be a highly desirable industry for the country,

1stly Because we have the raw material—wool and hair.

2ndly It is nearly all hand work and light enough to give employment to children as well as adults.

3rdly There is a ready sale for all the felt, felt boots and felt hats we can make.

4thly It will be a credit to the Government to start a factory which will fill a want felt in
the North-West more than elsewhere.

6thly It will give useful employment to our pupils and ex-pupils if required.

6thly The felt made with wool will be far better than foreign felt made of rags and should speedily replace it.

I have made careful enquiry into the subject and can see no reason why it should not be successful from the start, and besides giving useful employment to the pupils be a source of revenue to the school.

sgd. J. Hugonnard,
Principal.

Sept 27th, 1897.

Rev'd Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that in compliance with the request of the Indian Commissioner that the water used at the Industrial School be examined, I took a sample from the well in the dining room, as this is considered the best water and most used for drinking and culinary purposes, and sent it by express to Prof. Hutter of Winnipeg, Analytical Chemist.

He reports that it is decidedly contaminated with organic matter which is probably of animal origin, that is to say excreta, and the water should be condemned for drinking purposes.

This proves what I have for years been calling attention to, that the present arrangement of closets and disposal of sewage is contaminating the soil in the vicinity of the wells, and will lead to very serious results.

It would, I think, be advisable to have Prof. Hutter analyze the water in the Bakeshop which will be found worse than that condemned, and also that of the well in the new building.

I have the honour &c,

The Rev'd Principal

M.M. Seymour, M.D.

Oct 11th, 1897.

Rev. Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that all the cases of Scarlet Fever have now recovered. Sixteen more leave hospital today and the few convalescent cases remaining in hospital are just completing their period of quarantine after recovery. To have had fifty cases of scarlet fever without a single death among Indian children is a record I think any medical man may feel a certain amount of pride in.

I have much pleasure in testifying to the unremitting care and attention given the sick by the Reverend Sisters in charge.

I have the honour to be, &c

M.M. Seymour, M.D.

The Rev. Principal

Industrial School.

Ou'Appelle.
Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

Oct. 12th. 1897.

Sir,

Attached I have the honour to forward you Dr. Seymour's report on the Scarlet fever patients.

The few cases yet quarantined are progressing favourably, the rest are down with their companions again, and though most are very thin and rather weak they are all in high spirits and improving every day.

Three of the Revd. Sisters were quarantined with the sick, as nurses, and did not leave the hospital the whole time; their careful nursing, and attendance to the doctor's directions, have no doubt contributed greatly towards the happy issue of the epidemic.

It was most fortunate the fever broke out the day it did, as if it had occurred a day later we would have been without the services of Dr. Seymour, who was actually on his way to the station to attend the Medical Conference in Montreal, when he called in here and discovered the first cases. He decided at once it was a case of "duty before pleasure", and to his constant attendance, skill, and knowledge of the peculiarities of each individual patient is (D.V.) due

The Indian Commissioner.

Winnipeg.

Mar.
the fortunate issue of the epidemic. His proximity to the school was most advantageous as in a few minutes his services were secured either day or night.

The provision made by the Department for isolated hospital accommodation has been taxed to the utmost and its position, arrangement, and suitability in the present emergency have fully justified the expenditure.

I have the honour to be, &c,

J. Hugonnard.

Sir,

I beg to enclose a summons and statement of Mr. Booz's claim against the School forwarded from the Clerk of the Court, Regina. The whole case can be summarized thus: On June 17th, 1896 an official letter authorized the engagement of R. Booz at $45.00 per month and board. On October 1897 I engaged him at $30.00 per month - the balance of $10.00 to be given him only if there was a clear cash profit of that amount from the felt industry.

Mr. Booz was engaged for two years so that he could not compel us to raise his wages or stop the industry. The Department were informed of this in letter No. 5984 of April 2nd, 1897.

The fire at the end of Nov. 1897 having destroyed the factory put an end to the industry, and I was instructed to discharge Mr. Booz. This I did giving him 3 months salary.

The plaintiff in this case was a manufacturer and worker in felt, and on the 2nd of October, 1896, entered into an agreement in writing with the Reverend J. Hugonnard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Indian Industrial School, whereby the Principal agreed to employ plaintiff from such date until 31st December, 1896, to manufacture felt and oversee other workmen at the Indian Industrial School at Qu'Appelle, for $35.00 per month, and also to pay $10.00 per month extra out of the profits of the concern. position of the Principal of the Qu'Appelle School in the matter, viz: that he agreed to give Mr. Boez $35.00 a month together with an additional $10.00 a month providing that the felt shop made a certain stated amount of profit per month.

OTTAWA, 12th July, 1899

The Secretary,

Re claim of Rudolph Boez for wages as instructor at the Qu'Appelle Industrial school:

Boez sued the Principal of the school for his wages and his action was dismissed by Mr Justice Richardson at Regina on the ground that the Principal was not personally liable under the contract as he was acting as the Agent of the Dominion Government. Messrs Hamilton & Jones, who are acting for Boez, state that if the Department does not intend to entertain his claim, they intend to apply for the necessary leave to file a petition of right.

There is nothing on file to show that the Department is a party to the contract before us. It would appear that any arrangement entered into was made either through the Regina Office, or through the Deputy Superintendent General when he was in the West in '96.

I think that the question of the liability of the Department should be submitted to the Law Clerk.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, 15th July, 1899.

Re Claim of Rudolph Boez.

From the material on file I should certainly have gathered that if the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School engaged Boez on behalf of the Dominion Government that he exceeded his authority and that he was personally liable under the contract. There is nothing to show that the Department authorized the employment but on the other hand the Principal's letter of 30th June, 1898, stated "if the Department would supply the plant I would run the tannery on the grant with profit to the pupils, to the institution, and probably to a certain number of ex-pupils."

If the learned judge trial judge held that the Principal was not personally liable I can only conclude that he had before him evidence which does not appear on the file.

There would appear, however, to be a good defence to the claim on the merits; and should it be discovered, that as between the Principal and the Department, there was no departure from his offer above quoted the Department even if there is any liability under the contract the Department would have a right over against the Principal of the school.

Law Clerk.

OTTAWA, 27th September, 1899

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 31st ultimo, in which you state that Mr Johnstone, who defended the Rev. Father Hugonnard in the suit brought against him by Rudolf Boez, informs you that he has not yet received payment for his costs, I beg to say that before the Department can assume any liability for such costs, it will require an assurance from you that counsel was retained on the understanding that he was to be engaged at the expense of the Department.

There is nothing on file to show that this is the case; your letter of the 3rd July last merely mentions in connection with Mr Johnstone's bill that Rev. Father Hugonnard was authorized to avail himself of his services. The Department does not acknowledge its liability to pay the claim of Boez, even if he had been successful in establishing it, and it does not feel disposed to assume the cost of defence, unless it is actually bound to do so by the terms upon which counsel was employed.

Boz vs Hugomard.

By the statement of claim the plaintiff alleges that he is a manufacturer and worker in felt and the defendant is the principal of the industrial school at Lebret.

That on 2nd Oct 1896 the defendant entered into an agreement in writing with plaintiff by which defendant agreed to employ plaintiff from that date until the 31st December 1898 to manufacture felt and oversee other workmen at the said industrial school for the consideration of $5 per month and board and lodgings and if at the end of the first year there was a clear profit over all expenses and work connected with the felt factory a further sum of $10 per month.

That under this agreement plaintiff entered upon his said employment and continued therein
year there was a clear profit of $240, which entitles the plaintiff to the extra $15 per month.

That although the plaintiff was willing to continue on with his said employment, defendant has refused to keep him on.

Plaintiff further claims $45 for his services in fixing the felt plant in the factory.

The plaintiff then claims damages for wrongful dismissal.

On the record the defendant denies entering into the alleged or any agreement with the plaintiff for his services. That plaintiff performed no services for the defendant. That he is not indebted to plaintiff $45 for fixing up the felt plant. That at the end of the year there was no clear profit. That plaintiff has not always been ready and willing to continue the services he agreed to do.

That instead of being discharged plaintiff left his employment of his own accord and if held that defendant did employ plaintiff that...
He received a bonus of three months' salary and after leaving defendant, employed plaintiff engaged in other services.

The main question to be determined by me was upon which the plaintiff's right of action depends; whether plaintiff's employment was by defendant in his private capacity or as the agent or representative of the Government of Canada.

From the evidence on this head the following facts appear: Plaintiff knew that the Indian Industrial School over which the defendant was principal was a government institution.

Knowing such, plaintiff called upon defendant at the school about May 1876 and after explaining his own capabilities suggested that a felt factory should be started at the school. To this defendant stated that he was willing, but would have to be guided by the Indian Department, and to further the proposal defendant wrote to the Indian Commissioner at Regina giving this letter to plaintiff who stated he duly delivered it in person to that official who after discussing the subject with plaintiff told him, he, the Commissioner would have to corre...
Two weeks later, plaintiff again waited on the Commissioner's office on the second occasion meeting Mr. Reed, the Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs who has come up from Ottawa. This interview happened 17 June 1896, resulting in an official letter being written by Mr. Reed's direction to defendant which letter plaintiff either carried or delivered or it may have gone by post. By this letter defendant was informed that plaintiff had been instructed by the deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs to report to defendant for duty. His salary is to be $5 per month with board and lodging and will be payable from your grant and the proceeds of the manufacture.

Plaintiff appears then to have gone to work about 17th September '96 and was engaged in fixing up the plant and it was in order for work by the 30 September '96 and the defendant then started the manufacture of felt. On Oct 2/1896 a writing was prepared and signed. This is sworn to as that upon which it is claimed by plaintiff defendant is liable in this suit and the one referred to in paragraph 7 of...
Indian Industrial School

In Appellee 2nd Oct. 1876.

I, undersigned, Rudolph Boey, hereby agree to manufacture felt and to oversee other working at it in this school from date up till 31 December 1898 for the consideration of $5 a month and board and lodging.

Rev. Father Hugonnard agrees to add another $5 a month if there at the end of the first year there is a clear profit of $240 over all expenses and work connected with the felt manufacturing.

I agree to work 15 hours a day and to take in the felt-making the same interest as if it were my private business.

Mr. Boey will receive 3 months notice before to leave after 2 years.

P.S. J. Hugonnard

From the date of this agreement, the felt manufacturing proceeded under plaintiff's labor until 26 November 1877, when the establishment was totally destroyed by fire and thus was plaintiff thrown out of employment.

During the working of the factory, plaintiff wages were regularly paid him by defendant out of money placed to his credit by the Government and out of the parliamentary grant for carrying on the Industrial School.
private bank payable to plaintiff's order and indorsed by him. They are signed J. Hoganward and under his signature appears stamped "Industrial School Gillisville."

A further agreement was adduced at the hearing § 18 as follows:

14 May 1897. I, undersigned, agree to allow Mr. Booz above his salary the rent of the house from May 17, 1897 and one month he put in to prepare plant provided that after all expenses paid there is sufficient sum of money profit of the felt industry to make for the school the same amount as the rent and month work will come to. As Rudolph Booz. Rs J. Hoganward.

Now the following facts are plain and clear:

I. That the plaintiff knew from the commencement that of negotiations that with the defendant that the latter was the officer in charge of the Industrial School, a Government Institution.

II. That he arranged for services in that institution with the Deputy Superintendent and Indian Commissioner, defendants' superior officers, and under this in September 1896 became a civil servant of the Crown.

III. That receiving a cheque for wages as he did by law, the was...
grants made to plaintiff for running the institution, i.e., the public purse.

Plaintiff admitted that after the fire he personally applied to the Indian Commissioner for further employment.

That on the face of Ex. "A" there is no express undertaking or promise by defendant personally to pay the plaintiff the wages named in the consideration, i.e., the services were to be performed for the Government and which in ordinary cases of contract between individuals there would be an implied promise to pay for services undertaken when as in this case it is plainly apparent from the contract—Ex. "A" itself, defendant was contracting, not as a principal but as agent notwithstanding he signed the document in his own name without the qualification inasmuch as evidence for what capacity and for what purpose defendant did sign it, is receivable on the ground that it does not contradict the document itself.

It was thus proper for me at the hearing to receive and now give effect to the intention of the parties in signing Ex. "A" which I find was to evidence a contract between plaintiff and defendant as an agent of the Dominion Government. His evidence was receivable also because what defendant did was proven to have been done by him.
contracts for service with public servants being on a different footing from the liability of an ordinary agent on his contract in the absence of special material evidence of an intention by defendant to be personally liable.

I refer to Smith leading cases 386 in appeal Young vs Schuler 117 F. R. D. 654 to Wake vs Harrup L. H. & C. 202 Dun vs McDonald 1896 Iq. 18 401 in appeal Dunn vs McDonald 1897 Iq. 1855 and cases there cited.

I find I have omitted noticing the fact established that the house referred to in Ex "B" was situated on the industrial school premises, the property of the Dominion Government, and under defendants control as a public officer.

Hugh Richardson

J. S. C

Memo: the Secretary,

The copy of Mr. Justice Richardson's judgment in the matter of Bocz vs. Hugonard which is now on this file was submitted to the Department with an informal request that the matter should be gone into in the light of that judgment, and the question decided as to whether under all the circumstances Bocz had not an equitable claim against the Department for a portion of his claim. It was pointed out that Father Hugonard before employing Bocz to start the felt industry submitted the matter to the Department; that the then Indian Commissioner communicated with the then Superintendent General; and that the felt industry was started and Bocz was employed with the authority of the then Deputy Superintendent General. It was urged that this interven-
intervention of the Department justified Bocz in believing Father Hugonard was acting as Agent of the Department, and that the Department would be responsible for the carrying out of the terms of the agreement. Judge Richardson's judgment is in favour of that view for he dismissed the action on the ground that Father Hugonard had not incurred a personal liability, but was acting as the Agent of the Crown in the agreement which he made with Bocz.

After going carefully into the matter I would suggest that the principal papers in the matter appear to be of record in the Indian Commissioners office that a copy of the judgment be sent to him with the substance of this memorandum, and that he be asked to go carefully into the matter in the light of that judgment, and advise the Department whether he considers Bocz has an equitable claim, and, if so, to what amount.

It seems to me that as Bocz purposes seeking redress by petition of right, the Dept should go fully into his claim before leaving him to that last resort.

J. D. McL.
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant respecting the claim of Mr. R. Bocz for arrears of wages as instructor at Qu'Appelle Industrial School, covering a copy of His Honour Judge Richardson's judgment in regard to said claim as brought in action against the Principal of the School, and asking me to advise the Department in the light of that judgment, whether I consider Mr. Bocz has an equitable claim, and if so to what amount.

I have carefully read Mr. Justice Richardson's judgment and the correspondence in this office bearing upon Mr. Bocz's claim, and must say it is very complicated. But as the transactions, respecting which the alleged arrears of wages are said to be due, took place before I became Indian Commissioner, I feel free to give an opinion on the equity of the claim. Being a layman, of course, I cannot be expected to discuss its legality.

There are two aspects in which the claim may be viewed, namely, the Department's direct instructions, and the agreements entered into by the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, acting, according to Judge Richardson, as the Agent of the Dominion Government. The papers on file here, however, do not clearly show that these agreements were authorized either

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
either by the Department or the Indian Commissioner. Mr. Boez in making out his statement of arrears seeks to take advantage of every point where the Department and the Principal were not in touch, whereas, in my opinion, to establish an equitable case, he ought to hold by either the Department or the Principal of the School.

Among the papers in this office is a copy of the following letter:

"Commissioner's Office,
Regina,
17th June 1896.

"No. II37/18

"Sir,

"Mr. Rudolph Boez, who is a manufacturer of German Felt and who recently interviewed yourself and the Commissioner regarding employment in this line at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, has been instructed by the Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs to report to you for duty.

"His salary is to be $45.00 per month with board and lodging, and will be payable from your grant and the proceeds of the manufacture. The Department will bear the cost of necessary plant for a beginning on a small scale, the aggregate of which is placed by Mr. Boez at $50.00.

"Mr. Boez has, I understand, already left for Qu'Appelle."

I am, Sir,

Yours obediently,

(Sgd) F.H. Paget,
for Commissioner.

"The Principal
Industrial School,
Qu'Appelle."

At any rate he claims $45.00 per month, from the date of above letter, irrespective of his agreement with Rev. Father Hugonnard on the 2nd October following. In my opinion, therefore, should the Department, on behalf of the school, offer Mr. Rudolph Becz, without prejudice, the sum

The Secretary:

Re claim of R. Boez for arrears of wages as Instructor at Qu'Appelle Industrial school.

A copy of the judgment of His Honor, Judge Richardson of Regina, who dismissed the action brought by Boez against Rev. Father Magomard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial school, as well as a copy of a letter from the plaintiff Boez addressed to the Minister, in regard to his claim, was sent to the Indian Commissioner, who was requested to go carefully into the matter in the light of the judgment and advise the Department whether he considers that Boez has an equitable claim, and if so, to what amount.

The Commissioner writes under date of the 20th instant, recommends that the Department on behalf of the school should offer Boez the sum of $330 in full settlement of all his claims, and he considers that he would then be liberally dealt with from an equitable point of view.

In arriving at this amount the Commissioner includes the costs Boez was put to in his suit against Father Magomard, amounting to $65.00. Boez never made any claim on the Department previous to entering suit against the Principal and his first claim.

Honourable and Dear Sir,

Rev. Father Hugonard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Indian Industrial School, sends me his request to the Department for a leave of absence, and I take much pleasure in recommending it to the kindness of the Honourable General Superintendent of Indian Affairs, the Honourable Clifford Sifton, and to your own kindness. The Rev. Father has worked a great deal and with great success during the many years that he has spent in Qu'Appelle. It is through his genial activity and great tact that this School has met with such a remarkable success and I think it is but right that he should be granted a few months of absence, to settle private and family matters, and to take a rest. I need not add, Honourable and Dear Sir, that the Reverend Father feels confident that whilst Rev. Father Magran will replace him, the Department will continue to cover this prosperous Industrial School of Qu'Appelle with the same kind protection as before.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, in which you ask for the particulars regarding Mr. Ross's claim, etc., for arrears of wages as instructor at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, I beg to inform you that Mr. Ross brought an action against the Principal of the School. His Honour Judge Richardson, before whom the case was tried, dismissed the action on the ground that the Rev. Father Hugonnard, the Principal had not incurred personal liability, but was acting as the Agent of the Crown in the agreement which he made with Mr. Ross. It was pointed out that Father Hugonnard before employing Ross to start the felt industry submitted the matter to the Department and that when the felt industry was started at the Qu'Appelle School Ross was employed with the authority of the Department, and that the intervention of the Department justified Ross in believing Father Hugonnard was acting as Agent of the Department and that the Department was responsible for carrying out the terms of the agreement.

The Indian Council was requested to go carefully into the matter, in the light of the judgment referred to, and to advise the Department whether he considered Ross had an equitable claim, and if so to what amount. The Commissioner reported recommended that

The Auditor General,
Ottawa.
the Department, on behalf of the School, should offer Boes the sum of $380.00 in full settlement of all his claim, stating at the same time that he (the Commissioner) considered that Boes would then be liberally dealt with from an equitable point of view.

In arriving at the amount stated the Commissioner included the costs Boes was put to in his suit against Revd Father Hugonnard (which amounted to $65.00). Mr Boes never made any claim on the Department previous to entering suit against the Principal, and his first claim against that officer was only $448.00, although he sued the Principal for $1038.00 and afterwards claimed $1444.80. The Department Department had to pay over $170.00 for defending the Principal and if Boes had brought an action further against it (which his solicitors threatened to do) it would have been put to additional cost. His Honour Judge Richardson (as above stated) apparently holding that the Department was liable for the carrying out of the agreement with Boes. It being therefore considered that in equity Boes was entitled to compensation, and also that it would be cheaper in the end to arrive at a settlement with him than to go to law again, the Department offered him, through the Indian Commissioner, the sum of $380.00 on the distinct understanding that this amount was in full settlement of all claims his claim.

It was thought advisable to draw the cheque in the Commissioner's favour, in order that he might see Mr Boes and personally adjust attend to the matter, which would have been difficult to arrange by correspondence. The matter was adjusted, Mr Boes accepting the amount in question, for which he gave a receipt in full of his claim, which receipt I transmit herewith.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

House of Commons

Ottawa, April 17th 1901

James A. Smart, Esq.
Dep. Minister of Interior.

My Dear Mr. Smart,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th on the subject of the claim of Mr. Rudolph Bocz of Regina in which you state that this matter was finally adjusted in August last when Mr. Bocz accepted from the Dept. the sum of $330.25 in full settlement of all his claims against the Dept., or the Qu'Appelle Industrial School as well as expenses in Court and otherwise. I beg to submit that my personal knowledge of the case warrants me in stating that the above is a mistaken presentation.

I was at Regina when the Indian Commissioner came there last August. He had an interview with Mr. Bocz and stated that he was prepared then and there to pay $330.25 in full settlement. Bocz declined to accept that and came to see me about the matter. I advised him to refuse to take the $330.25 as a full settlement but told him he might as well take that amount if the Commissioner would pay it over to him on the understanding that it would not prejudice his claim for further consideration. It was on such distinct understanding that he accepted the payment of the amount.

Since that time Bocz had several interviews with myself and he
had one interview with Hon. Mr Sifton. Both myself and Mr Sifton promised him that his claim would receive further consideration. I am very strongly of the opinion that another $330 at least is due him. If I recollect aright his total claim was for an amount in the neighborhood of $1400. I do not think that he can show good title to the whole amount but I think a total amount of $660 would certainly be nothing more than he is well entitled to.

Yours faithfully,

Walter Scott

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 20th April, 1901.

The Secretary:

Re claim of Rudolph Bocz.

This claim has been before the Department in different forms for nearly three years first taking the shape of an action against Father Hugonnard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial school for arrears of wages as instructor, which action was dismissed by His Honor, Judge Richardson of Regina on the ground that the Principal was not personally liable under the contract as he was acting as the agent of the Dominion Government. Proceedings for the recovery of the costs in the above action were instituted against Bocz, but were discontinued by order of the Acting Minister, and the Indian Commissioner was directed to go carefully into the matter in the light of Judge Richardson's judgment and advise the Department whether he considered Bocz had an equitable claim, and if so to what amount. He reported fully on the matter in April of last year and recommended that the Department, on behalf of the school, should offer Bocz the sum of $330.00 in full settlement of all his claim, considering that he would then be equitably dealt with from an equitable point of view. In arriving at this amount the Commissioner states that he included the costs Bocz was put to in his suit against Father Hugonnard, amounting to $85.00.
I have turned out the memorandum signed by the Minister directing that Boez be offered the $330.00 as recommended by the Commissioner, as well as the Department's letter of the 25th July addressed to the Commissioner directing him to offer Mr Boez that amount on the distinct understanding that it was in full settlement of all his claims against the Department. A Cheque for the amount was enclosed to him and he was requested to obtain a receipt in full from Boez and forward the same to the Department.

On the 13th August last the Commissioner reported that he had proceeded to Regina to endeavor to effect a settlement with Mr Boez, stating that it was well he did so as it could not, he believes, be accomplished by correspondence. He forwards a receipt from Mr Boez for $330.00 being in full settlement of all his claims against the Department or the Qu'Appelle Industrial school in connection with his services as a former employee of said school, expenses of suit in court and otherwise. The Commissioner further states that it was understood that when this receipt was signed that the Department would make no claim thereafter for costs in the case of Boez vs Hugonnard. (Receipt and covering letter turned out).

In conclusion I may add that there is nothing on file to show that the Commissioner made any agreement, or that any understanding was arrived at that the acceptance of this amount by Boez would not prejudice his claim for further consideration, and the only way to corroborate the statement of Mr Scott, M.P., would be to write to the Commissioner.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 4th instant, relating to the claim of Rudolph Bocz, late instructor at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and the knowledge of Mr. Scott, M.P., respecting the case, I beg to say that I clearly understood that the amount paid was, in the words of the receipt signed by him, "in full settlement of all my claims against the said Department or the Qu'Appelle Indian Industrial School, in connection with my service as a former employee at said School, expenses of suit in court and otherwise."

I saw Mr. Bocz twice. On the first visit he asked till the afternoon to consult his friends. When he came back he made some remarks in the tenor of Mr. Scott's statement; but I told Mr. Bocz positively that my instructions from the Department were to offer him the sum of $350.00 on the distinct understanding that this amount was in full settlement of all his claims against the Department; and if he did not accept the cheque in this sense, I would have to return it to the Department as declined on the terms of a full settlement. After some further conversation he signed the receipt, accepted the cheque endorsed to him, and I considered the case closed forever.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

My Dear Sifton:

I am in receipt of a letter from your Deputy Minister dated May 22nd with further reference to the claim of Mr Rudolph Booz, in connection with the Quappelle Industrial School.

Mr Smart quotes from a late report of the Indian Commissioner at Winnipeg; the purport of which is, that Mr Booz accepted the $350 as full settlement. I may say that I am absolutely positive that this is a mistake. I was not present at conferences between Mr Booz and Mr Laird, but after the first conference Booz came to me and stated that he had refused to accept the amount offered. I advised him to accept the sum offered, on the understanding that further consideration would be given his claim; and certainly the various conferences that took place in October would give Booz the very strongest ground to deny that he had accepted the $350 as a full settlement.

If the Commissioner's report to Booz is to stand, I think that Booz could rightfully claim breach of faith concerning myself, yourself, and Mr Smart.

As I have already stated, my own opinion of the claim is, that Booz is well entitled to have the sum already paid him duplicated.

I think it will be well for me to have a final understanding about this matter before going home.

Yours faithfully,

Walter Scott

Memorandum:

Mr. Adolph Bocz, of Regina, has had a claim pending before the Department for a considerable time now, and I think something should be done to have it disposed of in some way. Briefly the facts would appear to be as follows:

In the month of October, 1896, an agreement was entered into between Rev. Father Hugonnard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and Mr. Bocz, by which the latter agreed to manufacture felt and to oversee others working at it at the School from the date above mentioned to the 31st December, 1896, 27 months, for the consideration of $35.00 a month, with board and lodging. On the 26th November, 1897, the Felt Manufacture was destroyed by fire, and in consequence the services of Mr. Bocz were discontinued. He thereupon instituted proceedings against Father Hugonnard for breach of agreement, and Judgment was rendered against him on the ground that Father Hugonnard was not personally responsible, but had acted in this matter as the representative of the Department. The matter then came before the Indian Commissioner at Winnipeg, who recommended a settlement by which Mr. Bocz should be paid any moneys coming to him for services rendered up to the time of the fire, but his claim on account of termination of contract was not recognized.

I have marked underneath a copy of the agreement entered into between Father Hugonnard and Mr. Bocz in this relation, and according to my reading; of the same it would seem quite cle

The Hon. Clifford Sifton,
Minister of the Interior,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 660-1, part 1)
that although the was destroyed by fire some 13 months before the termination of the contract it did not relieve the Department from the obligation of giving employment and board to Mr. Booz up to the 31st December, 1896, and I am therefore of the opinion that he should be paid for the full term of his engagement, including three months prior to the date of such engagement when it was understood he should receive $45 per month. The following is a rough statement of his account:

3 months at $45 per month prior to date of agreement ........................................... $135.00
27 months salary at $35 per month .................................................. $945.00
13 months board at $15 a month ......................... $195.00
Costs of suit against Principal ............... $5.00

Private:

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have carefully gone into the claim of Rudolph Boez, of Regina, and outside of his full receipt which he gave through the Indian Commissioner, and I have come to the conclusion that the only settlement that could be arrived at and to which I think Mr. Boez could not take the slightest exception, is as follows:

I allow him three months salary at $45 per month, the rate fixed before he entered into the agreement with Father Hugonard. This amounts to $135. Allowing him 27 months salary 1/4 of which he was employed in the institution and 1/3 he was out of it altogether in consequence of the fire, at $75, $945. I also allow him $65 costs of suit against the Principal. This makes a total of $1,165, upon which he has already been paid $922, the balance being $243. The only difference is in connection with the charge which he has made for board for the 15 months, the balance of the time under the agreement during which he was not given any work or pay, and I have balanced this against whatever he may have earned during that time. I do not think any other arrangement can be made than this.

Walter Scott, Esq., M.P.,
Regina, Assiniboia.

OTTAWA, 26th December, 1902

Sir,

In reply to the enquiries contained in your letter of the 26th ultimo respecting the further payment of $243.00 made to Rudolph Booz in full settlement of his claim for $500 as Trade Instructor at the Qu'Appelle Industrial school, I beg to say that in the month of October 1896 an agreement was entered into by Rev. Father Hugonnard, Principal of this school and Mr Booz by which the latter agreed to manufacture felt and oversee others engaged in this work at the school from the 2nd October to the 31st December 1896 (twenty-seven months) for the consideration of $35.00 a month with board and lodging. On the 26th November 1897 the felt shop was destroyed by fire and the services of Mr Booz were, in consequence, discontinued. He thereupon instituted proceedings against Father Hugonnard for breach of agreement but was non-suited on the ground that Father Hugonnard was not personally responsible but had acted as the representative of this Department. The matter then came before the Indian Commissioner at Winnipeg, who recommended a settlement by which Mr Booz should be paid any monies coming to him for services rendered up to the time of the fire, but his claim on account of the termination of his contract.

The Auditor General

OTTAWA, 23rd December, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the application of Rev. Father Hugonnard, Principal of Qu'Appelle Industrial school for an increase of $10.00 in the per capita grant, I beg to say that this school is at present paid at the rate of $115.00 per pupil, which is a lower rate than is allowed to any of the other Industrial schools in Manitoba and the Territories, with the exception of the one at St Boniface, which receives $110.00 and is, I understand, shortly to be abandoned, partly on account of the unsufficiency of the grant.

For the reasons stated by Father Hugonnard I think he is quite justified in making this application. The school is conducted with the greatest economy and notwithstanding this, he finds himself with a deficit of over $1300.00 at the present time and he is not asking the Department to assume this liability, but to make the per capita grant sufficient to maintain the school in future. I have it on good authority that there is almost too much economy exercised at this school as regards the clothing and diet of the pupils, this having been rendered necessary by the increased cost of supplies, fuel and labor and the difficulty of recruiting pupils.
The school is some twenty miles distant from the nearest railway station and all supplies, including coal have to be freighted by team at a cost of from 15 to 20 cents a hundred. This is a disadvantage not felt by other schools, except Battleford, where the grant is $145.00 more than covering the difference.

Father Hugonnard has been in charge of this school since its inception in 1864 and under his management it has been most successful. It is the largest school we have and has an enrollment of 230 pupils with provision for 225, which is about the average attendance.

Father Hugonnard is correct in stating that the rule of the Department to pay pupils under ten years at only half the grant, has considerably reduced his income. When such rule was put in operation, he objected to its being applied to the Qu'Appelle school for the reason that there are no boarding schools, where these young children who are generally neglected or orphans, could be placed.

The Regina school received an increase in January last and $125.00 is provided in the estimates for the Qu'Appelle school, $10.00 of which is retained by the Department to pay for incidentals. This deduction is not made from Brandon or St Boniface schools, and only $5.00 is retained from the Battleford school for contingencies. I think the present vote could stand the increase asked for from the beginning of the current quarter and it would relieve him of a portion of his deficit and allow him to purchase for cash and receive the trade discount.

Dear Sir,

Your favour of the 2nd instant, addressed to the Hon., the Minister of the Interior, with reference to the granting of a gratuity or bonus for your services in connection with the Industrial School Qu'Appelle, has been transmitted here for action and I beg to say in reply that the school, as you are aware, is under the auspices of the R. C. Church and the Department does not appoint the staff, it simply approves the appointments that are made from time to time by the church authorities; neither does the Department fix the scale of remuneration, although if it were thought the school was being managed extravagantly it would naturally feel bound to call attention to this fact and endeavour to have more economical methods introduced. The Department pays a per capita grant to the school and while exercising a supervision over the work and expenditure does not ordinarily interfere

C. Miles, Esq.,

with the management, this being practically left entirely in the hands of the school authorities.

You will see, therefore, that your case is one which this Department cannot deal with along the lines suggested by you. Possibly if you were to take the matter up with the school authorities they might be able to arrange for something in the way of a gratuity.

As the La Ronge Industrial School has been destroyed by fire, doubtless there will be discussions as to the advisability to rebuilding it. I thought perhaps my 16 years of teaching and observation of Indians might be of some use to you in deciding what is best to rebuild or not.

I will confine myself to the pupils of this Day School who have attended the different Industrial Schools. Chas Eagle went first to Red Deer Industrial School for one year, and was then transferred to Brandon as he was so far advanced in his studies as to require a separate teacher and for the same reason he was sent from the industrial schools to the Brandon public where he passed his entrance examination into high school when he was sent back to the reserve to begin life without anything. He now has a wife (one of our day school pupils) two children own between 20-40 head of cattle, about 20 horses and good implements.

Lucy Littlecrow attended Regina Industrial School one year came back to this reserve married a strange Indian who eloped with another young woman and Lucy is here living with her mother.

Betsy Whitecap attended Regina Industrial School for one month came home sick lived for two years and died of consumption.

Lizzie Hawks attended Regina Industrial School for one month took sick and came home and is here living.

Joseph Road attended La Ronge Industrial School two years and died thus of consumption.

Sam Buffalo attended Regina Industrial School returned his sick and died in a few...
few weeks of consumption.

Aggie Berth attended Brandon Industrial School five years came home sick and lived for 18 months and died of consumption.

Eddie Whitecap attended Red Deer Industrial School about 2 months was sent home sick lived for six months and died of consumption together with his 6 year old brother and two sisters 16 & 14 years old.

I may say that we have had but one death from consumption in ten years except those who brought the disease from the Industrial Schools.

The Dr. maintains that we had no active consumption on the reserve when Eddie Whitecap came home but his sister and brother took the disease from him in fact the whole family except the father and mother are dead.

I myself consider it a crime to send a pupil sick with a contagious disease from the Industrial school to a reserve and spread the disease.

To say the least it is a very effectual way of solving the Indian problem.

Yours obediently,

Sergeant

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Ottawa
