2nd January 1905.

Sir:

I have the honor to present for your favourable consideration some reasons that I hope will induce you to grant me some compensation for the very heavy loss I sustained in the fire that destroyed the Qu'Appelle Industrial School on the 4th December 1904;

I was book-keeper at the school and had nothing to do with the children in the ordinary course of events, but as I knew the children, the building, and had some experience in fires I took charge at the time.

The Principal, Rev. J. Hugonard, was in Ottawa at the time.

The Asst. Principal, Rev. P. Geelen, had only been in the building about twenty minutes, so, though my superior officer, as he did not know the building, the children, or the whereabouts of things, every one looked to me for orders.

The Senior Boys' Teacher was at his home for lunch.

The Junior Boys' Teacher, a young Irishman who was acting two ten, did not know all the children, or the interior of the building.

The furnace man was away hand. The other male employees boarded at home and were at their noon meal, except the farm Instructor who discovered the fire.

There were over two hundred children in the building at the time; under my direction all were taken out quietly, and some sick children from the hospital carried out on stretchers.

I fought the fire as long and as capably as I could. I was wet through repeatedly and had no coat, cap, or mitts.

Under my direction bedding, clothing, and stores of provisions were rescued and taken to a safe distance.

Still wet, but having no change of clothing, I have arranged for sleeping accommodation for the children, the Superintendent General

Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Superintendent General.

I have read the attached letter from Mr. Graham inclosing a letter from Mr. Sworder with reference to his large personal losses when the Qu'Appelle Industrial School was burned. If the fact can be faced that a payment to Mr. Sworder would create a precedent which would likely be followed by large claims from other persons who lost at that fire, his claim may be viewed favorably and some recompense granted him; but it seems to me that until we decide to pay the personal losses of all employees at this school it would not be well to make an exception in Mr. Sworder's case. I regret to report in this direction because it was the case that Mr. Sworder acted at the time of this fire in the interest of the Department and probably to the neglect of his own personal interest, but I am compelled by a broader view of the case to take this position.

Accountant.
Qu'Appelle Inspectorate,

Fort Qu'Appelle, 3rd January, 1905.

Dear Mr. Pedley,

You will remember me speaking to you about Mr. Sworder's loss by fire at the Qu'Appelle School. You told me at the time to have him furnish you with a letter giving further particulars; this I now enclose.

Mr. Sworder's loss was an exceptionally heavy one and I am satisfied that had he let other matters go and looked after the saving of his own property, his loss would have amounted to practically nothing. As it was, he sacrificed his own property and took charge of the whole situation with the result that there was no loss of life and a great deal of property saved. Sworder's case is an exceptional one, and I think the Department should do something to recoup him for his heavy loss.

Wishing you the Compliments of the season.

Qu'Appelle Inspectorate,

Fort Qu'Appelle, 3rd January, 1905.

Dear Mr. Pedley,

You will remember me speaking to you about Mr. Sworder's loss by fire at the Qu'Appelle School. You told me at the time to have him furnish you with a letter giving further particulars; this I now enclose.

Mr. Sworder's loss was an exceptionally heavy one and I am satisfied that had he let other matters go and looked after the saving of his own property, his loss would have amounted to practically nothing. As it was, he sacrificed his own property and took charge of the whole situation with the result that there was no loss of life and a great deal of property saved. Sworder's case is an exceptional one, and I think the Department should do something to recoup him for his heavy loss.

Wishing you the Compliments of the season.

Yours faithfully,

Frank Pedley, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have the honour to draw your attention to the fact that a night watchman should be employed at the Qu'Appelle Industrial at once. The buildings and plant are worth about One Hundred Thousand dollars and there are about two Hundred and Fifty people sleeping in each building every night, and if a fire took place at midnight and got well under way it would be a difficult matter to save these lives.

My opinion is that the School is in splendid shape financially and should bear the expense of this man's salary, but at the same time the Department should appoint the man. One can be engaged at $40.00 per month. He should be called upon to patrol all the stations, sixteen or seventeen, with his watch clock at least once an hour. The key of the clock should be kept by the Clerk, who should examine the paper dial every morning and place a new one in for the next night.

A watchman's clock, sixteen stations, can be bought for $75.00 in Winnipeg, and I would ask authority to purchase one at once.

I hope the Department will insist on the employment of a watchman at once and that strict and rigid

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
rigid instructions be sent to the Principal on this important matter. There is an old man at the school nearly seventy years of age, whom Father Ugonnard will probably tell you can do the work.

I do not approve of this old man being engaged for this important work; a young man is wanted.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inscr. of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, December 6, 1906.

Sir—

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th ult., recommending the appointment of a night watchman for the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and in reply I beg to say that the Department agrees with you as to the necessity for a watchman for this institution, and you are hereby authorized to secure the services of a thoroughly reliable man for this position at the salary named by you, namely, $40 per month, to be paid by the school, and you should notify the Principal of your instructions in this direction.

You may also purchase a watchman's clock, sixteen stations, the key of which should be kept by the clerk, who should examine the dial every morning and replace it by a new one for night.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir,

I have been asked by Mr Sweder late book-keeper here and now with Mr Graham Inspector, to recommend his claim for compensation for losses in the fire that destroyed this school.

It gives me great pleasure to do anything I can to assist towards that end as I consider Mr Sweder's claim for compensation for losses in that fire merits your special consideration and sympathy.

Although I was not personally present at the fire, I have heard enough about it from all quarters to know that Mr Sweder was most energetic in fighting the flames, in assuring the safety of the children and in saving Government property and other buildings. From all accounts he could certainly have saved most, if not all, of his personal property had he not devoted his efforts to protecting and saving the property of the Government. We all recognized Mr Sweder's claim as a special one and his receiving compensation would be a just recognition of his services and would not lead to any further demands being made on the Department in consequence of losses in that fire.

I have the honour to be

sir

I have the honour to present for your favourable consideration some reasons that I hope will induce you to see the justice of my claim for compensation for the very heavy loss I sustained in the fire that destroyed the Indian Industrial School at Qu'Appelle on the 4th of January 1904. In January 1905 Mr Inspector Graham, who from his investigation of the fire knew the facts, recommended my case to your favourable consideration. Since then I have made enquiries as to any one else making any other claim for losses at this fire in the event of my receiving compensation, but as my case is looked upon as different to, and as my losses were so much larger than any of the others, as far as I can learn no one else intends pressing their claims, and in confirmation of this I enclose a letter from Rev J. Hugonard, whose losses were also large.

At the time of the fire I was book-keeper at the School and had nothing to do with the children in the ordinary course of events, but as I knew the children, the building, and had had some experience in fires, I took charge.

The Principal, Rev J. Hugonard, was in Ottawa at the time, the Assistant Principal, Rev P. Gealen, had only been in the building about twenty minutes, so, though my superior officer, as he did not know the building, the children, or the whereabouts of things, every one looked to me for orders. The Senior Boys' teacher was at his home for lunch, the Junior Boys' teacher, a young Irishman who was acting pro tem did not know all the children or the interior of the building. The furniceman was a new hand, the other male employees boarded at home and were at their homes having their noon meal, except the Farming Instructor, who, coming from home, discovered the fire.
There were over two hundred children in the building at the time; under my direction all were taken out quietly and some sick children were carried out on stretchers from the hospital. I fought the fire as long and as capably as I could, I was wet through repeatedly and had no cap or mitts. Under my direction bedding, clothing and stores of provisions were rescued and taken to a distance, out of danger. Still wet but having no change of clothing I had to arrange for sleeping accommodation for the children, the distribution of the blankets, for heating and cooking facilities and dining room accommodation, the housing of the provisions saved, etc.

I contracted bronchitis and got very sore eyes, and was under the Doctor's orders for some weeks, though there was too much for me to see about to remain in bed as the Doctor advised; my eyes have been permanently weakened and my heart action has not recovered and probably never will.

I saved most of the business records of the school.

The wood yard with about two hundred cords of dry wood and two out buildings were on fire at different times; it was in saving one of these out buildings that I got thoroughly wet, having water thrown on me to keep my clothes from catching fire, less than ten feet separated the building destroyed from the one we saved, the glass and window frames in the latter were consumed by fire, and the roof was alight several times.

When I realized the impossibility of saving the main buildings of the school, if there had been another person to take charge, I could have saved the business books and documents and then could have easily saved my own things except perhaps the heaviest furniture. The Office and my private room had a separate passage cut off from the main hall by a door, so these rooms remained intact and were the freest from smoke for a long time.

I have lived at Qu'Appelle since 1882 and had accu-
ulated a lot of things; my loss in furniture, bedding and equipment; oil and water colour paintings; books and wearing apparel; shooting, cricket tennis, photographic and microscopic outfits; collections of foreign coins and postage stamps; minerals, Indian, natural history, and other curios; harness saddle etc., and $130.00 in cash, amounted to over $3500.00.

Three thousand five hundred Dollars would not nearly replace what I lost in the fire, and money could not replace the sentimental value of many things. I had $300.00 insurance on some of my pictures and furniture and I would respectfully present my claim for Seven hundred and fifty Dollars, being less than one quarter of my losses, and which I would willingly give to be physically as fit now as I was previous to the fire.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Deputy
of the Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Respected Sir,

Permit my voice to echo the sentiments of all present who offer you a most hearty welcome to our dear home, which was so generously given us by the Department.

We are aware that you were instrumental in the re-building of the school, and we fail to express our gratitude for the gift was so great; however, we gladly accept of this occasion to tell you how much we appreciate your liberality, for you took pity on our children, and gave us back what the cruel fire had taken away. In return, we hope to be ever worthy of all that is being done for us.

Thanking you kind sir, for the honor conferred upon us today by your visit, and wishing you many years of good health to continue your work in its high position you occupy. We beg to remain, with deep gratitude,

Your respectful children

The pupils of the Pi'Appilii Ind. School

Sir,

We wish to bring a few facts under your notice in connection with the Quappaw Industrial School which we hope and trust will be remedied as soon as possible, and if not we shall be compelled to have it enquired into by our representative. We understand that the Govt is paying into the School each year at the rate of two thousand dollars per month in addition to other things by way of vouchers, and in addition built them a fine...
School at an enormous expense we suppose and we know that this money is coming out of the pockets of the public and naturally we would like to know and have a lawful right to know that this money is spent fairly.

In the first instance and one of the greatest complaints is the principal who his staff buy a lot of goods dry-goods and so forth with the school money supposing this to be for the Indians and instead of giving and using this for the Indian children they keep almost a general store and sell and trade with the half-breeds and by doing this...
they are working in opposition to our store, and then we learn from authority that the profits is not going into the School funds at least the books do not show it. The question is then where is this money going. Another every year the School grows a lot of potatoes and various other kinds of vegetables and we know for a fact that the principal sells hundreds and if we say thousands of acres worth of vegetables for now a number of years past and we know that this money is not going into the School funds. The beauty of the thing is he buys a lot of potatoes each year again the same with milk and butter the same with meat at the present time for instance he kills his own
brief from his own ranch and charge the Govt a big price for it; then as we know and see with our own eyes every day he sells part of this meat out to other people and we are told that this money does not go into the School funds. So there must a fortune in this school for somebody, and we ask the honest question why this is not stopped. We hope and trust it will be stopped at once; if not we will see that it is stopped. There are a hundred other things which we hear and think is wrong and the public must know and know at once.

Fair play
Honesty

24th April 1907.

Sir:

When you were at File Hills last November you very kindly promised to see if you could not get me some compensation for my losses in the fire that destroyed the Qu'Appelle School in January 1904. I saw in a recent Free Press that the estimates for the Indian Department had been passed and I trust my case has not escaped your favourable consideration.

The loss of all my personal property wiped away nearly all I had to show for twenty-two years pioneering in this district and after passing through the bad seasons, the lack of railway facilities, and the experimental stage it was exceedingly hard line to have to mortgage what real estate I had to equip myself again in clothing, furniture etc., and meet my obligations, and to practically make a new start; especially at a time when this Western country had just commenced to develop so rapidly.

As you know I lost my property entirely through taking charge of the saving of the Government property and I am sure you will admit that the compensation of $750.00 that I asked for is very reasonable as my losses amounted to over $3500.00, and the new outfit of clothing, bedding, travelling equipment and furniture I had to purchase when transferred from clerk at the Industrial School to Clerk to Mr Graham, of the South Saskatchewan Inspectorate would not leave much of that sum.

Physically I have never been as well since my exertions in that fire, as in some way I strained my heart, and my eyes were permanently weakened from the smoke and heat; I had my eyebrows and eye-lashes singed off.

On account of not being able to realize on last season's farm produce, as yet, through car shortage on the branch lines,

F. Podley Esq:
Deputy of the Supt. General
Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter above quoted and observe that you have received a report from the Qu'Appelle Industrial School to the effect that there is a deficit of $4723.27 at that institution, which deficit you are told is due to work paid for on the new building out of the Per Capita grant. I stopped sending in the Pay Lists on the 16th of August, 1906 for work in connection with these buildings, but since that date there have been odd jobs such as patching, repairing, work on outbuildings and many other matters that would naturally have been carried on in any other institution of this size, and paid for out of Per Capita grant. These size have all been charged up to New Buildings but should in my opinion, be paid from the grant and this was understood by the Principal, who will, to my mind have no difficulty in settling this matter.

Ottawa, October 10th, 1907.

Memorandum,

The Accountant.

Will you please look into the general question of buying, selling and contracting for the Qu'Appelle Industrial School and see what system is followed in regard to this. You might refer to Inspector Graham's reports in this connection.

D. S. J. I. A.
MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General.

With reference to the attached memorandum regarding the system in vogue at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School for purchases and sales and contracting, I have to say that as this School is on a per capita grant we have no definite information as to their current methods. As the School is self-supporting it is evident that the management is conducted on that basis and that so far as their purchases under contract and otherwise are concerned they are probably made economically. In the winter of 1905 I see that Inspector Graham asked us for advice on certain questions. Mr. Benson reported on his letter and referred the question to me to be considered in connection with some matters that I had then in hand. I remember the reference distinctly, but the file was evidently taken away and I have not seen it since. It was probably the Qu'Appelle Industrial School that Mr. Graham had in view when he wrote his letter.

With reference to Mr. Graham's first question I should say that the Department should have a rule to be observed by per capita schools that they should not traffic in ordinary merchandise, but should sell only the agricultural or trade products of the school. I think it perfectly fair that they should compete with general merchants or farmers for crops raised or articles made at the school, but I think they should not be
allowed to buy general merchandise and re-sell it at a profit thus entering into competition with local merchants along their own lines of business.

In answer to Mr. Graham's second question I should say that so long as these transactions are shown in the books and that the staff was not allowed long credits for these transactions there is no serious objection to the practice. As the Principal himself pays the staff from the per capita grant he has almost perfect control of collections.

As regards the third question, it is so open to abuse that I think the whole matter of these outside contracts should be the subject of a report by the Principal of the school, and that he should receive the permission of the Department before entering into them. He is supposed to conduct his school, so far as its educative function goes, on a certain curriculum or system. How far this system may or may not be violated by outside contracts is open to question; and a question we should have the opportunity of deciding. One can easily understand how the Principal anxious to make his school a financial success would indulge to too great an extent in this practice, and make his boys and instructors simply a means to that end. A wider mechanical experience of what these contracts lead to might be of value to the boys in certain stages of their development; but it appears to me the Department should have the full facts placed before it when these contracts are being made, and that we should be able to judge by our Inspector's reports (as the matter would then become one of general management) what the main results are and whether they are valuable or not. Inspector Graham's report in 1905 was not specially pointed at
the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, but it was probably intended to apply to that school. If you thought it advisable to approach the matter openly we might ask the Principal to give us a statement of these contracts in the last two years; the number of boys employed, their ages, how long they have been in the school, under what supervision they work, name of instructor, rate of wages, time employed &c. &c.

Accountant.
Ottawa, October 14th, 1907.

Referring to your letter to the Department dated 20th February 1905 making advice with reference to certain transactions at Industrial Schools I have to say that it is evident that the Department should have a rule to be observed by per capita schools that they should not traffic in ordinary merchandise, but should sell only the agricultural or trade products of the school; they should not be allowed to buy general merchandise and re-sell it at a profit thus entering into competition with local merchants along their own lines of business.

So long as transactions with members of the staff are shown in the books there appears to be no serious objection to the practice of members of the staff purchasing from the school; but it should be distinctly understood that the transactions are to appear on the ledgers of the school and that no long credits should be allowed.

As regards your third question, the matter is certainly a serious one and should receive the attention of the Department. Would it be possible for you to report what the outside contracts undertaken by the Qu'Appelle Industrial School have been during the past two years; how many pupils and instructors have been employed on them, and any other information which would give the Department the full facts. It is thought that these contracts should come under the survey of the Depart-

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Balcarres, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 660-1, part 1)
ment in some way in order that it may be clear that the pupils and staff are not being exploited as a means of making money for the institution with detriment to its general educative value.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.
Was a mission for 35 years under Father Hugonard.

The School was built in 1884 on a section of land at the foot of Lake Qu'Appelle; 50 acres in valley and 2 sections on high bluff. The bottom is good hay land, situated 6 miles distant. Desires more land as that near the School is a little light for farming.

The new building is the largest yet seen; was built by the Department, completed last year. Main building is 120 by 180; has kitchen, dining room, offices, waiting rooms and special rooms on 1st floor;(storage rooms in basement); A chapel and Sisters' room on second floor; Hospital on third floor. There is also the girls' house, 50 by 80, and the boys' house, 50 by 80,— connected with main building by a covered passage.

Staff:
Principal,- Rev. Fr. Hugonard.
Asst. do.,— Fr. Buel.
Two male teachers.
One accountant & Head Master.
One Farmer.
Ten Sisters.

Pupils:
In attendance when visited:- Boys,-105;
and Girls,- 130. Drawn from southern reserves and R.C. boarding schools. Insp. Graham states that the recruiting is not so difficult as it was formerly. There were 7 children found in bed from various causes,(1 consumptive), and 7 additional afflicted with scrofulous glands. (See my letter to Department written from School; No. 309,157 file).

School Work:
The younger pupils have whole day in school, with hours from 9 to 12 and from 1.30 to 4; the older pupils have half-day system. Instructed in all outdoor work,—farming, carpentry; indoor work includes bakery, cooking, housework &c.
The plumbing is complete with baths and W.C. (Sanitary throughout; septic tank in yard and overflow to condition & water supply.) the river. There are Mr. Robie fire-extinguishers and ample fire-escapes provided.

The water supply is from the lake; is pumped by a 4½ H.P. gasoline engine to a 3,000 gal. capacity tank located in basement; the hard water for drinking purposes is supplied by a well.

Lighting is by acetylene gas.

(Ventilation;) The ventilation is inadequate; it could readily be remedied by shafts from each furnace room with steam coils heating the air. Such was advised by me during construction.

(RECOMMENDATIONS) There would seem to be two requirements to this fine school. The one is the lack of adequate ventilation, referred to above, and the other is that greater attention should be paid to the admission of healthy children and more immediate attention to the treatment of those children with tubercular glands. Would recommend that a Hospital Tent be supplied, (See file 309,157), and that operative cases from neighboring R.C. schools be brought here for treatment.

Father Hugonard has proved his great ability as (IMPRESSIONS) an organizer, but certain old ideas with regard to tubercular cases and their treatment demand that the medical officer act promptly in this matter. While Dr. Harvey, the medical officer of this School, is young, I have instructed him in the presence of both Insp. Graham and Father Hugonard, to remove the considerable number of tubercular patients to tents and operate, and it is probable this reproach will be removed.

(Note,- Regarding action re cases of tubercular cases, for treatment of which a Tent Hospital was sent in June, 1907, see file 309,157 for correspondence.)

Sir,

Manitoba and North West Cheque No. 57 for the current fiscal year, is for a payment of $500.00 to E. D. Sworder, being compensation for loss sustained from the fire that destroyed the Qu'Appelle Industrial School on the 4th January, 1904. On the slip placed among the accounts in support of this payment, which is signed by F. H. Paget, as Acting Accountant, it is stated that provision for the same was made in the Supplementary Estimates of 1907-08 under Vote 483 for Schools. On reference to the Supplementary Estimates, I find that no mention of this item is made at all. The estimate reading simply 'To provide a further amount for schools.' As the item in question passed the House without any discussion, I do not see that it can be held that Parliament specifically authorized this payment. I am strongly of opinion that all cases of this nature should be made a special item in the estimates, instead of being included in the ordinary estimates. In the present case, as this item was not specifically sanctioned by Parliament, I have to request that you obtain an Order in Council sanctioning the payment. A statement should also be submitted by Mr. Sworder, showing how the amount claimed by him was arrived at.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Auditor General.

The Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st Nov. last regarding the payment of $500.00 made to Mr. E. D. Sworder as compensation for loss, etc. In reply I beg to enclose herewith list of the articles lost by Mr. Sworder, with their estimated value, and I have also to inform you that the following explanation was before Council when the item was allowed for the Estimates and before the House while in Committee of Supply:

At the time of the fire Mr. Sworder was Book-keeper of the School. Although he had no personal responsibility with reference to the management of the children, knowing that there might be great loss of life if they were not removed quietly without panic, under his personal direction all were taken out safely and even some sick children were carried from the Hospital. After performing this useful service he fought the fire, and, owing to a thorough wetting that he received, he caught cold which settled in his eyes and permanently weakened them, so he states, and that the exposure and excitement of this occasion has materially weakened the action of his heart. Owing to his interest in saving Government property and lives under the care of the officers of the School, he neglected to save his own personal effects; some of which were very valuable. Mr. Sworder puts in a statement estimating the value of these effects at $447.00. It is proposed to compensate him to some extent for this loss by the grant

The Auditor General,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant (file No. 116,575, I.B.), in reply to mine of November 21st last, regarding a payment of $500.00 made to Mr. E. D. Sworder, as compensation for loss, etc. Although an explanation of this appears to have been included in the key to the Estimates, it does not appear to me that Parliament when voting the estimate in question was aware that an item of this nature was included therein. I am of the opinion that every special item of this or of a similar nature, which is not directly concerned with the carrying out of the Indian policy of the Government, should be specifically voted by Parliament. I have, accordingly, to request that a specific vote to cover this payment be obtained from Parliament in the Supplementary Estimates for the current fiscal year.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Auditor General.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Honorable Sir,

I beg to submit to your favorable consideration the following report of the financial situation of this institution and the insufficiency of the grant.

The Qu'Appelle school was placed by the Dept. of the capitation system in 1894 and the grant to each school was based on their respective cost. As this school was managed more economically, I have received ever since the smallest grant of all the Industrial Schools of the North West viz $120.00 per capita and only $65 for all pupils under 10 years old. Regina and Battleford receive $145 and they are by the railroad while we are 19 miles away, incurring an expenditure of over $100.00 for freight from the station. No school is farther away from a road and no school receives a smaller grant.

The Hon.
Sup. Govt of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Your Honor is undoubtedly aware that since 1894, the cost of supplies, material and labor has increased considerably. The heating of three separate buildings and the lighting by acetylene cost more. The occupation of the land around, the scarcity of wood, the distance from coal mines are another cause of increase of expenditure although this school is managed with the same old economy.

My efforts have failed to keep the deficit from increasing and it was over $7000.00 at the end of December as per our financial statement sent in monthly.

I beg to ask that the grant to the Qu'Appelle School be the same as to Regina and Battleford viz $145.00 per capita, and I hope you will consider the demand as fair and justified.

I am, Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal

Honourable Sir,

I beg to acknowledge, with pleasure, your letter of the 22nd ult stating your willingness to decrease our deficit by $3000.00 when proper accounts confirmed by Mr Graham are sent in. As Mr Graham has not yet returned the accounts have not been sent and we have to pay interest on overdue bills.

The above sum will pay less than half of our deficit and I was depending on the increase of grant and with economy to pay the balance in time but the increase was not allowed and could not be promised so I had to study the situation from a business point of view and at the approach of the new fiscal year I have come to the following conclusions:

1. The smallness of the grant which has made the deficit in the past will also cause a deficit in future.

2. Besides specials and temporary causes of the deficit there are permanent ones viz., increase of cost of supplies, a large salary of $800.00 per year imposed by the Department, the increase in cost of labor, the increased cost of light and fuel for three separate buildings and the fact that we had to procure three car loads of coal more than was expected.

3. The requisition to increase the grant to $145.00 having been already granted to two schools on railroad lines would create no new policy for the Department.

4. The distance from railways costs us $5.00 per head to freight supplies specially on coal. I feel that I cannot manage the school any longer with a deficit and an insufficient grant and the refusal of any increase of grant would
force me to the conclusion that you do not want me to manage
the school any longer since I cannot manage the financial
part without going into debt.

I have the honour to be

sir

Your obedient servant

J. Hugonard

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge, with pleasure, the receipt of your letter No 116575/1 of January 28th, 1910 advising an increase of $10.00 per head from 1st April next. It will be a much needed help towards the financing of the school.

As your letter states that the grant is $130 per head for 225 pupils, I take it to mean 225 full grants including pupils below ten years.

I notice that your letter No 116575/10 of April 16th 1909 stated that the object of the half grant was to discourage the recruiting of children below 10 years but the recruiting of this school in sufficient number would become impossible if children were not taken in before 10 years of age.

At the time this regulation was made it was understood that a system of day schools and boarding schools would act as feeders to Industrial schools where the children would not need to be taken before 10 but the policy had to be abandoned.

On the Muscowpetung Agency the Department closed three day schools and two boarding schools to have the children come to the Industrial school.

The sooner Indian children come to school the less difficult it will be to teach them English and to have them forget Indian habits and to acquire civilized ways.

The half grant reduction for small pupils has been one of the factors in crippling the finances of this Institution.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 4th. instant addressed to the Hon. Frank Oliver, I beg to say that in future no half-breeds will be admitted to Boarding or Industrial Schools conducted by this Department for the education of Indian children. Probably there were some few half-breed children admitted in the past for whom the management of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School is not paid the usual per capita grant by this Department, but in future such children will not be allowed in residence. There is no intention, however, of dismissing the few half-breed children who are now in the schools as this action would probably cause hardship.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Sir:

I beg to inform you of the result of a trip I have made in order to recruit Indian children to replace half-breed children as per your instructions.

I visited the neighboring reserves also the Assiniboine, Moose Mountain and the Sioux reserves at Pipestone and Oak Lake and have been able to replace only six half-breed pupils by Indian ones.

Having noticed the condition of the reserves for our ex-pupils I have considered it my duty to inform the Agent of the Qu'Appelle Agency the condition of affairs as regards dancing giving him information I easily obtained owing to my knowledge of the Indian language, and I herewith inclose a copy of my letter.

We have had two cases of Scarlet Fever which have been isolated outside of the Institution. The quarantine has been raised on the 15th inst.

The management of the school is as usual.

Qu'Appelle Board of Trade
Incorporated at Fort Qu'Appelle

Fort Qu'Appelle, Feb. March 25th 1913

Mr Campbell Esq
Winnipeg.

Dear Mr Campbell,

I am directed to call your attention to a state of affairs which existed at Lebret under the auspices of the Indian Industrial School last year, and which we look to you and the Dept to put a stop to, and give some others a chance. The people of Lebret aided and backed by those in authority of the Industrial went out of their way to cater for picnics from Regina and Melville, and got them. They were entertained in the school grounds, had in fact the full use of them, were fed in the School itself, at whose expense, or who got the money for the meals we are not in a position to say, but what we are in a position to say is, that we do not think it is right, that Government institutions should be allowed to run counter to towns which have no government institutions. Now take for example Fort Qu'Appelle. We purchased 30 acres of land last year for a public park. This cost us $2500 for the land alone and we are spending another $1000 or $1500 fixing the grounds up this spring. Now seeing we pay taxes for the upkeep of the country we do not think it is quite the thing to see places like Lebret who do not pay a cent for their grounds, butting in and taking legitimate trade away from us. We bought those grounds for the express purpose of getting the Regina and Melville people, and we cannot stand idly aside and let the Indian Industrial School get business which by rights belongs to us. I trust you will look into this state of affairs, and put a stop to it so that we can have a fair show.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Industrial School

of Qu'Appelle - Sask.

April 29th, 1913.

Letter No. 7974.

Sir:

Your Letter No. 116575/1 of the 18th inst received.

In reply I would say that the Secretary's version of the matter in question is not correct. Picnics from Regina and Melville were not catered for and secured to the disadvantage of the Board of Trade of Fort Qu'Appelle.

The facts are these; Deputations from Sunday Schools and other Societies came here and asked if they might be allowed to use the School grounds for their sports and, as was customary, permission was granted.

The Qu'Appelle Industrial School has always been an attraction for visitors and last year a greater number came on account of the favorable railway facilities.

Owing to the scanty accommodation for the feeding of visitors, the School served a number of meals at the urgent request of those who were unable to get food otherwise.

It was explained that any meals served here was a special privilege and only because few meals could be obtained at other places that any were served at all.

The School cannot be blamed for the Regina and Melville people choosing Lebret as a picnic point. If the Board of Trade of Fort Qu'Appelle wish to come here and cater to the crowds that intend coming this summer, the school has not the slightest objection and in fact would be glad if they undertook this, but it is certain that the School cannot compel the G.T.P. Railway from advertising excursions to this point.

Lebret being the most picturesque spot on the Qu'Appelle
Lakes, it is quite natural that the general public would select it for a day's sport or rest as the case may be.

Lebret is distant some miles from Fort Qu'Appelle and it is beyond us to understand how the School can interfere with the Public Park there.

It is not our intention to serve meals this year as there is better accommodation now but far from sufficient and therefore we are urging some society to take this matter in hand.

We understand that the G.T.P. has already booked seven excursions to Lebret and we feel certain that the Department would not ask us to exclude visitors from the School, either the grounds or the buildings.

We emphatically state that we have not taken any legitimate trade from the Board of Trade of Fort Qu'Appelle nor is it our intention to do so at any future time. It would be more reasonable that objections would come from our local people and as none have been made it would seem that the School acted wisely considering circumstances.

In conclusion we would ask the Department to allow us to feed the hungry if circumstances calls for it.

Your obedient servant

Acting Principal

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa - Ont.

READ THE NOTICE AND AGREEMENT AT THE TOP
Ottawa, June 4, 1923.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your telegram of the 25th ultimo, which reads as follows:

"The mayor of Regina alderman and city staff have requested the school to serve four hundred meals on June third. May we do so if others are unable now and on future occasion see our letter on seventy nine seventy four April twenty ninth."

To which the following reply was sent you by wire.

"Department does not approve of school grounds being used for picnic purposes."

In this connection I beg to say that while your letter of the 25th April, last, in explanation of the communication from the Secretary of the Qu'Appelle Board of trade complaining that your school catered for picnics from Regina and Wilville last year was accepted, the Department does not consider it is in the interest of the school to have the grounds thrown open to the public for picnic purposes, as it would have a disturbing influence on the pupils. The Department does not approve of the practice being continued.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

Rev. M. Kalms,
Acting Principal,
Qu'Appelle Industrial School,
Lebret, Sask.,

Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

I called at Interior Dept. today and paid respects to the Minister. My mission is in connection with the Lebre (La Cappelle) Industrial School. As you are the acting and real head of the Indian Dept., it is only proper I should come to you and I know the Minister would not do anything without consulting you. I was told you were out of town so have sent a few lines.

According to instructions the Half-breed children on the Lists 5 La Cappelle Ind. School should have been removed at the end of June Quarter. The Principal, Mr. Auger, undertook a recruiting campaign last winter but was obliged to interrupt on account of illness and has been disabled ever since. The result is that the Admissions during the last 12 months were only 37 (Treaty Child), and about 20 Treaty children were discharged during same period (deaths, marriages, other causes).

The net result is that there are still 51 non-Treaty Children on a list of 225. In the interest of the school I feel obliged to plead the case of those...
Children and submit the following:

1. Because of illness & Principal recruiting could not be attended to effectively.

2. With the No. 8 discharges yearly it is almost too much to expect to eliminate 50 children and make up for ordinary discharges besides.

3. It seems a very drastic measure to turn away children when their course of training is already begun but only half completed.

4. The school cannot afford such a loss of revenue when expenditure will practically continue the same. It is well then in mind that cost of living has greatly increased during last years.

5. The Half breed problem is at present under consideration by the Ind. Dept., and intimation has already been made that it was not the intention of the Dept. to apply exclusion rules to the half breed children (whatever the ultimate ruling may be).

My suggestion in regard to the problem facing us at Our Opelle School would be simply to admit those already on the list (half breeds) - there have been no new admissions in the last two years - or if there is no formal admission to allow these names remain on the list until elimination takes place by ordinary discharges.
This course will permit the school to go ahead and keep up its attendance although no other half-breeds should be accepted in future. In the meantime a different ruling may prevail in regard to half-breed children in their relations to the schools.

I think the above remarks will appeal to you as carrying some weight. Knowing your interest in our Indian work and your familiarity with its problems I confidently trust that a solution will be found to bridge us over the present difficulty at the La Appelle Indian School.

I am leaving the city today but will be back about Tuesday or latest Wednesday next week.

Yours very sincerely,

Chas. Cahill

Sir;

I wish to inform the Department that a Hotel has been erected in the village of Lebret within a few hundred yards from the Indian School.

Last Spring I was successful in preventing a License being granted but there is a strong feeling now in favor of a license on the ground that a hotel cannot be operated successfully without one.

A licensed hotel is not a good thing to have so close to the Indian School on account of so many Indians and halfbreeds coming here to see their children.

I could successfully oppose the granting of a license only with the assistance of the Department and would request that your Department could obtain from the Department of Justice a ruling that no license be granted in the village of Lebret for the reasons above stated.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit herewith a report of inspection of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School made between Feb 10th. and 20th, 1914.

It is my duty to bring the following matter to your notice. I found about—fifty half-breed children in this institution over and above the number shown on the last returns sent in vis. 43. I also found that the practice is followed of drawing a grant for Indians for three, six nine and in some cases for 12 months after they have left the institution, their names appearing on the return sent to you as if they had been present and receiving regular instruction. The explanation given me is that while the Indians whose names appear on the return were not in the school there were sufficient half-breed children there, over and above the 43, to make up the required number. As you are aware the school has an authorized grant for 225 pupils. I think it is a mistake allowing the Principal to admit half-breed children without even referring to the Department, even if they are not grant earners. In my opinion, every admission, whether Treaty or non-treaty should be authorized by you. It is wrong having children in school and leaving their names off the returns that are sent to the Department.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham

Inspec. ogé of Indian Agencies.

Mr. Scott,

Father Hugonard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, has written the Department stating that the Roman Catholic Bishop of Regina has asked that the secular priests of his diocese to the number of 30 or 40 be allowed to make a four days spiritual retreat at the school, as there is no other suitable place available for this purpose. Some time in October 1896 Rudolph Bocz was employed at the Indian school as a manufacturer of felt under a certain arrangement apparently made with the Rev. Father Hugonnard. Dear sir,

Allow me to call your attention to the tradesmen at the Industrial School at Lebret.

They are doing painting outside of the school and this is taking away work which should come my way. Most years I run a business of from 8 to 10 men, but this year I will be satisfied if I can find enough work to keep myself going and I think it unfair that men can use the Government shops to compete with outside labor, as they can work much cheaper, and I take the liberty to ask you to stop it.

My Dear Mr. Scott,-

The young Indian who wrote the letter I sent you as an exhibit is named Allie Nokohoot and is a grandson of old Chief White Bear. He was six years at the Regina Industrial School, not at Lebret as my first informant stated. His education cost the Department $840.00 (Eight hundred and forty dollars). I understand when he left school he got entangled with a bad squaw from Turtle Mountain and for two years he was useless. The agent endeavoured to start him farming and gave him a yoke of steers which had to be taken from him after about a year. He now has a pair of small ponies and is doing a little farming but is more or less of a loafer. He is now married and has one child. This is all the information regarding him I can gather.

Yours sincerely,

Indian Industrial School

at Lebret - Sask.

June 5th, 1915.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of May 22nd re trade shops doing work for the public. There is no good ground for any complaint made against our shops. We have a carpenter who is a first class wheelwright and as there is no wheelwright in this village and none in the neighborhood five rigs were repaired for the public who asked to have the work done as a favor which work was done to the great satisfaction of those concerned, we have no regular outside trade and no outside accounts, the little that has been done was a cash deal.

We are selling some vegetables during summer and Fall to accommodate the public and some person might consider this as a complaint also.

We do not at all times have sufficient work to keep a wheelwright busy and what little was done for the public could not be done in the village so there was no competition besides this work benefits the school by enabling us to keep a good man when the work of the school is slack, who repairs our machinery and other implements which otherwise have to be taken to other villages for repair.

The complaint comes from an ex-employee who was discharged for being incompetent and who applied to the Conservative Candidate to be reinstated. It would be regretable if by such means the ex-employee could have the satisfaction of injuring the school to satisfy a personal spite.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa - Ont.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa - Ont.
Sir;—I beg to submit for your consideration a report on our financial standing and an application for an increase of grant.

This school is managed, as you know, with a grant per capita since 1894, the grant was fixed at $115.00 besides drugs, medical attendance and stationary and the grant was the smallest of all Industrial Schools in the North West, at a later date the grant was raised to $130.00.

The increase in the cost of supplies and salaries soon brought a deficit which was $3000.00 at the end of 1900. In 1911 the deficit was $7000.00 and it is now $xx about $8000.00.

The fires of some time ago likely increased the deficit as the management had to replace grain, vegetables, provisions and other material destroyed.

Although every effort has been made to increase the receipts from the farm, to keep up the number of pupils and to economize whenever possible, still the steady increase of cost of supplies and labor caused deficit to increase and to render the management impossible unless a remedy is found to relieve the situation.

The division of the new school into 3 separate buildings has made the heating and lighting more expensive. Many articles of supplies are twice as high as formerly viz; meat, flour, wages and clothing.

The present number of children is about 15 less than the authorized number which means $2000.00 less grant with very little decrease in the expenses and I fear a larger decrease in the number of pupils.

The increased cost of living has been felt in almost every branch of the Government service and has necessitated a redress in most cases.

The above considerations, the amount of our deficit and the prospect of an increased deficit has forced me to ask for better terms.

If the department would pay our present deficit an increase of grant of $15.00 per head may be sufficient to carry on the work without loss but if the Department does not pay our present deficit it would certainly require an increase of $2 $20.00 per head to enable us to reduce gradually the present deficit.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Principal

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa - Ont.

Sir;-

I beg to refer to my Letter No 8289 of Dec last re increase of grant and to state that the deficit on the 31st of December last was exactly $10,570.34 which amount was reached by the purchase of beef, flour and coal for the winter. The necessity for an increase of grant is urgent.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Principal

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa - Ont.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Rev. Father Hugonard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, wrote on the 4th ultimo and submitted a statement which showed a deficit of about $8,000.00. The school has been going behind for a number of years and Father Hugonard claims that the present grant of $130.00 per capita is not sufficient to meet the running expenses of the school, although the strictest economy is exercised. He says that the deficit is occasioned by the increase in the cost of supplies and salaries and that the fires which have taken place there have increased it, as the management has had to replace grain, vegetables, provisions and other materials destroyed. The division of the new school into three separate buildings made the heating and lighting more expensive. Father Hugonard asks to be relieved of the deficit, which, in a letter just received dated the 12th instant, he states amounts to $10,570.34. This includes the purchase of beef, flour and coal for the winter. He claims...
claims that, even if this deficit were paid, it would still be necessary to have an increased grant to meet the current expenses.

The grant of $130.00 is as high as is paid to other schools of this class and we have in the past paid deficits for schools conducted by other denominations. If the cost of the Elkhorn school is considered, it would appear that $130.00 per capita is not enough to meet the current expenses of an industrial school in the west under existing prices. The missionary societies or the protestant denominations help out the cost of the management of the schools by contributions of money and clothing, while this school is only dependent on the government grant for its support.

Although there is an existing deficit to the amount stated by Father Hugonard the school has assets in the neighbourhood of $30,000.00, as shown by the statements submitted by Mr. Inspector Graham with his report of the 12th of November, last, herewith. Mr. Inspector Graham, who made a thorough examination of the school then, reported most favourably on the conditions there and I think Father Hugonard's application is deserving of the favourable consideration of the Department.

Referring to your letter No. 116,575-13 of May 8th, 1916.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter above quoted, and in reply would say that I visited the Qu'Appelle school yesterday for the purpose of investigating the complaint by Mr. Martyn of Fort Qu'Appelle, that Mr. Carriere, the blacksmith at the school, was allowed to take in outside work, thus interfering with Mr. Martyn's business.

I find that Mr. Carriere is not a regular employee of the school. He has a blacksmith shop of his own in the village of Lebret. Occasionally he is employed at the school to do work in their blacksmith shop, there being no blacksmith at the school. At times while at the school outsiders have come to Mr. Carriere to get small jobs done. This is where the mistake was made—in doing work for his own private profit, with Government tools and on Government property. I have instructed the Principal not to allow such a practice.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
to continue. I have also forbidden Mr. Carriere to use the Government property for other purposes than school work, and he has promised there will be no ground for complaint in the future.

I should be glad if you will confirm my instructions.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Inspr. of Indian Agencies.
June 26th, 1916.

Rev. Sir -

Sometime ago the Department was informed that Mr. Carriere, the blacksmith at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, was doing outside work during school hours. Dear Mr. Scott,

For some little time I have intended writing to you personally regarding matters at the Qu'Appelle School, but put off doing so until I received the quarterly returns for Sept. 30th, which I am sending to you with this letter. I wish to call your attention to the sad neglect of class-room training that is being shown here. Matters in this regard have been going from bad to worse and I think the time has come to make a complete change. Allowing that July was not a teaching month, there would be 42 teaching days in the quarter, but we find from the returns that nine days was the most that any boy attended the class-room and many of them were there only 2 days. In the girls Department things are almost as bad. I may say I have received many complaints from parents of late about the manner in which their children are treated. They claim they are receiving no education and that the sole aim of the Principal is to get the children to school to make them work and not to teach them. I think that if you look through the returns, not only of this quarter

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
but for previous terms, that you will agree with me
that they have some ground for their complaints.

I have told Father Hugonnard that he is
getting away from the idea of the Department and
that our schools must not be turned into work houses.
The trouble is that Father Hugonnard, not being well,
has handed over a great deal of the work to Father
Kalmes, his assistant Principal, and as he has increased
outside work to such an extent, the main idea and object
of the school is being entirely neglected, in my opinion.

In order to make a complete change instructions
will need to be quite emphatic and I would suggest
that the Department insist that every child under 14
years of age be required to attend class-room the full
number of teaching days in each quarter (unless prevented
by sickness), and that pupils over 14 years of age, should
be in the class-room at least half the time.

The Indian parents, especially the educated ones,
and those who are farming at home, claim that if their
boys are to go to school to do nothing but work, they
can make better use of them at home.

I should like to have a copy of any instructions
that are sent to Father Hugonnard in this regard.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter 116575/1 of the 17th inst re attendance of pupils at class.

It might be observed that while the boys had only 9 days of class most of the girls had 22 days attendance. The pupils do not all take their holidays at the same time, some in July, others in August so if teaching is given to only part of a class the same work must be repeated when all pupils are in attendance while the industrial teaching can be given if only a part of a class is being instructed.

As for the boys we feel that they should get more class in the Fall in accordance with the wishes of the Department and of the Indians and we are trying to do so as much as is consistent with the management of the school about the Farm, garden and keeping the grounds in order.

The main industry for boys is farming and as there is none to be done in Winter, except the care of stock, they can be taught farming only in the Summer and chiefly in the Fall.

In winter time the boys go regularly to class both A.M. and P.M. to make up for the time spent on the farm in the Fall.

As to keeping boys under 14 years continually at class it is difficult to draw a line exactly at that age as some come late to school and need more class even at 14 years.

In the summer and fall when there is light work such as weeding, thinning out of vegetables and gathering the vegetables and only boys above 14 were taken the rest would be an incomplete class and these outside
could not have the overseeing of the Teacher who would have
to remain in class while if all go to the field the work is
quickly done and the Teacher being with them will see that
they talk and behave properly and that every one does his
share and well and the overseeing of a number of boys at work
is necessary.

During the year the boys under 14 years lose very little
class and the others have almost a continual class in the
winter and spring.

I may say that our farm being five miles away it is not
always easy for the boys working on it to come back for class
in the afternoon. Our boys are well advanced in their studies
and the work done does not prevent them, when leaving school,
to know as much as an ordinary farmer needs to know.

We shall endeavor to carry out your instructions as
near as possible.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Principal

Sir:

I beg to submit for your consideration a report on our financial standing and an application for an increase of grant.

This school is managed, as you know, with a grant per capita since 1894; the grant was fixed at $115.00 besides drugs, medical attendance and stationary and the grant was the smallest of all Industrial Schools in the North West; at a later date the grant was raised to $150.00.

The increase in the cost of supplies and salaries soon brought a deficit which was $3000.00 at the end of 1900. In 1911 the deficit was $7000.00 and it is now $9768.22.

The fires of some time ago likely increased the deficit as the management had to replace grain, vegetables, provisions and other material destroyed.

Although every effort has been made to increase the receipts from the farm to keep up the number of pupils and to economize wherever possible, still the steady increase of cost of supplies and labor have the deficit to increase and to render the management impossible unless a remedy is found to relieve the situation.

The division of the new school into 3 separate buildings has made the heating and lighting more expensive. Many articles of supplies are twice as high as formerly viz; meat, flour, wages and clothing.

The present number of children is about 20 less than the authorized number which means over $2000.00 less grant with very little decrease in the expenses and I fear a larger decrease in the number of pupils.

The increased cost of living has been felt in almost every branch of the Government service and has necessitated a re-dress in most cases.

The above considerations, the amount of our deficit and the prospect of an increased deficit has forced me to ask for better times.

If the Department would pay our present deficit an increase of grant of $15.00 per head may be sufficient to carry the work without loss but if the Department does not pay our present deficit it would certainly require an increase of $20.00 per head to enable us to reduce gradually the present deficit.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Scott,

On June 10th, 1915, you wrote to me regarding a complaint made by one, A. Beer, painter of Fort Qu'Appelle, in which he stated that the Qu'Appelle School was doing work for outsiders, thus competing with legitimate tradesmen who were paying taxes, rent etc.

I replied to this letter on June 16th, 1915, giving my views on Father Hugonnard's report on the matter.

On June 23rd, 1915, you informed me that you had written to Father Hugonnard informing him "that these trade-shops must not be employed in any way even to a moderate extent, for outside work."

These explicit instructions were apparently ignored for a year later you received a complaint from Mr. Martyn, Blacksmith of Fort Qu'Appelle, who stated that work was being done in the school shop for outsiders.

I was instructed by you to investigate this complaint, which I did, and reported to you on June 3rd, 1916, after having ascertained that the complaint was well founded.

I repeated to the Principal the instructions contained

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
in your letter of June 23rd, 1915. After having done this I asked you to confirm my instructions, but I was never advised as to whether this was done.

To-day I learn indirectly that your explicit instructions given direct to him on June 23rd, 1915, and again repeated to him by me in June 1916, are being ignored, as work is being done in the school blacksmith shop for outsiders.

Now, Mr. Scott, it seems to me that Father Hugonnard has gone about far enough in taking matters in his own hands in the face of such emphatic instructions, and unless he is prepared to carry out the orders of the Department, it is very little use for me to try to keep a check on what is going on, for as you know these are not the only instructions he has ignored. I have had continual trouble with him during the past few years.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

Your letter of the 9th instant came yesterday. I can assure you that what was done was not considered to be against the spirit of your instructions, but somewhat against the letter of it. The same things were done in the past to help a neighbour without any complaint, but there are here two parties divided chiefly by racial lines, and that is the real cause of the complaint. A neighbour was allowed to use our appliances to shoe wild horses. It was not done in disregard and still less in defiance of your instructions. But since your order is so imperative and since we are watched so closely, I have taken your measures to refuse any service to such a neighbour, even with the thought of sending our blacksmith work away, in order to avoid anything that might give the least reason to complaint.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

My Dear Sir,

We have proposed Nathan Leacy as the one best qualified to succeed Mr. Hugonard at Labat's Ind. School.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter written me on occasion of Father Rigonard's death. I must thank you for your kindness and courtesy in the matter. I trust there will be no unnecessary delay in the appointment of a successor. Certainly we are as anxious as anyone to have a competent man there.

I would suggest that the new Principal be given a little time to familiarize himself with conditions before launching an investigation. It was difficult to get the late Principal to depart from certain old rules—so far as we are not only disposed but determined to see every irregularity as to methods disappear, and to have the management carried out on straight business lines.

I will simply add that I have very confidence in the spirit and ability of the new Principal in respect to such matters.

If you will kindly wire me as soon as the appointment of the new Principal is an accepted affair, I will have his letter proceed without further delay to debut.

Your most obedient servant,

Chas. E. Hill

My dear Father Cahill,

You will have received my wire of February 28th. to the following effect:

"I will agree to Father Lecocq's appointment provisionally. Writing you."

I think highly of Father Lecocq's business capacity, but you will perhaps allow me to say that I do not think he speaks English well enough for this special position. As you well know, the Qu'Appelle industrial school is a sort of show place, and he will have to receive a good many visitors during the summer. Father Hugonard had a most excellent manner and spoke English quite fluently. For this reason and for one or two others, which I will mention when we meet, we have thought it well to make the appointment provisional.

Rev. Chas. Cahill, O.M.I.,
222 Provencher Avenue,
St. Boniface, Man.
Of course we hope that Father Lescq will be quite equal to his task, and you may be assured that I will give him every support.

The officer who will look into the school matters with the new principal is Inspector Graham, who is at present on leave. He will not be back at his Agency much before the 1st April, and the urgency of the spring work will likely delay the special action for a sufficient time to allow the principal to thoroughly familiarize himself with conditions.

I think Father Lescq has good financial ability and will be able, no doubt, to place the finances of the school on a better footing. At the same time what we want to improve particularly are the conditions under which the pupils have to work. It has been constantly represented that they are simply used as so much manual power to produce revenue for the school, and this has certainly been a factor in making recruiting difficult. Mr. Graham and Father Lescq should look carefully into these conditions. With kind regards, I am

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Superintendent General

School
The Last Sad Rites

On Tuesday, February 15, the last service was held at the Indian Industrial school for boys. Father Francis Macdonald was the celebrant for the occasion and was assisted by Oblate Fathers who have long been identified with the school: Fathers Kim and Boyer.

On Wednesday, February 16, services were held at the Mission Church, the first mission where Father Cahill served, from 1874. Father Cahill celebrated mass on the occasion and Father Daly of the Holy Rosary, Regina, preached the funeral sermon. It was a panoramic for the saintly priest, the zealous apostle, Father Cahill, who named the church after the prince of the western apostles, the pioneer of Catholic missions in Canada, the man who had accomplished more for those who needed the most.

If today the people could behold the flowers in bloom, it was due to the good planting of the good father. He planted the seeds of faith and desire to follow in the sacred path and apostolic career, and would be pleased to see the fruits of his labors. For those left behind...

Archbishop Beliveau celebrated pontifical mass at the church, Father Cahill assisting at the throne. Father Juhinville officiated as deacon, Father Brabant, and Father Daly as sub-deacon. Representing the Oblates were Father Grandin of Edmonton, and Father Frisque Magnan, formerly stationed at the school. Father Mathieu was arch-priest for the ceremony and delivered the main address.

Archbishop Mathieu delivered the principal address. Among the guests were Lieutenant-Governor Lake; Hon. W. R. Moberly, minister of agriculture; and J. G. Gardiner, M.L.A., for Prince Albert, and Mr. S. H. Smith, Saskatchewan government.

Other guests present were Archbishop Mathieu, of Regina; Archbishop Beliveau; Bishop Bourneau; Domine Muenter Abbey; Vicar General Ledoux, of the Edmonton archdiocese; Fathers Cahill and Grandin, the first provincial of the Oblate order in Montana province, the second provincial for the province of Alberta; Father Juhinville, of Edmonton; Father Daly, of the Holy Rosary cathedral, Regina; Father Sutin, of St. Mary's, Regina; and Father Thibault, of Edmonton.

Other life-long friends of the dead priest were present.
