FUNERAL ORATION BY ARCHBISHOP MATHIEU

Archbishop Mathieu preached the funeral oration in French and English and with a voice full of emotion and the eloquence of a master he said:

"The very pages of Holy Scripture we are drawn to the love of God by the admiration of His works. All creation, God's creation, is an invitation to the tiny blade of grass in the field is called to testify to the greatness, to the power and to the goodness of God who has done all through love.

But there is no image of God in this world the grandest and most beautiful such as that which the Father gave man; man whom He has made to His image and likeness, command, after Him, all that exists.

Among men themselves there are degrees. There are souls capable of showing more particularly the degree the most rare, the resemblance with the Author of Life. They resemble Him in their noblest vices, perfections and the traits of the Perfection. They manifest the grandeur, the magnificence of Him to whom they offer their lives, to whom they have received. Their life is like a sacred offering and a lasting glory of the Most High. Of these men is he called "mirabilis Deus in sancta sua," God in his holiness.

It seems to me that I can affirm without fear that the name of such a soul in him whose loss we deplore, good Father Hugonnard.

He caused him to be born in France, the country of light, to fill the privilege of giving to Jesus the blood of his children, the blood of Christ shed in infidel countries, in a unique position.

He granted him that great grace of being born in the bosom of one of those families distinguished by the fact that the father gives the example of a pure and holy life, that he is a model of fervor and her zeal, sustains and encourages the religious education.

He made him bear the Eternal Word which makes apostles. "Come and follow me," He says to him, "for I will give you a lively intellect and noble heart, unerring judgment and a firm resolve upon him; he bowed his head under the weight of a too holy glory and he trembled at the thought of the crown of priesthood which, like that of St. John the Baptist, must be washed in the blood to flow only for the glory of my Father in heaven."

How often the generosity of his immeasurable love, so strong that it was the superior part of his soul an inexhaustible source of joy and consolation, that pleasure of being saturated with divine things and which died away only when God Himself entered and reposes in the interior sanctum.

For over forty years, good Father Hugonnard devoted himself to mission work in our country. His whole life was all his riches. He devoted it religiously, to the service and care of the poor savages for whom civilisation with all its possibilities seemed to cast aside without shelter. He said to them as said one of those men who were sent to proclaim liberty to the world God and liberty: "Gold and silver, all that you may need I have given you. I give you myself, all that I am, all that I have. In this mess, I offer you what saves, what makes you happy, what gives you hope and Charity."

From the first day of his life in Canada he belonged to these poor savages, without any reserve. All could count on him and he knew how to console their souls.

With more than he possessed a charitable heart full of the most tender affection, most faithful love for these poor abandoned people?

Who more than he had a hand for charity? Who more than he raised up, which saves; actions which multiplied themselves, steps which multiplied themselves, actions which multiplied themselves, steps which multiplied themselves? Night and day, a life spent drop by drop.

Father Hugonnard knew that God loved him, that he had in his hands the salvation of souls. He devoted himself to the salvation of souls, and he found happiness in sacrifice.

But with this suffering there would be joys which would pay a hundred fold for the pains which he bore.

Doubtless he would meet with crosses, but these crosses, as St. Augustine says, are only flowers in the garden, recalling those of the bird. It is true to say that sometimes it seems that it seems sometimes that they are a heavy weight that they carry rather than a weight, that they carry rather than a weight.

Doubtless he would lead a life of asceticism but he would find satisfaction for Jesus, for His Beloved. And not to be satisfied, not even for a moment, by our dear deceased, one must never cease to do good, to give, to take pleasure to others; one must never cease to pray for others; one must never cease to believe in others; one must never cease to help others; one must never cease to have faith in others; one must never cease to love others; one must never cease to have confidence in others; one must never cease to have trust in others.

No one could be more tender, warmer and deeper than he was in saving them, even when it was necessary to sacrifice himself.

He who does not understand this, does not understand Jesus Christ in the Old Testament, nor Jesus Christ in the New Testament of His wondrous, His wonderful, His wondrous works. He who does not understand this, does not understand Jesus Christ in the Old Testament, nor Jesus Christ in the New Testament of His wondrous, His wonderful, His wondrous works.

For this good Father, there was nothing that was more purely concerned; they were all worthy of sacrifice. He died a martyr. His perfect model has made the dew fall, the sun shine, the birds sing, the flowers fume, the flower and on the common tree which the eagle also feeds the sparrow.

The savages had a special claim on the affection of the missionary; they were poor, forsaken, abandoned. Good Father Hugonnard, he leaned towards them with tenderness and charity; he looked at them feeling themselves so tenderly.

They rendered happy their father who always sacrificed himself for their respect and sincere affection. Joubert wrote: "Oh happy happiness because it is rare." Let us say: "Oh happy happiness because it is rare."

Oh how this Bishop was manifested in his life, when he spoke of us this beautiful industrial school where the children who were exposed to the greatest sacrifices and sustained with faith.

How happy he appeared among those little children whom he loved as a father, a mother whom he could also love.

Those who witnessed this scene were touched and believed they were standing in the blue sky of Galilee, on the shores near the shady palm trees when the Divine Master伸出了他的手，宣布了这些发自肺腑的话：“让小孩子到我这里来。”

在这所学校里，他最热心于组织儿童的教育活动。在所有事情中，他首先想到的是孩子们的幸福和快乐；他希望把这些孩子变成基督徒，这个意思比我们所说的“应该首先学会爱上帝”更明确。他认为，在这种情况下，他们应该比其他任何东西，更爱上帝。

他所关心的不是他们应该得到什么，而是他们应该成为什么样的人。
The school as it stood on January 3, 1904. The next day it was in ashes. The work of years had crumbled. With it perished some of our precious records of the past, and the Grey Nuns. All the private possession of the great missionaries were also destroyed. Temporary accommodation was provided for the children in the shops and storage buildings and they were all kept together, not allowed to go back to the reserves.

Sympathy and Condolence

Expressions of sympathy and condolence have come to the Archbishop of Regina, to the Bishop, to the staff of the mission schools, in behalf of Father Hugonnard, from among them is chosen one which follows:

To His Grace Archbishop Mathieu,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

My Dear Bishop:
May it please your Grace to accept from me my heartfelt sympathy and condolence upon the passing away, (I do not say death) of one of our sisters, Father Hugonnard.

Those of us who were privileged to know the Reverend Father for the past thirty-three years, and who have appreciated his sterling worth, and can now realize what loss not only to his own flock but to the Church at large.

Our thoughts go back to the troublesome times of the 1885 rebellion, when the life and courage of the pioneer was an example and fearless attitude, he was, by the help of God, able to hold back the tide of savagery, and to direct the attention of the white settlers of the Qu'Appelle district.

Father Hugonnard, Father Hugonnard was one of the pioneers of the west who made life tolerable and even comfortable for others of us. He fed the hungry, nursed the sick, cheered the dying, and performed the last rites for the dead.

Old before his time through hard work and privations; yet in whose heart was always kept burning the hope of better things to come; the godly man who kept alive the consciousness of the ancient and enduring traditions of the race.

We shall see him no more for he has entered into his inheritance; and now we regard this holy life as a model to us as an example for us to emulate.

"And how he is gone, we can say, He helped the world upon its way, If he had failed in his work Mankind did have some little need of him."

What greater honor could he crave?

He did his best, he played the man. His words were straight, his soul was clean. His failings not united or mean. He helped his fellowmen and tried to help them.

Now he is gone we weep. Remember his life is done, And feel the loss we share, Because he is no longer there."

Among the great many who sent expressions of sympathy and condolence were: Archbishop A. A. Simcoe, Toronto; Bishop J. T. McNally, Calgary; Bishop J. J. Briand, Quebec; Lieutenant Governor H. S. Lake; Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa; W. J. Graham, Secretary of State, Ottawa; Mr. Harter Reid, of the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway, Vancouver; the village council of Lebret, the village council of Regina, Commissioner Perry, R.N.W.M., Winnipeg; Hon. J. J. Rouleau, council, Quebec; Hon. A. E. Forget, council, Quebec; Hon. M. W. Atwater, Gordon In- dian reserve, Saskatchewan; Mr. Thomas, Melville; Father Nassena, O.M.I., Prince Albert; Father Regina; A. W. Sherwood Indian Head; The A. McDonald Co., Winnipeg.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
HIS DEATH, THE LAST GREAT ACT OF HIS LIFE

Another missionary of that rare band of pioneers of Christendom in the West, Father Joseph Hugonard, that diminutive figure which has stood out so strikingly among all that man of earnest purpose, having been called by God to open and tread the trail to the summit of the Great Divide, died at Fort Peck, Montana, yet he lives; the monument to his memory is his life and work.

In the years as we came down the trail into the deepening shadows with the failing light of day, and stood before and around us, too late for the last call of the bugle, in that late twilight of life, be ours the joy of saying: "He died today."

For some months indications were not wanting that the venerable missioner was failing in health. The once robust frame was bowed under the great load of care; sickness and disease had taken their toll. Though the end was expected, his spirit was not broken, and he hoped that he might be spared.

But when the last breath left him in bed the man realized that he could not live much longer. There was still some work to do, there was one more thing to accomplish. The young Sioux brave, who wished to prove himself a true Christian man. And then occurred the crowning act of God's plan for the service of the white man, the zealous priest of the West.

In the bitter part of the month of January, the young Sioux came to the little chapel on the banks of the cleansing waters of baptism; he wished to prove himself a true Christian man to Manitou of the white man, that particular Manitou whom Father Hugonard prayed to. The old missionary priest had often called, there was work to be done, which he knew would cost at that price, he must once more show that he could give his life to the very end, must be in answer to God's call. In words, "Pauperes Evangelizantes," Father Hugonard rose from his bed, said his prayers, went to the morning, preached in English and Cree, instructing the last pagan he brought to the feet of his Lord, the One Christ who died for the white and red children of the West. He visited the pere and preached in the little chapel in which he had been surrounded by the Indian children. His life was sealed in prayer, his new love and devotion were there, and the young Sioux brave praying priest shone with a new light, for he had heard the voice of the martyr, he had his reward in sacrifice, and Father Hugonard grew tired so that he could not stand. He took him the young brave and while he knelt by the side of the altar, he wished to give religious instruction for the last time, wished to bring to God, A night of rest was given to Father Hugonard, and next morning he rose to the Christian faith the last pagan he had brought to the feet of his Lord, the act of his life; he had to take to his bed, but he did not murmur. Two weeks later he returned from whence he came, Breton, Canada, where his soul belonged.

But Father Hugonard, he did not murmur, he found no fault, he knew he was going to heaven, and the transition would be easy. When he was attending him he often said, "O, yes, I have to go, my race is run, I had just so much work to do and Jesus will not let me do any more."

His one great desire was to see his Archbishop, and for many a long year he had learned to love the archbishop, and the satisfaction which Archbishop Mathieu could give him was beyond his power to express. He was notified that Father Mathieu was coming to visit him, and he died. One priest had expressed a desire to see him before he died. Father Hugonard received the bread and blood of the Eucharist, and gave himself through his long years of labor, and through his deathbed agony the sacrament of Extreme Unction, thus giving his soul to God. He had ardently prayed for the consolation of the soul, the assurance to his soul that in passing from this life he had been fortified by grace.

There was a agony of about five hours, during which the little Indian children gathered around praying Death had conquered, but in death the conqueror was the victor. In peace of soul, he had gone to his Christ, even though the final day gave mute evidence of victory.

The body was prepared for the shroud, reverent lips prayed for the repose of the soul, and reverent hearts gave thanks for the occasion.

A peculiar coincidence of his death had been noted by Father Hugonard. Father Hugonard ever had a special devotion to the Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin Mary. He died on the Feast of the Immaculate Conception at Lourdes to the little peasant girl who had appeared to him and spoke to the day. At twelve o'clock high noon the bells of the mission church tolled the death knell, Father Hugonard gave his soul back to God, the final act of his life, the length of time of the chaplet, the same length of time that the little girl beheld the apparition at Lourdes.

Dear Sir,

Allow me to ask you if the Lebret Industrial School employees are at liberty to open up businesses in the village here in opposition to the people outside of the above Government institution, I may state we are running a restaurant here also an ice cream & refreshment business. Mr. Chauvel, one of the Industrial School teachers has opened up business in the village. Handling groceries, ice cream & refreshments.

Now we find this an injustice as he is steadily employed at the school; he has also cut prices in refreshments, which is unfair, if government employees want to compete with outsiders let them come out from under the wing of a Government School and take the same stand as the outsider, they cannot pay attention to their work and be mixed up with business outside, we don't care what they do providing they don't take away part of our living. I had a talk with Rev. Father Auger about the above trouble, he thought it an injustice and was going to have the matter fixed up, he said he would not stand for any such sort of business, unfortunately he took sick and never was able to accomplish what he considered an injustice, we are only trying to protect the ice cream and refreshment business. You can see where Mr. Chauvel can have a certain amount of influence with the Indians & their children being a teacher certainly is a drawing card.

Dear Father LeCoq -

I have a communication from a citizen of LeBret, in which I am informed that Mr. Clouvel, one of the teachers in the industrial school under your charge, has opened an establishment in the village where he conducts a grocery and refreshment business in opposition to others engaged in this line.

In the past complaints had been made in this respect regarding employees of the Qu'Appelle industrial school and the matter was taken up with your predecessor, the late Father Huguenard, and assurance given that there should be no cause for criticism in future. Dear Father Lecocq,

I was surprised to learn from your letter of April 28th, that employees of the school had been engaging in business pursuits. In the first place I do not see how it is possible for these men to look after their school duties properly if they have other concerns, and I will count upon you to put a stop to it. I am given to understand that Indians who have children in residence at the Qu'Appelle Industrial school are accustomed to go to the school and expect to be given free lodgings and food. Ottawa, May 19, 1917.

Sir,

I wish to call your attention to the following matters in connection with the management of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School:

1st - The extensive farming operations carried on at this school have entailed too much work for the pupils, which has caused dissatisfaction among the parents, who complain that the children are overworked and their studies neglected.

While the Department is aware that there is considerable work on the farm which can be attended to by some of the older boys, it does not wish boys under fourteen years of age to take part in the farming work, as they should be in the class-room all the time. In regard to boys over fourteen, the half day system should apply to them, but only when their services are actually required. The farming operations in connection with this school should be a paying proposition and the school should pay for the necessary labour out of the profits derived from the farm.

2nd - The same also applies to the stock raising carried on at the school. The Department is not in favour of more cattle being kept than are actually required for school purposes, as in the past this industry has taken up much of the pupils' time at the expense of their education.

Rev. E. Lecocq,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Industrial School,
Lobet, Sask.
3rd - A return of all the live stock should be sent to the Department through the office of Mr. Inspector Graham at least once a quarter, so that it will be known what stock belongs to the Government and what to the Roman Catholic Mission which adjoins the school and whose trading operations should be kept separate and distinct from the Government stock.

4th - It is the wish of the Department that the teachers employed at this school should be fully qualified to teach English, so that the pupils may have an opportunity of obtaining a thorough English education and learn to speak this language fluently.

5th - As you have already been informed, the Department wishes the practice of feeding visiting Indians to cease and the Agents of the reserves from which pupils are recruited for your school have been informed that this practice is against the wish of the Department and a great drain on the resources of the school and that Indian parents cannot go to the school without a permit and that they must provide their own food and lodging during their visit, which must not last longer than one, or at most two days.

6th - I beg to notify you that in future no Government property of any kind must be sold without permission from the Department, Mr. Inspector Graham.

7th - The practice of allowing children to go home, except during the regular vacation, must be stopped, unless valid reasons are given which meet with the approval of the Department.

The Department trusts that you will see that these suggestions are carried out.

Your obedient servant,

J. B. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated the 14th instant with reference to the visits of Indians to the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. I have already had the opportunity of telling some of the parents and will tell the others when first I see them.

I do not think that my Indians have imposed on that school very much as their visits are not very frequent owing to the distance they have to travel and they almost invariably get a pass when they go to visit their children.

The openhanded hospitality extended to the Indians in the past at the Qu'Appelle Industrial school has been one of its great attractions for them and they have come to look on it as a matter of course. They no longer make a convenience of the Boarding schools here in this respect as we stopped the practice some years ago.

July 23rd, 1917.

Dear Father LeGocq -

I have just received Mr. Inspector Graham's report on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

In connection with the management of the school Mr. Graham draws attention to the shortcomings of the Assistant Principal, the Rev. Father Kalmes. It has been very difficult to recruit for this school lately, due to its unpopularity with the Indians. Father Kalmes is reported to be a man with a violent and uncontrollable temper. The parents complain that he abuses the children, and in face of the complaints as to the treatment our officers find it impossible to ask Indians to send their children to the institution.

In the interests of the school, therefore, I think that Father Kalmes should be removed to some other field of labour, and I would ask you to see that the necessary steps are taken to carry out this arrangement.

Yours very truly,

Rev. G. LeGocq, O.M.I.,
Principal, Qu'Appelle Industrial School,
LeBret, Sask.

Deputy Superintendent General.
REPORT OF INSPECTOR GRAHAM ON THE QU'APPELLE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.

II. While on the subject of classrooms I would call the attention of the Department to the poor attendance of some of the senior boys during the year, also to the number of days taught in the classroom. It appears to me that we should expect the classrooms to be open at least two hundred teaching days in the twelve months, instead of which, we are falling far short of that number.

I found the junior girls' classroom crowded, there being no less than fifty small children in a room that should not contain more than twenty-five at the most. The other two rooms were not so crowded.

The only remedy for this is to divide the children into a morning and afternoon class. Even if the classroom were large enough to accommodate fifty children, it seems to me that the class should be divided, as the children are mere infants and a full day in the classroom is too much. I would particularly recommend that you insist on this class being divided.

Date of report—July 10th, 1917.
REPORT OF INSPECTOR GRAHAM ON THE QU'APPELLE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.

In the line of sewing the girls receive good training. They are also taught cooking and housework, but I regret to inform you that they are not being taught to milk a branch of the training which is so essential for girls going back to the reserve, to be farmers' wives. You will perhaps be interested to know why this branch of the work is being neglected but to my mind there is no reason for it and I hope that the Department will insist that attention be given to this part of the girl's education. A number of years ago, I drew your attention to the fact that this work was being neglected. Instructions were received from you that it was to be taken up and a fresh start was made. However it did not last long and I hope you will make your further instructions emphatic, also have the Principal mention in his monthly reports what is being done in this direction.

In regard to the Boys Inspector Graham considers that they are not being given proper instructions in agriculture. For some time past farming has been carried out on a large scale and the boys have been worked very hard. This defect has now been remedied by employing outsiders to do the farming and neglecting any agricultural teaching for the boys almost completely.

The Inspector considers that half of the present land properly farmed by the boys under competent direction would give these boys a great deal better training for their future life.

Date of Report: July 10th, 1917.
Ottawa, July 31, 1927.

Rev. Sir,-

I beg to advise you that Mr. Inspector Graham, in a recent report on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, states as follows,-

"I found the junior girls' classroom crowded, there being no less than fifty small children in a room that should not contain more than twenty-five at the most. The other two rooms were not so crowded.

"The only remedy for this is to divide the children into a morning and afternoon class. Even if the classroom were large enough to accommodate fifty children, it seems to me that the class should be divided, as the children are mere infants and a full day in the classroom is too much. I would particularly recommend that you insist on this class being divided."

The Department considers that it would be well to give Mr. Graham's suggestion to divide the class referred to a trial.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. E. LeGros, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Industrial School,
Lebret, Sask.

Sir,

As to the first complaint I must say: That the extensive farming operations carried on at this school have not entailed too much work for the pupils.

Last year we had four horsemen working at our farm and sometimes not a single boy until the month of August when some of the boys helped stocking. When we used the boys at the ploughing, seeding or harrowing it was only by hires, changing them every week and only one, two or three at a time.

If the Department believes all what the Indians write, we can leave the boys remain idle. We can hire men very easily to do the work and the boys will do all the work of the old Indians.

Any time I heard visitors coming to the School making the following remarks: "What are all these big boys doing in the yard? Playing football when during the war all school children in white settlements are working, helping to put in the crop. The answer was easy to give.

2. The same also applies to the stock-raising, as in the past this industry has taken up much of the pupils' time at the expense of their education. I must say this.

For the last four years never any boy of this school puts his feet in the stable during winter or summer the time they should be in the class-room.
We have over thirty-five horses and over one hundred head of cattle to look after. Here is how we look after the cattle: In the morning the vice-Principal himself, right after breakfast goes to the stable with about seventy boys. About twenty boys the oldest ones, feed, comb and water the horses. Two other boys milk the cows, eight others clean them and about twelve feed them. About six others feed the hogs. All this work can be done in half an hour.

I have a lot of other boys for any emergency. At four o'clock we repeat the same thing after class. Where is the overwork of the boys?

All the rest of the time they are free and can play.

As for raising cattle the school has to buy every year at least thirty heads.

A few years ago the School had rented from the Oblate Fathers a piece of land but it has all been for the interest of the School since not a cent was given to the Oblates.

3. In the beginning, very likely Rev. Father Hugonard obliged to tend to the interests of the Mission together with those of the School necessarily was compelled to put everything in common but for many years this community of goods was put to an end. So be assured that what we are in possession of belongs to the School only, and that those who wrongfully give you false informations are positive of the contrary.

To lessen the School in the eyes of the Department outrageous lies were told.

Mr. Chouval left and the teacher who will replace him has a First class certificate from Nova Scotia and a Second from Regina. He is a young man, single, English speaking by the name of Mr. McLenan. I am quite aware that some will have something to criticise over but very soon I intend to write to you concerning this matter.

Who has ever heard of a man that gives you a friendly advice and behind your back does his utmost to backbite you and tries to draw away the Indians from your School?
By this article I sincerely hope that you do not intend to tie up the land. I do not wish to sell an inch of land belonging to the School but when I shall need cattle for table-use or farm-implements I hope that I shall not be forced to go to Ottawa to obtain permission to buy them.

I have nothing to say concerning the 7th article and will have it observed to the best I can, notwithstanding that no one will say to me, "Send this gas or I'll blow you up." In order to be friendly...

Yours very truly,

E. [Signature]

Ottawa, August 6, 1917.

Rev. Sir,

The attention of the Department has again been called to the fact that none of the girls in your school are being taught to milk and, as it is necessary for them to know how to do this work when they return to the reserve and have homes of their own to look after, the Department would like you to arrange to have a certain number of the older girls given instruction in this branch. It will not be necessary for them to do all the milking.

Reference has also been made to the lack of proper instruction in agriculture to the boy pupils. The Department considers it essential that the older boys should be given practical lessons in agriculture under a competent instructor and that a certain portion of the land under cultivation should be set apart for this purpose. Hitherto these boys, while doing hard manual labour, have not been receiving the lessons in agriculture that would fit them to successfully farm their own land when they leave the school.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. E. Legoo, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Industrial School,
Lebret, Sask.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter above quoted, dealing with only some of the matters referred to in my report on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. I am sorry that you did not see fit to give definite instructions regarding the dividing of the over-crowded class-room of the small girls. Knowing how your instructions in almost all matters have been ignored by the authorities at the School, I asked that emphatic instructions be given on this point. I see you have seen fit to merely write—"it would be well to give my suggestion a trial." It remains to be seen if your request is carried out. In the meantime, I wish to repeat that it is entirely wrong to tolerate existing conditions. I can get outside medical authority to endorse all I have said on the subject and feel it is too important a matter to let pass without further comment.

I have pointed out to you that Dr. Hall is not Surgeon and as a result there appears to be neglect. If you would authorize Dr. Gorrell of Regina to make a report on the pupils, you would have some information that would be of real value to the Department.

With regard to the large girls doing the milking,

I regret

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I regret that your instructions were not emphatic. I fear merely saying that you would like to arrange to have a certain number of girls given instruction in this branch will not suffice. Apparently nothing was said about your previous instructions on this important point.

You are aware that instructions have recently been given to the Principal not to overwork the boys on the farm; also to give more attention to the classroom. These instructions were the outcome of complaints from the parents. I hope that the Principal will not interpret your remarks as cancelling recent instructions on the matter.

I note that nothing at all has been said regarding the hiring of outside labor and the carrying on of farming operations on a large scale—to the extent of renting land from outsiders. I may have been wrong in criticizing these conditions; if so, will you be good enough to advise me as it is no pleasure for me to do so.

I may also add that the new Principal is very seldom at home. At present he is away and has been for three weeks and no one appears to be in authority, or to know where he is. The mail is left unopened, by his order, and generally speaking, things are going from bad to worse.

I undertook to build the laundry at this School in order to save money. I have had little or no assistance from the School, except from a lay brother and I am sorry I undertook the work.

There is little use in trying to improve conditions here unless the Department follow up matters; it only makes trouble for me referring to these things and not having them acted upon. In fact I think it unwise to do so, under existing conditions.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Letter No 8536.

Sir;-

I beg to report upon a visit I made to Nut Lake Reserve in the Touchwood Agency for the purpose of recruiting.

I found that the Indians are very much opposed to sending their children to any school, there is a Day School six miles distant from their camping grounds and too far for the children to attend even if they were willing to send them.

From personal observation I could see that the children of these Indians are in special need of school training in order to develop civilization and promote morality.

I was unable to get any children but I did get a list of Indians who have children of school age from the Overseer Mr P. Hamilton, who has tried many times to have these Indians send their children to school but without success. I am enclosing a list of the Indians and number of children.

Nearly all of these Indians are Pagan, I would ask the Department to give their assistance towards having the 34 children sent to this school.

I have informed Mr Inspector Graham of the result of my visit to Nut Lake.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa - Ont.

Dear Sir,

I take the liberty of writing to ask you for a leave of absence for a couple months. At this period of the year, which is one of the less busy times, Father Kalmus could manage the work alone. I have a very sore eye and I would go to California to a specialist for the eyes who treated me last year and cured one. And assured that with fifteen days more at that time he would cure the other. But I was called back to Manitoba and besides entertained hopes that that eye would continue to improve and get better & left California. But since my eye has been worse gradually and I have met no doctors to do me any good. This is the reason why I have thoughts of going again to that doctor before it is too late.

Kindly let me hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Respectfully Yours,

E. Secog

Ottawa, June 26, 1918.

Rev. Sir,

As you have lately been appointed Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School there are certain matters to which I wish to call your attention in regard to the management of the institution:

1st. The Department is of the opinion that the extensive farming operations carried on there entail too much work on the pupils, which causes dissatisfaction among the parents, who complain that the children are over-worked and their studies neglected.

While it is admitted that there is considerable work on the farm which can and should be attended to by some of the older boys, it is not the wish of the Department that boys under fourteen years of age should be required to do farm work, as they should be in the class-room continuously during school hours. With regard to boys over fourteen, the half day system should apply to them, but only when their services are actually required. The farming operations in connection with the school should be a paying proposition and any necessary labour required should be paid for out of the profits derived from the farm.

2nd. The same rule should apply to the stock raising carried on at the school.

The Department is not in favour of more cattle being kept than are absolutely required for school purposes.

Rev. A. J. A. Dugas,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Industrial School,
Lebret, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 660-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
In the past this industry has taken up much of the pupils' time at the expense of their education.

3rd. A return of all the live stock should be sent to the Department through the office of Mr. Commissioner Graham at least once a quarter, so that it will be known what stock belongs to the Government and what to the Roman Catholic Mission, which adjoins the school and whose trading operations should be kept separate and distinct from the Government stock.

4th. The Department must insist upon the employment of teachers who are thoroughly qualified to give instruction in English, so that the pupils may have an opportunity of obtaining a thorough English education and learn to speak the language fluently.

5th. A strict account should be kept in the books of all buying and selling done by the school and your accountant should keep regular office hours, so that access can be had to the books when required and information given when called for.

6th. The Department would like to be furnished with a complete list of the staff, with the duties assigned to each member and the number of hours required for their performance.

The Department will expect you to see that the foregoing directions are strictly carried out.

Your obedient servant,

Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Honourable Sir,

I beg to state that the Superiors of the Oblate Fathers think that it has become necessary to change the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. Reverend Father Lecoq having of late failed in health very rapidly. Recently, he has been the victim of an attack of pneumonia and pleurisy which left him very weak.

We think Reverend Father Dugas would run successfully this very important institution, and beg the Department to approve of same as Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

I beg also to inform the Department that Reverend Father Pafard O.M.I. has been chosen as Principal of the Cowesses Boarding School.

As for our Muscovequan's Boarding School, as soon as we are able to nominate a successor to Reverend Father Dugas, we will advise the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Provincial of the Oblate Fathers.

Indian Industrial School
At
Lebret - Sask.
July 31st, 1918.

Letter No 8619,

Sir:

With reference to your Letter No 116575/1 of June 26th last I beg to state that I have under careful observation the matters named therein. It is impossible for me at this early date of my installation as principal to give a full and detailed report of the management but it is my intention to arrange regulations that may fully correspond with the wishes of the Department.

1st. The extensive farming operations carried on for the past two years was thought to be a good scheme owing to the food conditions caused by the war and as the Department was in favor of allowing the pupils to assist at outside farming it was considered reasonable to apply this privilege at the school, hence the extensive farming. The farming operations for next season will be considerably curtailed in so far as school lands only will be cultivated.

There is much work on the farm which must be attended to and I intend to see that only the older boys will be employed by the half day system and when absolutely necessary; I am of the opinion however that some boys under 14 years could receive valuable training in lighter farming and gardening but in short periods, this would be a relaxation from continuous class work and would assist in maintaining the health of the pupils. Any boys who may work on the farm will receive practical instruction as the farmer now in charge has had years of actual training and takes an interest in imparting the necessary information for successful work.
2nd. No more cattle than are required for school purposes will be kept. The number at the present time does not exceed 100 head and this number is not sufficient for the use of the school as it takes about 45 head per year to supply beef for the pupils, as well as a number of hogs, besides from 15 to 18 milk cows are needed for the milk supply. Each summer we are obliged to purchase a few head locally for fresh beef but in the Fall when the cold weather sets in a large number are slaughtered giving a supply of beef till the following June thus reducing the number to be cared for during winter. The cattle industry will not in any way conflict with the education of the pupils except in so far as the feeding of stock in winter time and the milking which is done alternately by the boys and girls and that outside of class hours.

3rd. A return of all live stock will be sent to Mr Commissioner Graham once a quarter commencing September quarter next. We would request that a number of live stock forms be sent here so that we may be able to carry out the instructions of the Department. There is no mix-up nor confusion in live stock trading operations between the school and the Roman Catholic Mission nor can there be any as the stocks are completely separate and distinct the Mission having their own lands upon which they have raised stock for many years previous to the establishment of the school. A wrong impression may have prevailed as the School and the Mission are under the management of members of the same Religious Order but are completely independent of each other the administration being entirely different.

4th. The Management clearly understands the necessity of giving a thorough instruction in the English language and at the present time we think that the teachers now employed are well qualified. When classes resume work after vacation it is my
intention to frequently visit or inspect the class-room work and if found deficient changes will be made.

The present employees with whom the pupils come in contact can speak the English language fluently but although difficult at times to engage extra labor who are fluent we will do our utmost to secure those who come nearest the standard if it be only for a short time.

5th. I understand that a custom had been in operation whereby buying and selling outside of the office had been done but remittances made direct to the principal which eventually were entered in the books. This custom I do not approve of and my orders are now that all financial transactions be put through the office direct so that there may be no chance of an oversight or error and regular office hours will be named to insure prompt entry of business transactions and for access or information which may be required.

6th. Complete list of staff with assigned duties is herewith attached.

Your obedient servant

Principal

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, August 8, 1918.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I am in receipt of your telegram and letter, with reference to Father Dugas' visit; he came particularly to endeavour to secure a successor to Father Kalmea; he has a promising man in view, and I trust that he will be able to secure him. He understands, of course, that Father Kalmea cannot remain at the school, and I am certain that he is personally desirous of making the change. From what he says, I gather that he wishes to co-operate with you, and there is certainly no antagonism whatever to our instructions; there are one or two points which he brought up, about which I told him that he must consult you. He is very anxious to get some exchange of land, so that the school farm can be nearer the buildings; I am aware that this was discussed in 1916, and you wrote a letter then, supporting Father Hugonard's recommendation, but, unfortunately, we had no funds at that time; I told

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Father Dugas to converse with you on this matter.

I am sending you herewith a copy of a letter which he sent in reply to our instructions of the 26th of June, which, you will remember, was written when you were here.

Father Dugas says that some repairs are necessary; I asked him to make an estimate and submit it to you in the usual way.

He did not ask for any change in the instructions given him, except in one particular, that is the employment of boys under fourteen, and he had some suggestions to offer about a different system of alternating classroom work with outside work, but I told him he would have to consult you and have your support.

He assured me that all the teachers and instructors employed could speak English well, and that he would support us in this matter.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Duncan C. Scott.

Sir:

I feel satisfied that Rev Father Lalonde will more than meet the wishes of the Department as he is a graduate of the University and had fifteen years of training as a professor and disciplinarian.

Ottawa, September 5, 1918.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that the Department is in receipt of a letter from the Rev. Father Dugas, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, Lebret, Sask., regarding certain equipment which was furnished for the use of the cadet corps in the school in September, 1912.

A demand has been made on the Principal for the return of the articles by Lt.-Col. E.A.G. Hosmer, O.I.C. of C.M.D. No. 12, and also by Major J. Graham, General Staff Officer, Military District No. 12.

Father Dugas states that, having had possession of the articles for so many years, he feels that he should be allowed to keep them, especially the hats and belts, which are used by the boy scouts of the school. If they have to return the hats and belts it would interfere with the scout movement, which is now thoroughly established, as the school would be unable to purchase others, owing to the shortage of funds occasioned by the increased cost of maintaining the school during the war.

The Department has, therefore, to request that you will, if possible, allow the school to retain the hats and belts, as it would be a pity to interfere with the scout movement there, which has a very beneficial effect on the physique of the boys.

I am enclosing you a copy of the list of the equipment which was furnished this school in 1912.

Sirs—Gen'l. Sir E. Fiset, K.B., O.M.G., Your obedient servant,
Deputy Minister of Militia and Defence.

Sir:

I beg to submit for your consideration a report on our financial standing.

Since taking over the management of this school in June last I have made a careful study of the whole situation and have concluded that it is almost impossible to successfully carry on the work here with the present grant.

The excessive cost of the most necessary articles is so great that with the most careful supervision and limited buying I am unable to keep down the debt.

It is needless for me to say (as you are aware of the fact) that such staple articles as flour, beef, sugar, tea, clothing, leather and fuel are at an excessive price and still advancing but these goods must be purchased, regardless of cost, in order to feed and clothe our pupils.

If we had the allotted number of pupils the situation might be very slightly relieved but the maintenance of an institution with 20 or 25 short makes very little difference in the expense, however we are making every effort to obtain the authorized number.

As we are obliged to curtail our farming operations for the future I can foresee that a source of revenue will be denied us and this loss must be met in some other way and I know of none except a raise in the grant.

Owing to the high cost of living, salaries have advanced but in this respect we have a capable staff for an exceptionally fair wage.
Our deficit on the 31st of October was $9706.69 and this with only the necessaries and we cannot see how we can reduce this without the aid of the Department.

We thought that if the Department would increase the grant by $15.00 per capita we would soon be on a good financial basis and would be in a better position to insure the success of the school.

We have endeavoured to give you a candid opinion of our financial condition and would ask you to seriously consider the request for an increase of $15.00 per capita over our present grant.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Principal

Dear Sir,

Complying with the request expressed in your letter File No. 116,575-1, of the 6th inst., I went to meet Commissioner Graham on the 20th, in Regina.

Mr. Graham had seen the day before, on Nov. 29th, for the first time the new Principal of Lebret, Reverend Father Leonard.

Should Reverend Father Leonard not give satisfaction, we would have then grounds to proceed to his removal; but in fact, he has a good record. He has organized our Sandy Bay School, of which he was the first Principal, and he has satisfactorily conducted our Pine Creek School, for some years; this last School ranks in importance immediately after our Lebret School.

Hoping this will prove satisfactory to all,

Sir:

When making application for the usual Railway Passes for the current year, I was informed that no Pass would be granted for this year at least.

For a number of years it has been the custom to issue a Pass to the Principal of this school for recruiting purposes and the withdrawal of this privilege will be quite a serious matter financially as it is absolutely necessary that the Principal must do a certain amount of travelling by railway to the different points where Indians are located.

Being an official of the Department, it occurred to me that any legitimate expenses incurred by the school for recruiting might be borne by the Department as in the case of other outside officials of the Department.

It is extremely difficult, in this period of excessive prices, to find sufficient means to procure the necessaries for the school and with the unexpected additional liability of railway fare will make our position more difficult to manage.

May we expect that the Department will pay all railway fares in connection with recruiting for this school?

Your obedient servant

Rev. and dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 12th ultimo in which you advise the Department that the privilege of a pass on the railways has been withdrawn from you, and ask that legitimate travelling expenses incurred when recruiting Indian children, should be borne by the Department.

In reply I have to say that it is not the practice of the Department to pay travelling expenses for principals of any schools when engaged in recruiting. I presume, however, that you are aware that the Railway Act 1919, which greatly curtailed the issue of passes and in consequence of which presumably you did not receive yours, provides that those engaged in religious work as you are may be granted fares at half rates. I would, therefore, suggest that you apply to the management of the railway or railways on which you usually travel and ask that this reduction be granted to you, referring to Section 345, sub-section "A" of the Railway Act, 1919.

Letter No 8883.

Sir:

After carefully investigating the financial condition of the Qu'Appelle School I have decided to place before you its present standing, and the immediate cause for same, and would ask that favorable consideration be given to this particular case.

As you are aware during the past few years the absolute necessaries for the maintenance of the school has advanced enormously in price and out of all proportion to the increase of grant. Although an extra grant of $10.00 for the current year was allowed, and was of great assistance, yet it was far from sufficient to meet the ever increasing cost of goods and now in the final month of the fiscal year I find our indebtedness to be approximately $1000.00.

The following articles which are the essentials for the upkeep and healthful sustenance of the pupils are excessive in price, viz; Flour, Beef, Tea, Sugar, Syrup, Clothing, Leather, Coal etc. The purchase of a car of flour and several cars of coal late last Fall is responsible, more or less, for the large deficit but these articles had to be secured. Of course no flour nor coal will be again bought for some months but the greater part of these accounts are outstanding and must be paid sooner or later.

Since I took over the management of the school last Fall I have endeavoured to carry on the work with the minimum expense consistent with the progress and welfare of the pupils and to continue the work successfully, in these particularly hard times, I would respectfully ask the aid of the Department.

To have a fair start at the beginning of the coming fiscal year, I would propose that the Department might assume a portion of the present deficit by using the balance of the
of the total grant voted (of the present year) towards the reduction of the deficit.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA Ottawa, March 16, 1920

MEMORANDUM.

Rev. G. Leonard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, draws attention to the present financial position of the school. He states that their indebtedness at the end of the present fiscal year will be approximately $10,000.00. He states that owing to the continued increase in the cost of supplies during the past few years that the per capita grant, although increased by $10.00 per capita for the current year, was not sufficient to meet the expenditure. He requests that the Department comes to his aid and that the balance of the per capita grant, being the difference in the amount earned and the amount of the grant voted, be paid him.

The per capita grant is provided for 225 pupils at $150.00 per capita and amounts to a total of $33,750.00. For the present fiscal year there has already been paid from this amount as follows:

| Month | Year | Amount |
|-------|------|--------|
| June  | 1919 | $6,875.62 |
| Sept. | 1919 | $7,220.87 |
| Dec.  | 1919 | $6,413.25 |
| March | 1920 | $5,500.00 |

Supplies furnished by Militia Dept. and charged to per capita grant ... $335.80

$26,345.54

The total amount of the earnings due for the current quarter can only be estimated when the quarterly returns of attendance are received and will probably be about $6,500.00. This will leave a balance of approximately $6,740.00 not earned by the school from the amount of appropriation provided.

During
During the fiscal year 1909-10 a special grant on account of the deficit was paid, being the difference between the per capita earnings and the amount voted for that year to the total of $1,578.06. Vouchers were submitted for expenditure which could properly be paid by the Department after an examination of the books by Commissioner Graham and were certified by him.

No assistance has been given in the payment of deficits to any of the residential schools since April 1912, the date on which the agreement for the maintenance and management of the schools was entered into with the various church authorities. In the case of the Industrial schools no agreements were signed, except in the case of the schools of that class in the Province of Ontario.

The present enrolment at Qu'Appelle is 201 pupils with an average attendance of 171. The enrolment, I might say, has been gradually decreased during the present fiscal year.

I shall be pleased to receive your instructions as to what action is to be taken regarding the request of the principal of the Qu'Appelle School to pay the school the balance between the amount of the grant earned and the amount provided.
Ottawa, March 17, 1920

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, drawing attention to the present financial position of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School and requesting that the Department allow you the balance of the per capita grant, being the difference between the amount earned and the amount voted for the present fiscal year to help you meet your indebtedness.

In reply I beg to say that it is very much regretted that funds are not available for the payment of any deficits incurred by the school.

It is noted that the enrolment and average attendance has been decreasing each quarter at the Qu'Appelle school during the past year and a strong effort should be made to recruit a sufficient number of new pupils to bring the enrolment up to the number of grant earning pupils provided for.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rev. C. Leonard,

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith the returns of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School for the quarter ended March 31st, 1920.

I asked the Principal for explanations as to why Wm. J. Bellegerde, Justine Desnomie and Jos Kauizance were shown as in residence 91 days when none of them attended class-room at all. He replied as follows:

"Wm. Bellegerde was allowed home on your authority April 10th, 1919 and was kept a longer period than granted, he was here at intervals since then but finally kept by his father who claims he has your authority. As it seemed impossible to get this boy back and being nearly of age to be discharged, I decided to write his name off the returns this quarter.

The case of Justine Desnomie is a similar one. The parents refusing to return the girl, claiming you gave them authority to keep her at home."

I do not think the grant should be paid in these two cases. Surely the Principal ought to know better than to take an Indian's word regarding such matters or to suppose that I would give such authority or discharge pupils without advising him. I might point out here that I am convinced he would not have experienced so much difficulty in getting pupils to return to school, if the parents had felt satisfied that their children were really receiving an education. For years the

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
parents have been complaining that there was too much work and not enough class-room education being carried on at this school. The quarterly returns have borne out this contention and I have repeatedly called the Department's attention to this fact.

Regarding Joe Kiwizance the Principal writes as follows:

"Joe Kiwizance, who is from Nut Lake, was admitted to the school in his 17th year for the purpose of later being an influence towards recruiting at Nut Lake. Being a big boy and here for a short time only and did not care to mingle with the small boys in class was given outside work. Having incurred great expense to recruit this boy for such a short period and having again to pay his fare home we thought ourselves justified to claim for this quarter."

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Commissioner.

Sir:

For the past few months I have been approached by some of our employees for an increase of salary which we believe they are justified in asking for but owing to the high cost of everything which we are obliged to procure we cannot possibly give relief.

Unless an increase can be given we fear we may lose the excellent service which these employees have rendered in the past and besides will interfere considerably in the management of the school.

If by some way or means an increase of $10.00 per month could be obtained for about six faithful employees, an arrangement could be made to retain these reliable men until such time as conditions become normal. The amount of increase would mean only $720.00 per year and if provided by the Department would, in our opinion, be quite a small amount but a very large amount if the school had to stand the increase owing to the large present deficit we are now struggling with.

The present salaries of the interested employees range from $40.00 to $75.00 per month, and some are married men with families, which means that their request for an increase is reasonable.

Could we ask the co-operation of the Department in this matter to the extent of $60.00 per month?

Your obedient servant

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs

Principal

Ottawa - Ont.
Ottawa, April 27, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, in which you request that the Department pay an amount of $60.00 per month to enable you to increase the salaries of six of the staff of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School to the extent of $10.00 per month each.

In reply I beg to say that the Department does not contribute towards the payment of the salaries of the staff at any of the residential schools conducted under the auspices of the various religious denominations and it cannot make any exception in your case. No funds are appropriated for the purpose, and it will, therefore, be impossible to comply with your request.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to enclose herewith a quarterly return of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School for the quarter ended September 30th, 1920.

The attendance in the class-room is still far from what it should be. From the possible number of school days the girls missed 642, without any reason being inserted in the column for such remarks. The boys missed 594 days unexplained, besides a great number for which reasons are stated. The maximum number of class-room days shown on the boys' return is 40, whereas the girls' return shows 43. The boys' class-room should have been open the same number of days as the girls!

The poor attendance in the class-room has been the subject of repeated letters to the Principal of this school, and very little improvement has resulted. It would appear that something more drastic will be needed, if these Indian children are to receive an education such as we should expect them to get at an institution of this kind.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

October 25th, 1920.

Rev. and dear Sir,

There has been considerable criticism of late years regarding the character of the class-room work conducted at the Qu'Appelle Industrial school. I have just received a report from Mr. Commissioner Graham forwarding a return of attendance for the quarter ended September 30th., which shows that during that period the girls missed 642 days and the boys 494 days, for which there was no explanation besides a great number of days for which reasons were given. This is very poor attendance in the class-room and Mr. Graham reports that although the matter has been repeatedly brought to the attention of the principal, very little improvement has resulted.

I regret the necessity of having to bring this matter to your attention, but there must be a decided improvement in this feature of the work of the institution. I shall be obliged if you will at once communicate with the principal with a view to impressing upon him the importance of the matter, and avoid the necessity of more drastic action on the part of the Department.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Lebret, Sask.,
July 1st, 1921.

Sir,

I beg to report on the inspection of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School books as follows -

I checked all accounts in the Journal, Cash Book and Ledger, checking from one book to the other. I checked all invoices from the invoice book into the various accounts into which they were posted. I also examined all cheques issued, comparing them with the stubs, and noting any difference between stub and cheque; these traced to bank adjustments, when they were again taken off the Cash Book. I also compared all deposits with the Bank Book, tracing differences between deposit slips and bank book with any commissions and interests charged on cheques and notes by the bank. These charges were traced to bank adjustments and I find they have also been taken on in the Cash Book.

With the exception of one or two discrepancies shown in attached notes, I found all accounts properly kept. All debits and credits carefully and neatly entered into the various accounts.

Upon the management of the school in general, I cannot but report favorably, with perhaps a little too much laxity in discipline in the dining room.

Your obedient servant,

"W. R. Taylor"

Indian Agent.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Regina, Sask.

Sir:

Sir,

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 14th instant, No.100-14, with reference to the advisability of sending a circular to all principals of Indian residential schools concerning the matter of absenting themselves from their duties without the consent of the Department.

In reply I regret to say that the Department is not prepared to meet your wishes with regard to the issuing of instructions to principals of residential schools. They are not members of the Civil Service and are really employees of the denominations. Of course we must hold them to a proper administration of the schools, and if you notice that the management is suffering on account of any prolonged absences, you should report and the matter can be dealt with.

OTTAWA, October 28th, 1921.

Sir,

I have been directed to draw your attention to a matter that arose out of my report for the summer months.

In the case of Sister Brabant, the teacher of the intermediate girls' class room in the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, it has been decided to inform the Reverend Principal that her services are not desirable in the class room. I am convinced that this sister, who is a French half-breed, would make an excellent officer in one of the Departments, but in view of her broken English, and very faulty choice of language and pronunciation, we cannot allow her to direct the academic instruction in an Indian school.

When I was in your office in Regina you drew the matter to my attention, and I am pleased to inform you that the Department agrees upon the necessity of securing better qualified teachers for class room instruction.

Will you take whatever action you believe necessary in connection with this case in the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,

Dear Mr. Scott,

In a letter to the Secretary dated the 14th inst., I drew attention to the action of the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School in suddenly leaving his duties there without the sanction of the Department, and suggested that all principals of Industrial and Boarding Schools should be advised that they must not absent themselves from their duties without leave from the Department, and I am in receipt of a reply from the Secretary's office stating that it is regretted no such instructions can be issued to the Principals of Residential Schools as they are not members of the Civil Service, but are Employees of the denominations. Although this is so, they are responsible to the Department for the good government of the schools of which they are in charge, and I think the Department is entitled to know when they leave the precincts of the school for any length of time. In this case the Reverend Father Leonard briefly informed me.

Ottawa, October 31st, 1921.

Mr Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Pursuant to our recent conversation I am much pleased to ask officially from your Department to head the list of subscriptions for the erection of a Monument to the late Rev. Fr Hugonard O.M.I., Principal of Lebret School.

Rev. Fr Hugonard was personally known to you and to most of the Officials of the Indian Department with whom he has cooperated in the introduction of Education among the Indians of the Western Provinces. The Reverend Father has been a pioneer in this philanthropic work and the Indians always remembering him as their father and benefactor have decided to perpetuate his memory. They have appointed a Committee with Very Rev. Fr J.B. Beys O.M.I., Provincial of the Oblate Missionaries for Manitoba and Southern Saskatchewan, as Chairman.

The Monument which will cost over $3,000 will be erected in front of Lebret Industrial School, on the property of the Department. The subscriptions will be mostly made up of Indian contributions and that is one of the reasons why the Committee in charge has requested me to appeal to you for a substantial subscription in the name of the Department.

Kindly interest the Honorable the Minister of the Interior, Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, in this matter. I leave to your judgment and generosity to suggest the amount that will fitly express the Department's appreciation of Rev. Fr Hugonard's efforts and success in Indian Education and Civilization.

Yours very truly,

Joseph [signature]

Hon. Sir James Lougheed -

Attached is a letter from Rev. Father Guy requesting that the Department should make some contribution towards the erection of a statue to the Rev. Father Hugonard in the grounds of our Indian industrial school at Lebret.

This is a somewhat unusual request but there may be some grounds for the Government considering it favourably. Father Hugonard was a pioneer missionary and educationalist among the Indians. For many years he was principal of the industrial school. This school is visited by a great many people particularly during the summer months, and a statue of the virtual founder of the school in the grounds would add something to the interest of the institution.

If anything were to be done a special vote would have to be taken for next year's estimates, as the Department has no funds for such a purpose. I would ask for your consideration.

Duncan Elliott

Dear Mr. Scott,

As far as Father Leonard is concerned, I think if you knew the gentleman you would say that he is the last man we should have in charge of the largest and most important of our schools. He is not qualified, and has not got the right ideas. I had numerous complaints from the public last year about the manner in which the outside work at the school was carried on, particularly in regard to the garden, which was a disgrace to a public institution, which is supposed to give instruction to Indians. I suppose the Reverend gentleman was annoyed because the Nurse complained about the totally inadequate supply of milk which the children depend upon. The whole the report of the Nurse was favourable to the Institution, but as 90% of the work touched upon by the Nurse occurred under the direction of the Reverend Sisters you can understand that it would be good. No matter how incompetent the Principal of the School might be, the household portion of the work would be up to date. I intend, the first opportunity I get, to discuss with the Reverend Dr. Jeyes the matter of having Father Leonard replaced by a more competent priest, as this school should not continue under the present management.

Yours very truly,

H. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

I have your No. 508-14 of the 14th instant, referring to the failure of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School authorities to remove Sister Brabant, the teacher of the Intermediate Girls' Classroom.

In reply I beg to state that I have been in touch with all residential schools in connection with teaching methods and related subjects, and that the Department has been lately in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Principal, to the effect that the Mother Provincial had promised Rev. Leonard a change at the first opportunity.

I agree with you that this matter has been treated rather lightly, and I enclose, for your information, copy of communication which was addressed to the Rev. Principal upon receipt of the letter which I am now answering.

In view of the fact that there has been an apparent failure to accede to the Department's wishes in this connection, I would be grateful for information from you, upon the occasion of the first visit of one of your officers to Labret. If no change has been made in the course of a few weeks, the Department will get in touch with the proper authorities and see if a successor to Sister Brabant has been appointed at the time of such visit; a report by your representative concerning the English of the new teacher would be appreciated.

I expect that in the near future arrangements will have been completed with the Departments of Education for the three Prairie Provinces, in connection with an inspection of all Indian schools that are readily accessible to the public school inspectors.

Your obedient servant,

Enclos.

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

W. M. Graham Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, No.116575-1 regarding the removal of Sister Brabant from the teaching staff of the Intermediate Girls' Classroom, U'Appelle Industrial School. I may say that I received a letter from the Mother Superior of the Sisterhood some little time ago in which she stated that she hoped to make a change in the near future probably at the end of next Month.

Inspector Christianson returned two days ago from making an inspection at Lebret and he is very dissatisfied with the manner in which the classroom work is being carried on in the boys' department. His opinion is that Mr. Rossington is an absolute failure, lazy and to use his own words, unfit to occupy the position that he now holds. He also informs me that this man has a very poor pronunciation, uses poor English and urges that he be removed at once. I have never had much of an opinion of Mr. Rossington myself, I know that he takes little or no interest in the boys once they leave the classroom and it seems to me that a change here would be beneficial.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We the undersigned Citizens of Lebret, have heard with regret of the action of the Principal of the Industrial School in discharging Mr. G. J. Harrison from that Institution.

When the report was first given out it seemed incredible as the above named gentleman is held in respect by every fair minded Citizen.

It is known that his dismissal was not in any way for non-performance of his duties but for reasons pertaining to the Parish, and as Citizens, strongly object to the Principal's action, as it is altogether out of his jurisdiction.

We feel sure that Mr. Harrison fulfilled his obligations as a trusted employee and member of the School staff with loyalty and honour during the period of years that he has been here, otherwise comments...
would have been heard years ago from the Department.

We do not know Mr. Warren's feelings in this matter (as he is very reticent about it) neither is he aware of the action the undersigned are taking in regards to his notice of dismissal, and feel sure that you as Commissioner, in charge of affairs, under the Indian Department, will, until such time, that good and sufficient reasons, as to why the action taken by the Principal, that would warrant his removal, that pressure be brought to instruct the Principal to recall the notice of dismissal.

We have heard in the past from the above named gentleman, that he served long enough at the School and would like to resign when he decided to sever his connection, but apparently through some unseen influence, that has been brought to bear upon others, that his dismissal would be more in order, and as stated before, not through non-compliance of his duties, but petty jealousies on part of few unsettled minds.

We ask that this petition and communication be treated Confidentially.
