COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

S. REGINA, SASK., 8th March 1922.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I am enclosing, herewith, a report of an inspection which has just been completed by Inspector Christianson on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

You will note that the Inspector found the class room work, so far as the girls' department was concerned, to be in excellent shape, and even comments favourably upon the girls' intermediate class, which is taught by Sister Brabant, whose removal was requested by the Department on account of her poor pronunciation of the English language. The Inspector's report on the boys' class rooms is not very encouraging, and judging from his remarks it would appear to me that the work there could not be worse. The senior class is being taught by a Mr. Rossington, who, apart from any qualifications he may have as a teacher, is not the type of man who should be employed in an Indian school. I would recommend that the Department take steps to have him removed, and that great care be taken in the selection of his successor. This unsatisfactory state of affairs in the boys' class rooms clearly indicates how important it is that our Indian schools should be visited regularly by Provincial School Inspectors, and I trust that action will be taken to have this done as soon as possible.

I am glad to note that a little more attention is now being given to outdoor recreation, and that the girls are more in the open at the present time than was/

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 660-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
was the case in the past.

With reference to that portion of the Inspector's report dealing with the advanced case of tuberculosis, this case was first brought to my attention by the School's Doctor, who stated that the child was too ill to be removed, and that it was not a case for the Sanatorium. He further stated that the patient was well isolated.

Generally speaking the school buildings are in good repair, but, of course, in an Institution of this size painting and repairs are always required to be done. I presume the Department have requisitioned for a sufficient amount in the Estimates to cover these items.

With regard to fire hose, I would strongly recommend that the worn hose be replaced immediately.

In reference to the stables, the condition in which these are is undoubtedly owing to the fact that the Principal of the school is not a competent man. During the past year I have received many complaints from the public in regard to the manner in which this school is being managed, and you will recall that before Father Leonard took charge there I strongly protested against his appointment, as I felt confident that he would not make a success of the school. I also later recommended that he should be relieved of his duties, and you advised me that the matter was under consideration. The gardens at the school last year were a disgrace, and if any Indian had had his garden in the same condition I would have severely censured him. I have from time to time drawn the Principal's attention.
attention to the unsatisfactory condition into which the Institution as a whole is drifting.

With regard to the stock, it is really hard to believe how any man could imagine that cattle could be kept in good condition by feeding them with badly rusted straw. Straw, even of the best quality, is not fit feed for stock unless it is supplemented by hay etc. I have received a report from the Provincial Veterinary Surgeon to the effect that the cattle are only half fed, and that a large percentage of the cows are tubercular. In my opinion the Department should take immediate steps to have the whole herd replaced by a good milking strain, and before the new herd is brought to the school every animal in the old one should be removed. I recall that a few years ago the cow herd at the Battleford Mental Hospital was examined, when a percentage of the animals were found to be tubercular. New cows were purchased to replace those condemned, but after a year, on another test being made, it was found that the newly purchased cows had contracted the disease from those that had not been condemned in the old herd, and had been left at the Hospital.

The stables, which are in poor condition, are not what I would call good cattle barns, and new ones will require to be built, or the existing buildings remodelled. I, however, do not think it would be advisable to have them remodelled.

You will recall that a short time ago Nurse Le Drew drew the attention of the Department to the fact
fact that the pupils at this school were not obtaining an adequate supply of milk, notwithstanding the fact that there were 19 cows there, which only produced about 1½ pails of milk per day. As soon as I heard of this I instructed the Principal to have steps taken at once to increase the milk supply, and a few days later he advised me that a few more cows had been purchased. You can, therefore, imagine my surprise when I learned from Inspector Christianson's report that the milk supply does not exceed 2½ pails per day, which is not nearly sufficient for the needs of the pupils. This alone goes to show that the Principal is not sincere, and that he is not acting towards the Department in a fair manner. A man that requires to be continually under supervision, and whose word cannot be accepted should not, to say the least, hold the position Father Leonard does. Inspector Christianson in referring to him in his report states among other things "I do not think he is big enough to handle the position he occupies at the present time." However, I need not dwell on these remarks as I have already given you my views in regard to him.

With regard to the four children for whom the school is not receiving a grant, orders were issued to the Principal to have these children discharged, but the Inspector still found them at the school. The Principal states in regard to the Campo children as they lived 45 miles from a railway station he did not wish to send them home during the cold weather, but that he would do so just as soon as the weather got milder. It seems to me that the Principal should have acted on the instructions of the Department without question, and I shall be glad to know what is to be done in regard to these children.

With/
With regard to the brass band at the school, no one regrets more than I do that this band, which for the last 25 years has been an institution at Lebret, should have gone out of existence, although I am not surprised to hear that it has done so, as the Principal, Mr. Rossington, the Teacher, and Mr. Harrison, the Bookkeeper, who was Bandmaster, and kept the band going, have had continual friction among themselves. I received a letter yesterday from the last mentioned stating that he had received notice that his services would no longer be required at the school, where he has given faithful service for over twenty years, and in this connection I have received a petition from some of the inhabitants of the Village of Lebret, in which the school is situated, requesting that an investigation be made in regard to Mr. Harrison's dismissal. I am forwarding this petition to you as I think the Department should take some action with reference to the matter.

The report as a whole is not a very bright one, but I would particularly draw your attention to the fact that the work that comes within the jurisdiction of the Sisters has all been well done. All branches of the boys' department, however, are a failure, and the training the boys are at present receiving in the outside work instead of being of benefit to them in the future will have the opposite effect. I trust the Department will take steps without delay to have this very disconcerting state of affairs remedied.

Yours very truly,

W. M. GRAHAM,
Indian Commissioner.
Industrial School,
Lafret March 2nd, 1922

W.M. Graham,

Dear Mr. Graham,

On the last instant I received notice from the Principal that my services were not required after April 1st so I would ask that at the end of March you would have the books inspected so that I may have a clean sheet and avoid any insinuation which might be made after I quit, although I must say that I notice the Principal thanked me most generously for my work. The trouble seems to be about Mr. Rossington and the band at the time of inspection, however, this does not matter. After my long years of service I feel my request should be granted and would like to be assured that my work will be inspected before passing it on to another.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) Geo.J. Harrison.

Memorandum for File:

Action may have to be taken on the following facts, gleaned from Mr. Inspector Christianson's report on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. (Report on No. 6.)

Sister Brabant, Teacher of the Intermediate Girls' Classroom, has very poor English.

Mr. Hosington, Teacher of the Boys' Senior Classroom, appears to be lazy and devoid of interest in his work. The Brass Band and Boy Scout organizations, which have been lately under his wing, have ceased to exist. The Inspector and Commissioner Graham both recommend the early dismissal of this man.

The fire hose in (a) the basement, (b) the boys' play room, (c) the McRobbie chemical apparatus needs to be replaced immediately. (The 4 chemical engines each need a 50 ft. length of rubber hose 1" inside.)

Certain odd repairs are needed in different parts of the building. The Inspector's report mentions no specific needs.

Mr. Christianson states "that the condition of the stable is the worst feature at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School". The barns themselves are in a bad state of repair - the manure has been piled up behind the buildings - cows have been found to be tubercular - the milk supply is entirely inadequate. The cattle have been poorly fed. The Inspector's opinion is that the Principal has not kept his hand on matters outside the main building. The important outdoor work has no redeeming feature and the boys grow up with an improper understanding of the farming and the care of stock. It is suggested that the cows be disposed of gradually and the money spent in the purchase of good milch cows.

The Inspector and Mr. Commissioner Graham both report that everything inside the school and for which the Sisters are responsible was in first class shape; on the other hand, everything for which the Principal is responsible appeared to be neglected. The Principal also lacks dignity and is too familiar with his staff, with the result that they take his orders lightly.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, March 18, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your No. 502-14 of the 28th ultimo, referring to Mr. Rossington, Senior Boys' Teacher of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. I have noted that he appears to be devoid of interest in his work and that the "Brass Band" and "Boy Scout" organizations, which have lately been under his care, have ceased to exist. Ottawa, March 20, 1922.

Reverend Sir:

I have to refer to a matter arising out of the report of Mr. Inspector Christiansen on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. I have learned, with some regret, that Mr. Rossington, Teacher of the Senior Boys' Classroom, appears to have lost his interest in the work among the boys at Lebret.

The Inspector who has visited the Industrial School in the past, for the purpose of an official inspection, is of the opinion that the senior boys have made absolutely no progress of late. Further, it appears that the band and boy scout activities, which were notable features at Lebret heretofore, are no longer active organizations. When the Department learned that Mr. Rossington had the control of these activities, we felt certain that his services were becoming unsatisfactory.

It is the opinion of the Deputy Superintendent General that such organizations outside of the classroom as a cadet corps, brass band, boy scout and girl guide movements are of real value in preparing the youth of the Indian race for citizenship. I believe it is not too late to reorganize and put these activities again in a flourishing condition.

Concerning Mr. Rossington, if you agree with the Department that his services have become unsatisfactory, any action that you take towards securing an efficient successor will be approved and appreciated by this Department.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. G. Leonard, O.M.I.,
Principal,

Saskatoon, March 18th, 1922

To Mr. Duncan Scott
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Would you permit me to draw your attention to certain misleading statements against the Principal of the Liberty Industrial School. I have just been made aware that a group of citizens of the town have lodged a complaint with Mr. W. Graham, the Indian Commissioner, with a view to cast a slur upon him.

In point of fact their only end in view is 1) to harm the good reputation of the school before the Department and 2) to put the Rev. Father in the wrong. And the worst of it is, at least as far as I can see that these gentlemen are carrying their underhand scheme in a spirit of revenge.

Allow me here, dear sir, to explain my statement: Having been the Vice-Principal of this school for the two past years, and being an eye witness to all that happened there, I am in a position...
Les Révérends Pères Oblats

Lebret, Sask.

To state that the sole reason for the above petition against Fr. Leonard originated about a year ago, at the time he refused to lend the School Hall for the Parish's "card parties and concerts", on the grounds that such "parties" were creating a great disturbance in the School, contrary to order and discipline, besides adding a little extra expense.

This action, of course, displeased the aforesaid petitioners, who, ever since were bound to find fault with the management of the School. Slander is their stronger argument. "Down with Fr. Leonard" their motto.

For instance, they accuse him of keeping a poker den, which statement is absolutely false. All his staff can swear to that. They accuse him moreover, of being authoritative in the extreme. As Principal, he has full control and full responsibility over all the departments of the School, and it is only just and proper that he should manage and oversee every one of them. In former times, every employee was his own boss in his respective department, if I may so speak, and as a consequence, many misdeeds were recorded. Mr. W. Graham himself complained that there were too many bosses at the School, and strongly requested Fr. Leonard to take matters in hands and supervise every department, which he did with energy and for the good of the School. Why then blame him for it?

I wish the Department would conduct a fair investigation in this respect.
Les Révérends Pères Oblats

...and it shall soon be convinced that the Rev. Father never exceeded his authority. All his employees, to one exception are ready to stand by my statement if they only have a chance to get a hearing.

The above petitioners desire him lastly of keeping certain employees idle; the others are unfit for the work confided to them. This statement is in my judgment, the zenith of falsehood. A close investigation would prove the contrary, and I myself, for one witness, can swear that never before was the work done in a more effective way, and by men better qualified for it, and this in every department.

Now I beg to inform you, that the staff of the School, to one exception, I mean Mr. G. Harrison, the sponsor of the petition, is well satisfied with the Principal. They all work hand in hand together, and they trust in the able management of their leader.

Allow me to state further, that the Indians are also gratified with the management of the School. Never before has the list of enrolment attained such proportion, I mean a full house.

Besides, the heavy debt weighing upon the School has been greatly reduced since the past two years. In a word while everything goes so smooth and nicely, why should any one butt in to throw stones?

Dear Sir, in concluding, I beg you to bear in mind that the petitioners are for the most part all strangers in the School's affairs. They have signed the petition on hearsay, and Mr. W. Graham himself, if he was just...
Les Révérends Pères Oblats

Lebret, Sask.

upright would make an investigation before taking such slanderous petition against Rev. F. Leonard. I trust that the Department will give the Rev. Father a fair dealing and before passing any judgment, will conduct a thorough investigation. For the love of truth and justice, I wish you do it now and quick.

Pardon me, Dear Sir, this long letter, which I have written in a spirit of frankness and honesty. You are the god of the place in the Indian Department. I know that you will give it a fair appreciation, and do justice to a little missionary of the Indians.

Yours very respectfully,

Leo C. Jeannotte

Lebret, Sask.

Vice Pr. Agency

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

In view of recent developments, I believe it advisable to review the facts concerning the Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. Rev. G. Leonard, O.M.I., was temporarily appointed in October 1919. Mr. Commissioner Graham did not approve of this appointment until after Father Boys, Provincial of the Order, interviewed him in Regina. On December 3rd of the same year the Department approved of Father Leonard's appointment.

During the past two years there have been complaints concerning Father Leonard's administration, none of which, however, were serious enough to warrant the Department's drastic action. I believe that I would find shortcomings and complaints regarding management in connection with many other institutions if I examined other files. However, I am reviewing the facts in connection with Father Leonard, with a view to having on file the history of any mismanagement that has been charged against him.

1. In the Quarterly Returns for March, 1920, there were included the names of two pupils that were not in attendance. This was done, evidently, for the purpose of drawing grant.

2. In October et ff., there were repeated letters directed to Father Leonard from the Commissioner's office, concerning the poor attendance in his classroom, and the Department wrote to Father Boys in an effort to secure an improvement at Qu'Appelle in this regard.

3. In October, 1921, Father Leonard incurred the displeasure of Mr. Commissioner Graham, by informing Regina that he was leaving for Montreal immediately. (The reason given was the illness of his sister). Mr. Graham suggested that principals receive the permission of the Department, before absenting themselves from their duties.

4. On November 4, 1921, at the request of the Department, Mr. Graham instructed Father Leonard to secure a properly qualified teacher in the Intermediate Girls' Classroom. Several letters were written from Regina and Ottawa in this connection, and it was not until the 8th of March 1922, that a successor was appointed.

5. In December 1921 Mr. Graham ordered Father Leonard to arrange for a more adequate supply of milk, following the Nurse's report on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. At the time of Inspector Christianson's visit, about the first instant, there was but 2½ pails per day supplied.
6. Mr. Christianson's report reveals the fact that the Principal has allowed Mr. Rossington, Teacher of the Boys' Senior Classroom, to lose interest in his work and in boys' activities generally; the brass band and boy scout organizations have ceased to exist.

7. The condition in and around the barn, as found by the Inspector, indicates lack of attention on the part of the Principal to matters outside of the main building. Manure has been piled up around the barn and cattle have been poorly fed. Both Rossington, Christianson, and Commissioner Graham report that, although everything inside the school and for which the Sisters are responsible, is in first class shape; yet, on the other hand, the boys' side and outside work have been neglected. It is charged that the Principal lacks dignity and is too familiar with his staff, with the result that they take his orders lightly.

8. Father Leonard has incurred the Commissioner's displeasure in connection with the assigning of tubercular children to a sanitarium. It appears that the Principal refused to carry out Dr. Hall's wishes when the Medical Officer was acting under instructions from Mr. Commissioner Graham. Dr. Hall reports that Father Leonard stated children with tuberculosis would be better off at school than in the sanitarium.

9. Mr. Graham reports that last year the garden at Qu'Appelle, which is supposed to be an example to the Indians and also to the contiguous farmers, was one of the worst kept gardens he ever saw and was a disgrace to the institution.

10. Lately there has been friction between the Principal and the Bookkeeper, Mr. Harrison. Mr. Harrison has been discharged, and a petition was signed by some of the inhabitants of the village of Lebret, requesting that an investigation be made in regard to Mr. Harrison's dismissal. In this connection the Department is in receipt of a petition from a Priest of the Oblate order at Lebret, asking for an investigation of the slanderous charges made against the Principal and forwarded to Mr. Commissioner Graham.

From another source, the Department is in receipt of Father Leonard's defence. The Rev. Principal is of the opinion that Mr. Graham is dissatisfied with his management and is doing everything in his power to secure his removal. Father Leonard goes into his defence rather fully and asks for an impartial investigation before he is condemned.

[Signature]

Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir,

Ottawa, June 1, 1922.

Memorandum.

Honorable Charles Stewart:

Last October the Rev. Father Guy, on behalf of the Oblate Order, officially requested the Department of Indian Affairs to head the list of subscriptions for the erection of a monument to Rev. Father Hugonard, C.M.I., late principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. It is proposed to erect a statue in front of the institution and on the property of the Department, at a cost of over $5,000.00. Indians and other friends in the community are making contributions.

This is a somewhat unusual request, but there may be some grounds for the Government's favourable consideration. Father Hugonard was a pioneer missionary and educationist among the Indians and was, for many years, principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School at Lebret. This institution is visited by a great many people, particularly during the summer months, and a monument of the virtual founder of the school on the grounds would add something to the interest of the school.

In November, I presented this matter to the Honorable Sir James Lougheed, and he requested that it be given consideration when the estimates were being prepared. The matter was kept in mind when an item for alterations at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School was placed in the Main Estimates.

As funds are now available, I respectfully ask for your consideration of a subscription of $1,000. It may be necessary to have passed an Order in Council.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.
Memorandum.

Honorable Charles Stewart:

Last October the Rev. Father Guy, on behalf of the Oblate Order, officially requested the Department of Indian Affairs to head the list of subscriptions for the erection of a monument to Rev. Father Hugonard, C.M., late Principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. It is proposed to erect a statue in front of the institution and on the property of the Department, at a cost of over $3,000.00. Indians and other friends in the community are making contributions.

This is a somewhat unusual request, but there may be some grounds for the Government's favourable consideration. Father Hugonard was a pioneer missionary and educationist among the Indians and was, for many years, principal of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School at Lebret. This institution is visited by a great many people, particularly during the summer months, and a monument of the virtual founder of the school on the grounds would add something to the interest of the school.

In November, I presented this matter to the Honorable Sir James Loughhead, and he requested that it be given consideration when the estimates were being prepared. The matter was kept in mind when an item for alterations at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School was placed in the Main Estimates.

As funds are now available, I respectfully ask for your consideration of a subscription of $1,000. It may be necessary to have passed an Order in Council.

Deputy Superintendent General.
June 8, 1922.

Dear Father Guy,

In further reference to the monument which the Oblate Order proposes to place in front of the Qu'Appelle Indian Industrial School in memory of the late Reverend Father Hugonard, O.M.I., and towards the erection of which this Department has been asked for a contribution, I am pleased to say that, assuming that the monument is to cost not less than $3000.00, the Department will be willing to contribute the sum of $1000.00 towards its erection upon being furnished with a statement of the expenditure, accompanied as is the practice when the Department is sharing with a municipality or other body the cost of any work which is being executed other than by the Department itself - by an affidavit covering the statement and to the effect that not less than the said sum of $3000.00 has been expended on the work.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Reverend Joseph Guy, O.M.I.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
University of Ottawa,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott,

At the request of the Lieutenant Governor I attended a meeting at his office yesterday for the purpose of arranging a programme for His Excellency, the Governor General, who is to visit this City and district on the 24, 25, and 26 of this month. It was decided to visit the Qu'Appelle Indian Industrial School on the 26th and there meet some of the leading Indians as well as visit the Institution and it was decided also to have luncheon at that point. It will be necessary, therefore, to have an appropriation for the purpose and I would ask that I be granted authority to spend $75.00 on the actual luncheon as well as authority to purchase what is necessary in the way of glasses and cutlery. As a matter of fact I think that an Institution of this kind should have complete equipment to meet such occasions.

I am leaving for the West tomorrow and will be away two (2) weeks but if the authority is received in the meantime my secretary will look after the purchases and the requirements. I am also having a certain amount of painting done on the verandah and in the room in which the luncheon will be served. I therefore request authority to incur the above expenditures.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner

CANADA
Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to say that the visit of His Excellency, the Governor General of Canada, to the Qu'Appelle School on the 26th, was in every way a success, and I have today received a letter from His Excellency, congratulating the Department on the work being done at this Institution.

I visited the school on Thursday, June 22nd and closed the boys' class-room. I had about seventy-five boys working; white washing the fences surrounding the Institution and painting the iron fences around the front of the school. I also had the garden trimmed up and the grounds weeded, so that the place presented a favourable appearance.

The children, both boys and girls, were neatly dressed. The girls in a dark blue uniform with red facings, and the boys all in navy blue Norfolk suits. In addition there were two troopers of Indian Boy Scouts to receive him at the gate. The File Halle Band was in front of the Institution and played the National Anthem as he approached the School.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
His Excellency was accompanied on his visit to the school, by His Honour, The Lieutenant Governor, the Premier of the Province and two members of his cabinet, the Mayor of the City of Regina, and various other representatives of public bodies.

I felt sure you would be anxious to know how things went and I am taking this opportunity of letting you know.

Yours very truly,

W. M. GRAHAM,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am receiving complaints from quite a few Indians about the training their children are getting at the Qu'Appelle School.

They complain that their children cannot speak English when they leave school, as well as those who do not go to school. They also complain that a great deal of the children's time is taken up with farm work and that they get very little class-room work.

I would be glad to know if the Department are insisting upon qualified teachers being appointed to this Institution. I would also ask if the last appointment of teacher for the boys' room at the Qu'Appelle school was made with the approval of the Department and what qualifications the new teacher has.

It is the practice of the Department to notify me when teachers are appointed at the various schools but in this case I do not think I have been advised. I would be glad to know what the man's name is and what qualifications he has so that I will be able to answer the Indian intelligently when they make these complaints.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs Commissioner

Duncan G. Scott, Esquire
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs - Ottawa.
Ottawa, Sept. 29, 1922.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your No. 502-14 B of the 19th instant, informing the Department that complaints have been received by you from some Indians, concerning the training offered to the pupils of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. I have noted the remarks of these complaining parents, and I am of the opinion that you have been long enough in Indian work to intelligently attach proper importance to the complaints of parents who have children in residential schools. Occasionally such remarks are well founded, but generally they may be classed as the querulous result of some fancied and temporary personal grievance.

In reply to the second part of your communication, I wish to state that it is the practice of this Department to notify you concerning changes in teachers at day schools only. The personnel of the staff at a residential school is more or less a domestic arrangement and this Department holds the principal responsible. We expect the church representatives to appoint teachers who will do successful work, not only in classrooms, but in the other departments of educational work. It is only at the time of the annual report that we are offered the names and qualifications.

If, however, public school or department inspectors find in residential schools teachers who are poorly qualified, then we exercise our prerogative of supervision and we demand a properly qualified successor.

I think you are quite justified in telling any complaining Indians that the Department is taking adequate steps to secure good instruction. When inspectors or any of our officials offer criticisms, departmental action is then timely.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
REGINA, SASK.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK.

5th October 1922.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have your No. 116575-1 of the 29th ultimo, replying to mine of the 19th ultimo, respecting complaints received by me concerning the training offered to the pupils of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

The first paragraph of your letter would suggest that I had drawn attention to a matter which is considered by the Department as unimportant and trivial, but the nature of the complaints were such that I consider I should have been remiss had I not taken cognizance of them. I did not deal more fully with these in my letter, as, when you were recently in the West, I had talked with you over the conditions existing at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. My letter to you of March 8th last, enclosing a report by Inspector Christianson on that school, has also apparently been overlooked by you. Inspector Christianson dealt fully with the conditions existing there, especially regarding the training of the boys, and the negligence of the Principal in the matter of supervision and control. In the first paragraph of my letter I drew attention to the conditions existing in the boys' class rooms, and referred to one teacher in particular whose services have since been dispensed with.

Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 660-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
I also drew attention to the disgraceful state of the stables, and the consequent lack of care that the stock were receiving, and concluded by commenting that as a whole Inspector Christierson's report was "not a bright one"; that all branches in the boys' Department were failures, and expressed the hope that the Department would take steps to have this state of affairs remedied. My letter was acknowledged on March 18th., and I was advised that a memorandum was being prepared for you in connection with the action it was believed necessary to take, since when I have received no further intimation of what it was proposed should be done.

The attitude of the Department is disappointing, and I might well hesitate in future to call attention to matters which need remedying. I was indeed adopting a policy which the Department itself follows, for I have frequently received requests from Ottawa to investigate into Indians' complaints of various natures. Those which I received and drew attention to were not merely local, but came Agencies to me from the Fisher River and Portage-la-Prairie/ also, and it is significant that many of them are from ex-pupils of the school, who have raised the criticism that their children are not receiving the attention and education that they themselves received. Twenty five years ago Indian parents were indifferent to the teaching and upbringing of their children, but graduates today readily note/
note defects in school training which they discover in the conduct of their children at home.

After my conversation with you in regard to the Qu'Appelle School, and the information I gave you of the work I myself had to do to properly prepare the place and the pupils for the reception of His Excellency the Governor-General, I thought you would have taken a more serious view of the complaints relating to its management, of which I had been able to form a personal opinion, and which had come directly under my personal observation.

I have not singled out the Qu'Appelle Industrial School for special criticism, nor do I desire to be involved in a controversy with the Church, which, I am sure, is as ready as any other denomination to acquiesce in the Department's demand for better administration. In my letter of the 19th ultimo, I enquired if the last appointee as boys' teacher has the desired qualifications, and if the appointment was made with the approval of the Department. I think I might have received a reply to my query, for if the appointment was agreeable to the Department, I could have met the complaints of the Indians by so informing them.

I am of the opinion that the complaints drawn attention to in my letter of the 19th ultimo, are well founded, and call for recognition of and action by the Department.

Yours very truly,

W. M. GRAHAM
Indian Commissioner.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., Nov. 16th, 1922

Dear Mr. Scott,-

As you are aware, it is proposed to erect a monument to the late Father Hugonnard in the Qu'Appelle Valley, at or near the Industrial School. I have been taking an active part in this movement by soliciting subscriptions from his many friends and admirers. Many Indians would like to subscribe to this cause and a few have done so, but for the majority of the individual Indians the times are hard and some have suggested that the Bands who have funds could vote a contribution from that source. I do not know whether it would be in order to ask them to do this but hope it could be done. The idea is to raise $3000.00 and I thought the three Bands in the Qu'Appelle Agency might be asked for $200. or $250. each. File Hills Bands have no Trust funds but I am sure a number of them will be glad to give as much as they are able.

Father Hugonnard spent thirty-five years working among the Indians under all sorts of conditions and I often hear them speaking about him and expressing appreciation for all he did for them in the old days.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

CANADA
Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that the report of Mr. Public School Inspector Stevenson has been drawn to my attention and, although this Provincial Officer has commented favorably on certain phases of the classroom activity at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, there are some points raised by him that call for special attention, with despatch. This department wishes to cooperate with you and our officers in the field in an effort to provide the best possible educational facilities at the largest Indian residential school in Canada. The lighting in the three girls' classrooms and the junior boys' room is entirely insufficient and is injurious to the pupils' eyes. In the spring you will please draw this fact to the attention of Mr. Commissioner Graham, of Regina, who will arrange to have a competent workman go to Lebret and supervise the installation of more or larger windows. The Inspector reports that it will not be possible to provide more window space in the senior boys' classroom, but a brighter appearance will obtain if the ceiling is painted white. This painting should be attended to without delay.

The blackboard in the senior boys' room should be lowered and the steps at present in use removed. If at all possible, arrange to have more blackboard accommodation in the junior girls' classroom. If there is any expense in connection with the above matters, please requisition to Mr. Commissioner Graham for the material needed. The intermediate girls' classroom should be equipped with some library books and a selection will be made by this department and shipment made to you.

As you are aware, the classroom work among the boys of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School has never been very successful of late. I believe Mr. Inspector Stevenson has given us a most valuable suggestion when he advises that the junior room be presided over by one of the sisters. Her supervision need not extend beyond the classroom, but primary work in all its classroom phases can be best supervised by a lady teacher. I would therefore request that you will make arrangements, in the immediate future, to release Mr. Arthur Petit from his duties in the classroom and arrange for one of the sisters to take over the work.

The Department cannot allow Mr. Petit to remain in charge of a classroom. Mr. Stevenson, the Inspector, is known personally to the Department as a fair-minded and efficient educationist. From the facts that he has presented, I am convinced that Mr. Petit's English is not only faulty but positively bad.

Rev. G. Leonard,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Industrial School,
Lebret, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 660-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

CANADA
I notice on the Inspector's report that there were 52 pupils present in the junior boys' classroom on the date of his visit. This suggests to me that you are still following the half day system largely and perhaps there are not thirty-five boys in attendance in the junior room throughout the whole day. If it is your wish to continue a full day's teaching activity for these junior boys, you should prepare to arrange for a second teacher to supervise the kindergarten or more junior work. This Department will assist you with equipment for hand work such as paper cutting, sand tables, blocks, etc., if you are able to arrange for two Sisters to take charge of the junior boys.

A copy of this communication is being addressed to Mr. Commissioner Graham, so that he will be informed regarding the changes that are to take place and he will cooperate with you by authorizing any expense necessary in connection with such changes.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Letter # 9318

Sir:

With reference to your communication No. 116575-6 dated Dec. 15th, I beg to say that in accordance with your wishes, I am taking the matter up with the Mother Provincial of the Grey Nuns Order to arrange for the securing of a Sister to take charge of the Junior Boys Class-Room. Mr. Petit is being released from his duties as teacher in this Class. Mr. Paul, teacher of the senior Boys Class has left here to attend the Provincial Normal School at Regina, to complete his professional training, and we are securing a Saskatchewan qualified teacher to replace him, a Mr. Blanch, graduate from the Regina Normal School. We are also attending to the repairing of the Class Rooms.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, Jan. 12, 1923.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, informing the Department that you are arranging with the Mother Provincial of the Grey Nuns for the services of a Sister to take charge of the Junior Boys' Classroom, and intimating, also, that Mr. Petit has been relieved of his duties as teacher. The Department is pleased that you have taken action in this connection, with such despatch.

I have also noted, with satisfaction, that Mr. Paul is completing his professional training and that the officer substituting for him is properly qualified.

The travelling nurse's latest report refers to the Sister lately appointed to the school infirmary as an excellent nurse, and the Department wishes also to congratulate the school in this connection. The nurse's report, generally, was quite favourable to those in charge at the school; but I must refer to the meals that are being prepared for the children. Kindly arrange for a little more variety in the diet offered, and insist upon a more careful preparation of the bread. The Department will cooperate in any way possible in the effort to secure the best possible results at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. G. Leonard,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Indus. School,
Lebret, Sask.
Sir,

I have received from Father Leonard an explanation of the absence of a large number of girls from the Class-room during the last Quarter. He states that this irregular attendance was due to illness in every case as none of them went home without authority. I have instructed him that in future such explanations should be given in the column provided for that purpose on the returns.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, No.116575-1 relative to the food that is being provided for pupils at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. I am glad to know that the Department are taking steps to have a stock barn built at Lebret for milch cows.

I may state that I have already asked the Medical Officer of this institution to make a special note of the food provided for the pupils. I am hoping that there will be an improvement along these lines.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa, June 14, 1923.

Reverend Sir:

I have your No. 9380 of the 29th ultimo, with reference to diet sheets for Dr. Hall at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

In reply I beg to state that you should bend every energy towards securing harmony with department officers, and if our medical representative feels that frequent diet sheets are necessary, you should endeavour to meet his wishes.

The Department considers that an institution the size of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School should have method and definite routine in the kitchen, and the preparation of diet sheets should not entail work on the part of the principal himself. I am sure that Dr. Hall and our other representatives will be quite satisfied to have a recapitulation of the amount of the different varieties of food placed on the tables for the children for each meal of the day, and that it will not be necessary to draw up detailed and comprehensive diet sheets. A copy of this letter is being addressed to Mr. Commissioner Graham of Regina.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. G. Leonard,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Industrial School,
Lebret, Sask.

Ottawa, June 16, 1923.

Dear Father Guy:

I have to draw your attention to the unsatisfactory conditions at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. The Principal, the Rev. Father Leonard, has been given every opportunity to prove his capacity, and I regret to say that he has not measured up to the standard required at the more important institutions. Qu'Appelle is the banner school of the Roman Catholic Church in the West, and it is in the interests of all concerned to have as the administrative head a man of outstanding character and ability.

From our conversations on this subject, I would judge that we are practically in accord on the general principles involved, and I must insist that a new incumbent for this position be found in the immediate future. Please take, without delay, whatever steps you consider necessary.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Joe. Guy, O.M.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th inst., enclosing a copy of a communication that you had written to the Rev. Principal of the Qu'Appelle School, regarding the furnishing of a proper diet sheet for Dr. Hall, Medical Officer.

I may say that I was at this Agency last week and I instructed the Principal on the same lines as your letter indicates. There is no reason why we should not furnish the doctor with a diet sheet from time to time, so that he would be in a position to know what the children are getting in the way of food.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Department Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
The whole trouble here is that the parents of these children are demanding better care for their children and a better education and training. This school is not what it should be. The Department have been informed of this. I had reason to believe that a change would be made, but this has not taken place, and there will always be dissatisfaction about getting children to attend this school especially those of graduates. I am at a loss to know why the Department have not taken action on the reports that have been sent in by the Inspectors. This school is far from what it should be.

At the Board's request, I report to Mr. Sury

As a new teacher is expected in a month,

It stated action could be expected in a month.
I am in receipt of a letter from the principal of the Qu'Appelle industrial school in which he makes a request that the salary of the night-watchman in that institution be paid by the Department over and above the grant. I do not see that the Department should be called upon to pay this salary as it is not done in other institutions; the expense is borne by the school out of the per capita grant.

I visited the Qu'Appelle school some weeks ago and I found that the principal had done away with the services of the night-watchman on the score of economy. Personally I think this is poor economy and that the watchman is the last officer around the institution whose services should be dispensed with. I shall be glad, therefore, if you will advise the principal of the school that on no account is he to do away with the night-watchman and that his wages will have to be paid out of the school grant.

Yours very truly,

Indian Commissioner,
Duncan C. Scott, Esq., Litt.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Reverend Sir:

I have been informed by Mr. Commissioner Graham that you have dispensed with the services of a night watchman at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. I hasten to inform you the Department is surprised that you have taken any action which jeopardizes the lives of the children under your care. If you have not already arranged for a new incumbent, please do so without delay. The salary of a night watchman will have to be paid, as in the case of other schools, from the per capita earnings.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Letter # 9512

Dear Sir:

At your request, I engaged a night-watchman to go through the school and stables every hour from 8 P.M. until 5 A.M., inclusive. This man commenced his duties on Nov. 16th, and has been on duty every night since then.

Now I feel I cannot afford to pay this man out of the Per Capita Grant, as this money is needed for the children and really belongs to them. And, as this is an extra employee engaged for the protection of Government property, I would respectfully request that you take this matter up with the Department with a view of securing us a Bonus for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

(signed) G. Leonard
Principal.

Dear Mr. Scott:

We have been struggling for about two and one-half years to try and get funds to erect a Memorial to Father Hugonard, in the Qu'Appelle Valley, possibly in the grounds of the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. Times have been hard, and it is difficult to get people to give as much as they would like to give. I have succeeded, so far, in getting about $500.00, and I understand you are going to be able to secure a grant from the Department of $1000. Is this right?

Father Hugonard labored for thirty-five years with the Indians of the Qu'Appelle Valley. He was an outstanding man amongst the Indians, as you well know; and many of them look upon him as a great personal benefactor, and his name is a byword on most of the Reserves today. The Indians, I feel, would readily contribute something from their Band Funds, if it were in order for them to do so. I will be glad if you will give me your opinion, as to whether it would be in order to submit a resolution to the Band, to grant a donation from their funds. If we could get assistance of this kind, the outlook would be quite bright.

My personal knowledge of Father Hugonard and his work, makes me feel that some recognition of his work among the Indians, should be shown by them and by the Government. I trust you will be able to assist in any way you can, to bring about this venture successfully.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner

D.C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott:

With reference to my letter of October 31st, 1921, your letters of November 16th, 1921, and June 8th, 1922, in connection with the erection of a monument in memory of the late Rev. Father Hugonard O.M.I., and the promise, through your kindness, of the sum of $1,000.00 towards said monument, I beg to state that steps are being taken for the erection of this monument within the next year. I therefore take the liberty of asking to again enclose in the estimates this amount of $1,000.00, if such a course is necessary.

Yours very truly,

Joseph Guy, O.M.I.
I beg to say that it was my intention to discuss with you while in Ottawa, the question of making an allowance for additional pupils at the Lebret Industrial School.

This school has at the present time about 237 children in residence, which is twelve over the number they are being paid a grant for. The school building and staff at Lebret are adequate for 250 children, which means no additional cost for fuel or attention. The children who attend this school are from all over the Province of Saskatchewan, and from points in Manitoba, and as the boarding schools at Pine Creek and Sandy Bay have their full number, and the space is available at Lebret for the accommodation of 250 children, it seems to me only reasonable that the grant should be increased to that number. This would mean that the Department would not be called upon to provide extra accommodation at the various schools until this school was filled to capacity.

I would, therefore, strongly recommend that the Lebret School be allowed a grant for 250 pupils.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa
If the funds of the current year provide for this, it will certainly help the Church Authorities out with the work, but if funds are not available I would ask you to have the amount inserted in the estimates to provide for the coming year.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, February 6, 1925.

Sir:

I have your No. 314-11A of the 30th ultimo, with reference to increasing the pupilage at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. I should be pleased if you would indicate the exact number of children that can be accommodated in the dormitories - 500 cubic feet of air per child. The Department agrees that all available accommodation at residential schools should be utilized before consideration is given to enlarging our buildings at similar schools in the neighborhood. When the available dormitory air space is determined, the Department will give further consideration.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Referring to my letter of the 30th of January, File No. 314-11B, asking for authority for additional pupils at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and your reply of the 6th of February, asking me if I would indicate the number of children that can be accommodated in the dormitories at 500 cubic feet of air per child.

I beg to inform you that there is 105,104 cubic feet of air in the boys' and girls' dormitories in this institution, which would provide for 210 pupils. I took the matter of air space up with the Deputy Minister of Public Health in this Province, and he states that this school, or any other properly built school will accommodate children with perfect safety at 400 cubic ft., providing the ventilation through the windows is properly looked after. This being the case there is dormitory space for 250 children in this institution.

Further I may add that there are other rooms in the school, such as closed-in galleries and private rooms that are used by pupils, with an air space of 22,957 cu.ft. This would provide for about 43 additional pupils, so I think that you could safely authorize the additional pupilage at this school. Personally I think that we can accommodate about 275 children there.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner

Sir:

I have your No. 314-11B of the 12th instant, with reference to increasing the pupilage at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 17th of March last, #114-0-1 regarding the matter of increasing the pupilage at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, I beg to say that I have gone into this matter thoroughly and I am now able to give you some further information on the subject, and after consideration of same you will kindly decide whether it is the intention to increase the pupilage.

The two large dormitories provide for 210 pupils and there is a small dormitory which provides for 11 pupils. There is accommodation in the hospital for 65 beds, and this can be cut down to 35 beds, leaving additional accommodation for 28 pupils, making in all 246.

At the present time the school is drawing a grant for 235 pupils and there are considerably more than this number in the school; I think perhaps 235 or 240. Would the Department be agreeable to paying a grant on this number? I think myself that there would be no over-crowding. I will see that the children are not crowded into the two large dormitories but that some of them are placed in the various rooms mentioned, off the hospital and in the sleeping porches.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr Scott,

As you have perhaps seen by the press it is proposed to erect a monument at Lebret this summer to Father Hugonard. Through your good offices, Archbishop Mathieu gave the Memorial Committee assurance that a thousand dollars has been set aside in the estimates for this purpose. Premier Dunning has likewise given us five hundred dollars on behalf of Saskatchewan. The balance necessary for the required amount is being raised throughout the province - a notable contribution coming from the Indians themselves. Five thousand dollars is the necessary objective.

The monument is taking the form of a dignified bronze group with a figure of Father Hugonard with an Indian boy and girl in native costume on either side of him. It is to stand on a pedestal of field stone in the parterre of the Lebret School facing the shores of Lake Qu'Appelle. It is hoped to have the unveiling the last week in September or the first week in October.

Might we trespass on the generous amenities of your kindly interest in this tribute to Father Hugonard in asking if you would have the Government cheque forwarded to the Committee. Our Treasurer is Mr W M Graham of the Indian Department here and you could have it made out to the Hugonard Memorial Committee and forwarded to him. Time rushes so swiftly when a matter of this kind is brought to consummation that there are anxious moments until everything is definitely settled.

Thanking you kindly in anticipation,

faithfully,

[Signature]

Chancellor

Mr Duncan Scott,
Indian Dept., Ottawa.

(on behalf of
HUGONARD MEMORIAL COMMITTEE)

Lebret, Sask., July 6th, 1925.

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Director Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:

For the last two days I have had the opportunity of visiting Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School and discussing with the Principal, Rev. Fr. Leonard O.M.I., problems relative to the management of the institution.

I feel more than pleased to communicate to you my sentiments with the hope that it will afford you satisfaction to hear good news from the most important of the R.C. Indian Residential Schools.

First of all the exterior and interior appearance of the school is to be commended. The garden about which complaints had reached the Department in the past is in such a state that Commissioner Graham himself could not refrain from saying to Rev. Fr. Leonard that he had not seen such a nice one in Regina. The outbuildings are all in first class condition. As the walls and ceiling of all the rooms have been painted and the floor of the halls covered with cork linoleum the aspect is refreshing to the eye and the house appears really homelike to the children.

When Rev. Fr. Leonard was appointed Principal less than six years ago the school had a roll attendance of only 137 children. Since he has recruited 117 boys and 121 girls making a total of 238. The present number on the roll is 243 all Indian children with the exception of 3 whom the principal keeps through charity and 2 whom the Department has not thought fit as yet to admit. The above number is the highest ever attained at this school for Indian children and I think that the Rev. Principal is to be congratulated on his success as a recruiting officer. The curriculum of studies is of the highest standard under the direction of certified teachers for the Province of Saskatchewan. The children I have seen seem well developed and all strongly attached to their school. In fact I understand that the reputation of the school has never been better and I must say that requests from every quarter oblige us to consider in the very near future the necessity of enlarging as more than 50 children are waiting for their turn to be admitted, lack of space being the only preventive.

It may prove of interest to you to know that since his appointment Rev. Fr. Leonard has assured the financial position of the school and that fact speaks highly of his administrative qualities and singles him as our foremost Principal in the district.

I may add that the Principal, staff and employees (13 nuns and 15 men) form but one family all working hand in hand to realize the ideal of a true Indian Residential School according to the desires of the Department and their own convictions.

Trusting that the above details

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Sir:

As you are aware there has been movement here in the last three years to erect a suitable memorial to the late Father Hugonard, who was Principal of our Industrial School at Fort Qu'Appelle for thirty-three years, and who spent about forty years, in fact a long life, laboring with the Indians. He was a man that was dearly beloved by all, and a true friend of the Indians.

From time to time I have had suggestions from the various Bands in the Qu'Appelle Agency asking that a certain amount of money be deducted from their funds as a contribution from these Indians toward this memorial. A meeting was held on the various reserves on the 16th ultimo, and the Band concerned practically voted unanimously for a grant to be taken from their funds of $500.00 each. The Resolutions and lists of voters are herewith attached. I will be glad if the Department will send a cheque for the amounts mentioned.

I understand that the Deputy Head of the Department is absent, and if it is necessary I would ask that this be brought to the Head of the Department, as the amount is required almost at once. The cost of the monument will be approximately $6,000.00; public subscription will meet a little more than half of this.

Your obedient servant,

M. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
With reference to Mr. Graham's request for a cheque for $1500.00 being contribution by the Indians of Pasquahs; Muscowpetungs; and Piapot's Bands, as per resolution passed by each Band towards the monument to be erected to the memory of the late Father Hugonard, I beg to say that payment can be made from the Interest Funds of the Bands mentioned, but I would draw your attention to the Deputy's letter of the 19th June last wherein he states it will be necessary to have a voucher showing the expenditure on the monument before issuing a cheque covering the grant of $1000.00 to be made from the appropriation for Indian Education. I therefore think we should have this voucher before paying the grant to be given by the Indians.

Mr. Graham points out that the amount is required at once but I fail to understand why.

I would suggest wiring Mr. Graham for this voucher before issuing cheque.

Aug. 7th., 1925.

Thousands of Indians
At Historic Pageant
Of Days of La Verendrye

WESTERN TRIBES WILL BE REPRESENTED IN NUMBERS
AT FESTIVAL FOLLOWING HUGONARD MEMORIAL UNVEILING

Chief Day Walker, who is looking north with his bandmates in their tepees at Lebret for the Indian Days Saturday.

It is expected that between ten thousand and fifteen thousand Indians will attend the festival which will be held at Lebret on Saturday next, August 12, to attend the unveiling of the monument erected by the Lebret Chamber of Commerce in memory of Father Hugonard and the magnificent historical pageant which will be presented on the shores of the Qu'Appelle lakes. The Chamber of Commerce and other organizations have donated their full activities to stimulating interest in the festival.

Fully 400 western Indians will be present at the festival and will play according to W. M. Graham, Indians are still very much interested in the lives of the old adventurers who came to Canada from France and will be faithfully reproduced on a historic stage.

Apart from its dramatic features, the Lebret pageant promises to be the most distinguished gathering of distinguished speakers who will participate in the festivities. Mr. Herbert Munro of Highways, will speak on the life and times of Samuel de Champlain, and D. C. Coleman, Winnipeg's leading authority on the Western Line C. P. R., will tell of the discovery of the Qu'Appelle Valley.

Dear Mr. Scott,-

I am enclosing voucher No. 3768 amounting to $2500.00 in favor of the Architectural Bronze and Iron Works, Toronto, being estimated value of work performed on Hugonard Memorial.

I might add that we have $1445.04 in the Savings Bank here and subscriptions promised to the extent of $110.00, making a total available of $1555.04 towards the completion of the monument.

When the Indians of the three Bands of the Qu'Appelle Agency voted $1500.00, they did so on the understanding that the monument would be placed near the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and although there are some prominent citizens of Regina who think it would be better to have it located in the grounds of the Parliament buildings here, I do not consider it would be fair to the Indians to make such a change.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that Melanie Blondeau has resigned her position of teaching Indian Handicraft at this school. Her reason being that she is leaving Lebret.

I would recommend that Miss Rachael Newson be appointed to this vacancy. She has a thorough knowledge of Indian Handicraft and I believe quite competent to fill this position, as she has been working with Melanie Blondeau in this line for the last ten years. She is a hunch-back and has no other means of earning a livelihood except with work of this kind. She is forty-four years old and is an ex-pupil of this school.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 6th, 1926.

Sir:

The Principal of the Qu'Appelle Indian residential School informs the Department that Miss Melanie Blondeau, the teacher of Indian handicraft, has resigned her position, and he recommends the appointment of Miss Rachael Newson to succeed her. The Principal states that Miss Newson has a thorough knowledge of Indian handicraft and that she is competent to fill the position.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you as to the advisability of continuing this service and whether you consider that the results achieved warrant the expenditure in the payment of salary. If you concur in the appointment of Miss Newson, I shall be pleased to have a report as to her qualifications for the position.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant #114-0-1, informing me that Miss Melanie Blondeau has resigned her position in the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and that the Principal recommends the appointment of Miss Rachel Newson, stating that she has a thorough knowledge of Indian handiwork and that she is competent to fill the position.

In reply I beg to say that I cannot recommend that Miss Newson be appointed, and I do not think that Miss Blondeau's work warranted the payment of any salary that she has drawn in the last ten years. I would, therefore, recommend that nothing be done in the matter of making an appointment to fill this position.

Your obedient servant,

M. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., July 18th, 1927

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that the unveiling of the Monument to the late Father Hugonard at Lebret took place on Saturday, the 9th instant, the Lieutenant-Governor of the province officiating. There were a large number of people in attendance at the celebration, and the official visitors included Mr. J.G. Gardiner, Prime Minister of this province, Hon. Mr. Motherwell, the French Consul, and Monseigneur Marois representing Archbishop Mathieu who was ill. The ceremony was very interesting, but was marred somewhat by rain. I would say there were fully two thousand people present, including the Indians. I arranged to have representatives present from most of the reserves and they were camped on the grounds with their highly decorated tepees, and were very much interested in the proceedings. A very large number of ex-pupils were present.

I am attaching herewith a snapshot of the Monument, which is situated about sixty yards from the school in a beautiful little park and about sixty feet from the edge of the lake. I feel sure you will like the statue. The cash outlay was about $6100.00, and in addition to this we put in some work gratis, viz:- digging the excavation and putting in a concrete base ten feet deep, which is below the frost line.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart.

Re Monument to Father Hugonard.

This memorial statue has been erected on the grounds of the Qu'Appelle Indian Industrial School at Lebret. It is in the middle of the garden, and of course the grounds are kept in good order by the staff of the school. The monument cost about $5,100.00. $1055.00 was provided by Parliamentary Appropriation, and $1500.00 was contributed equally from the funds of three Indian bands: Muscowpetung, Pigeon and Pasqua. In all $2555.00 was contributed from these sources, and the remaining amount was collected from citizens of Saskatchewan. I beg to send herewith a snapshot of the monument.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Short sketch of Father Hugonard's life, his illness and his death.

In the year 1845, Almighty God looked upon a very pious family in the town of Colomb, France and blessed them with a son Joseph Hugonard who has been taken from this world to a better land to receive his reward. Though very young, he left his parents, his home and all the pleasures of the world to become a priest of God who surely had chosen him to be one of the great missionaries of the West.

He arrived at Qu'Appelle in 1872 and worked very hard to convert the Indians. He remained at the Mission with Reverend Father Magnan his great friend, who shared his sufferings for over 18 years.

Ten years after Father Hugonard's arrival in Qu'Appelle he wrote to the Department asking for money to build a school for his Indians. His favour was granted and soon men were at work. Sisters of Charity from Montreal were sent for, and arrived at Qu'Appelle Station October 21st 1884. Father went himself to meet the four Sisters.

He then went to the different reserves to get children for his school, but this was not an easy thing to do. Many refused and even many threatened to kill him; God took pity on poor Father Hugonard, softened the hearts of the cruel Indians, and a considerable number of boys and girls were sent here where a good training would enable...
them to live as white people do.

In 1904, while Father was on business affairs in U.S.A., the school burned down, but the children did not return home; they remained in little sheds until a new house could be built. Dear Father grieved very much for the school, but he had hopes to have another one built. He went to Ottawa and obtained the favour he was longing for. It was only in 1905 that the school was rebuilt. By this time Father had won the hearts of all the Indians. He converted hundreds of them. Father Hugonard was not one who thought only of himself, but tried continually to win all hearts to God and save souls. He was kind to every body, no matter how badly they had treated him, he was always ready to forgive them.

He loved his Indians and they loved him as a dear Father. Never did a poor person pass his door without him giving them all they needed for their body and also instructing them in the Christian faith. He had been Principal since the school has been built. Four years ago he was taken very sick and was sent to take a rest to New York; he was well and happy after a time and came back to continue his good works.

He fell very sick again the next spring and this time was sent to Texas; there he met one of his greatest friends, Archbishop Langlois who had also been sent there to take a rest, and was taken...
away in June 1915, and he had surely pleaded for our dear Principal. Our dear Father had never again recovered all his strength. He caught cold this winter and took very sick on January 15th, 1917. This was to be his last illness. It looked as if he had only been sent to us by God for the last four years.

He suffered very much during his illness. On the 30th of January, Reverend Father Cahill Provincial of St. Boniface anointed him. The next day his old friend Reverend Father Magan arrived, and had come to unite his prayers with ours. Though many were said, God will was that he should have him.

His Grace Archbishop Macdonald, who had been at Quebec for the last four weeks, arrived on Sunday at 1:30 P.M. Father was delighted to see him. His Grace gave him Holy Communion during the night. His agony began on Sunday morning at 7, and was most terrible while His Grace Father, the Sisters and the children were continually praying. At 12:15 P.M. he breathed his last. The dear Father Magan at his bedside seeing that his most faithful friend had left him, exiled on this earth of misery and sorrow then his head on the pillow of the dear departed, kissed his forehead and wept bitterly.

It was joy in heaven, but bitter sorrow on earth. Dear Father was spared...
in the parlor.

We had three services for him. On Tuesday in our chapel, Wednesday in the church; we accompanied the body in going. Thursday in our chapel was the final service. Around the coffin 50 priests formed a perfect crown, praying for their departed friend.

His Grace spoke eloquently in French and English of Father Hugonard's virtues and good deeds.

Reverend Father Leduc of St Albert gave a short sermon in Cree and Reverend Father Etienne in Sioux.

We accompanied the body to the cemetery where the remains will not be laid in the frozen ground but in the little vault for the winter. Another service will be held in the spring again our hearts will be broken by grief.

We will not try to paint the meeting of dear Archbishop Langevin and our beloved departed; it is a picture for higher and more skilful painters, a picture for which the colours have not been found yet upon this earth.

There also came to welcome him the innumerable souls of infants, old men and women, christianized by dear Father. What an everlasting joy must fill each breast.

We also shall inherit of the
eternal beatitude if we follow the instructions of dear Father Ligonard to whom we owe our salvation and for which our gratitude will be beyond capable expression.

May he rest in Peace.

Edna Trottier.
Ed. and Funeral of Father Hugonard. Feb. 21, 1907

I feel great sorrow that we lost this historic school was caused by the death of its venerable founder, the most Reverend Father Hugonard. Although he had grown old, we never expected him to be so suddenly taken away from us so soon, but it was true that he should receive the crown of bliss for the hardships he underwent in this part of the country which he so dearly loved.

His life was one of constant sorrow and hardship, but despite of the dehumanizing trials and tests he went through, still he persisted in his work for which he sacrificed so much for, that of converting the Indians. His zeal for this work led him to build the industrial school where he had the happiness of seeing so many children taught and brought up in a way which was so pleasing to the one who had sent him. Since he had built the school, never had so many prayers been offered up to God than at his death by the children of his school and many people who remembered in some way the kindness he showed to everybody. During the three days before his burial priests and bishops from the country around came to offer a prayer for him and see his beloved face for the last time. People from the neighboring villages came streaming in the room where he lay for the last time that they should thank the Almighty for sending such a future spouse amongst them.

Funeral services were offered up for his soul by his venerable brother missionaries that came straggling in as soon as they heard that our...
of them was dead. Not only did priests come but
the Governor with many of his people also came
to offer their prayers as a gratitude for this good
Father had done in this country. The unwound mission-
ary died on the eleventh of February 1917 and on Thurs-
day following he was consigned in the cemetery
house. During the morning a last Requiem Mass was
offered by the Bishop from St Boniface for Father
Kugonish. At the Mass I was honored with my niece to be
there from St Boniface and I was so glad to see our
chapel filled with visitors, including the Governor from
Regina, praying for one who was so dear to us. At the
sprinkling of his body with holy water I stood at his head
and looked on his peaceful countenance for the last time
and many were the sad feelings that stung up in my
heart when I recalled that affectionate face smiling upon
our chapel in the same chapel where he now lay with no
life to stir those blessed lips again. When Mass was over
the body was taken out and the sad procession began to
the little parish cemetery. I and another went near at the
head and when we got to the little house where the dead
were wont to be placed for the night, we waited for the
coffin to come in. We had not long to wait for this soon
appeared in of the oldest missionaries who were present at
the Funeral bearing in their midst one of their fellow
comrades. When the body was consigned in the little
house the people turned and went to the school or to
their homes. On the evening of this sad event the
priest and people who came from distant places
took their departure after showing their great
gratitude to one who was dead but who was
and will be the pride of the country for many
years to come.

By Willie Yuzieapi

Inspector Murison's Report on Qu'Appelle Industrial School

Sir:

I beg to report that I proceeded to the Qu'Appelle Industrial School on Thursday, the 19th instant, and audited the books from May 10th, 1925, the date of the last audit, up to the 21st instant. I also went carefully over the buildings and noted their condition. I visited the classrooms, but did not examine the children in their work, my visit being more for the purpose of noting the appearance and condition of the pupils.

Office.

I checked the receipts and disbursements of cash, and traced the same to the different accounts in the ledger. I examined the invoices and compared the amounts with the entries in the journal, and checked the entries from the journal with the various accounts in the ledger. I examined the Bank pass book, also the deposit slips and cancelled cheques, obtained a certificate from the Bank Manager as to the balance at the credit of the school account, and prepared a Bank Adjustment Statement, as follows:

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
