I am submitting herewith a financial statement for the fiscal year, March 31st., 1927 to March 31st., 1928, which shows a deficit of $774.89. I may state that no advance had been obtained on account of the March Quarter grant. The returns for that quarter called for $9124.42, so that when this grant is taken into consideration there would be a surplus of $5349.53 instead of a deficit at the end of the fiscal year. I am also submitting a trial balance from April 1st. to April 21st., 1928. The outstanding accounts amount to $655.85, and the April salaries, after deducting an advance of $50.00, amount to $745.00, so that when the balance of the March Quarter grant is received the surplus will amount to $7031.83. This appears to be a very good showing, but after looking over the farming equipment I find that very soon a considerable expenditure will be involved in replacing implements and machinery which are pretty well worn out. The financial showing of the institution I consider is in a very satisfactory condition. I may say that I found the clerical work in the office neat and accurate.

After making full inquiry it would appear that there are probably a number of pupils who were permitted to go home to convalesce following sickness, who might be in a condition to return.
Inspector Murison's report on Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

to return, and others who did not return after the holidays. It might be advisable to notify the Agent regarding them. The total number coming under this class would be about 17. I made a careful examination of the register, and I am satisfied that the pupils for whom grant is paid are entitled to admission under the regulations. There are a number, however, being carried on the register that I think should be written off. I noted that the girls were neatly and tidily dressed. The boys were very neatly dressed on Sunday, but during the week they did not present so good an appearance, although warmly clad. The yard was very muddy, however, and it could not be expected that they would be dressed up in their best clothes under these conditions. There were seven cases in the hospital, one of which, a pneumonia case, was quite serious. This latter is a boy from Keeseekoosne reserve, the son of Antoine Quewezance. The pupils generally, I thought, presented a healthy appearance. I was present during the meal hours, and while the food was plain, they appeared to get plenty of it.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., May 2nd, 1928.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, which was recently inspected by Mr. Murison. You will notice that the office work at this institution is in good shape as are also the finances.

With reference to the Inspector's remarks regarding the farming implements, it is not the duty of the Department to replace these implements and, if the school expect this, they should be told they are mistaken. I make these remarks as I feel that they have allowed the implements to run down and get in poor condition.

I would particularly draw your attention to what the Inspector says regarding the attendance. It is absolutely wrong that there should be 46 children out of the institution with an enrolment of 259. A great many of these have been out for a long period; in fact, there seems to have been very little interest taken to have them returned and our Agents will have to take some of the responsibility for this condition. I am not instructing the Agents regarding this as I understand this is a matter which the Department are dealing with themselves. As long as this present system of allowing children to return home, on the excuse that they are needed to assist their parents, without having the matter thoroughly investigated continues, the results will be very unsatisfactory. Our Inspectors will tell you that a child is more often not required at home than required, and the Principal is not in a position to know whether the child is needed or not; Principals do not visit reserves. At one time Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6327, file 660-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
we had a complete check on this system and a pupil was not allowed to go home unless his case was first thoroughly investigated by an Inspector, which is not the case now. I have had several conversations with the Department on this matter, but up to the present I have not been able to convince them that the present system is not satisfactory.

The out-buildings at this school are in a sad state of repair. You will notice that I have asked for $1,000.00 in the Estimates for repairs to the buildings; I hope this has been allowed.

I would draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks regarding the playroom and lavatory in the boys' department. This condition has almost always existed; it is impossible to keep this up to the standard in which it should be kept. The joists in the main building have apparently rotted away. This will necessitate considerable expenditure and I doubt whether the $1,000.00 asked for will be sufficient.

With reference to the laundry, I have asked that $6,000.00 be allowed to put a decent laundry in this school, as the present one is far from what it should be.

I note that some money has been spent during the winter in doing minor repairs about the buildings. This is the first intimation I have had that this money was authorized and that the work was being carried on. The walk leading to the ice house is reported to be unsafe; in fact, all the walks are unsafe. I would draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks regarding the storage facilities not being satisfactory. I have also asked for $1500.00 to put this right.

There does not appear to be a sufficient number of cows to supply milk for this institution. You are aware
are aware we supplied some cows a few years ago and by this time there should have been a large enough number, by natural increase. The farming has been carried on in a profitable way, as the finances of the school show.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
May 8, 1928.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 314-11 of the 2nd instant, enclosing Mr. Inspector Hurison's report on the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. I am particularly pleased to get this statement, as it is the first general report on this school that has been forwarded to me for some time. I should be grateful if you would have one of your officers inspect there at least once a year in future.

I note that there were 46 children on the roll who were not in school. This, of course, is too many. I have directed that there be a careful checking of the latest quarterly report, and arising from this, the Reverend Principal will be written. The school appears to be in good financial condition and is doing satisfactory work on the whole. You will receive a further communication with reference to the buildings.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Miss Cummings -

I am returning, herewith, the letter from Mr. Lafleur which accompanied your letter of the 29th ultimo.

I am informed that Mrs. Lee Hamelin (nee Miss Melanie Blondeau) was at one time employed at the Industrial School at Lebret, Sask., to educate the Indian girls in the native crafts, that is: beadwork, etc. It was thought at that time that, if she were proficient, it would be a good thing to have her educate the young Indian girls in these arts, but I understand the scheme was not very successful, and the department does not wish to re-employ Mrs. Hamelin.

I am not at present aware of any other position to which Mrs. Hamelin might be assigned, but shall be glad to keep her in mind.

Yours very truly,

W.J.P. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Ottawa, May 21, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is desirous of learning if the older girls at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School are being trained in milking cows. As most of the graduates of your school will return to reserves that are largely farming communities, it is very important that the girls be fully competent in this particular. The Department expects that the older girls, under proper supervision, will be given a course of instruction in milking, and I shall be pleased to learn that suitable arrangements have been made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Very Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant. In reply I wish to state that the Department approves of leave of absence for the Reverend Father Leonard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, who wishes to come East at the time of the consecration of the Right Reverend J. Guy, O. M. I. I note that Father Jeannotte will be in charge during his absence.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Very Rev. J. Magnan, O. M. I.,
340 Provencher Ave.,
St. Boniface, Man.
Ottawa, February 24, 1930.

Sir:

I write to inform you that the Department, at the request of the church authorities, has approved of leave of absence in the case of Father Leonard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. This leave will be taken some time this spring - the school to be in charge of Rev. Father Jeanotte during Father Leonard's absence.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, May 26th, 1930.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

WOULD LIKE THOROUGH INVESTIGATION OF THE FOOD AND HOUSING CONDITIONS AT THE QU'APPHELLE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL. INSTRUCT ONE OF THE INSPECTORS AND ASK DOCTOR CORBETT IF HE WILL BE KIND ENOUGH TO ASSIST AT THE INVESTIGATION. WOULD LIKE A COMPLETE AND DETAILED REPORT AT THE EARLIEST POSSIBLE DATE.

Charge I. A. Duncan C. Scott.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Inspector Hamilton's Report on the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Sask.

Dear Mr. Graham:

As instructed by you, I left here Tuesday, May 27th, accompanied by Dr. Corbett, to make a thorough inspection of conditions at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. This inspection I completed Thursday, May 29th.

In order that the living conditions may be thoroughly understood, I feel it necessary that the Department know the condition of the building, its equipment and the work carried on. Then, to understand it from the boys' side, I will describe the outside work, both in relation to farming and stock raising. The playgrounds and the equipment for recreation will also be discussed. In regard to the food, I will set down the menu as observed at each meal, and will give other information obtained from the Sister in charge. However, on this, and the question of health, I will not do more than pass on my impressions as no doubt a full report on this will be made by Dr. Corbett.

On the first floor of the main building is the Principal's office, the parlor, the guest chamber, and other staff rooms. These I found to be well furnished, tidy, and well kept. The halls were bright and spotlessly clean.

The girls occupy two dormitories. The small girls are on the first floor, and I found 68 beds in this

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
in this room. The room measures 65' x 50' with a 10'6" ceiling. All the beds were neatly arranged and nicely made. I examined the bedding on a number of beds, and the sheets and blankets were clean. Each girl was provided with a towel and toothbrush, and I found a night robe neatly folded under each pillow. The toilets and wash basins were all in working order and clean. The outside windows were off, but screens are needed. Of the fourteen windows only four have screens. The windows are located part on either side of the dormitory, thus making the room very bright and easy to ventilate. The floors, I understand, are scrubbed each week, and the spotless condition in which I found them gave every indication that the work was well done.

The senior girls' dormitory is on the second floor, with 59 beds. The room measures 50' x 60', with a 12' ceiling. At one end of the dormitory is a door leading into a sun room 12 ft. wide and 40 ft. long. This room has 9 large windows facing south, all of which I found to be well screened. The woodwork is painted white, and was clean. Five beds were arranged along the wall, all nicely made with white bedspreads and pillow covers. Here, as in the smaller girls' dormitory, I found the bedding clean. The girls are each provided with an individual towel, toothbrush, and night robe, and the toilets were clean and in good working order. The floors were clean and free of dust. In some places they are badly worn and will need renewing. There are 14 windows, and these are arranged part on either side of the dormitory, 4 of which were provided with screens. The storm sash were still on the other windows, but were on hinges from the top, and most of them were opened allowing
allowing an abundance of fresh air. More screens are needed as it will be impossible to keep the windows open when the flies and mosquitoes become bad.

The fire escape ladder is in good condition. The exit to this ladder is through a window which is $3\frac{1}{2}$ ft. above the floor. This would be very awkward in a rush, and a suitable step ladder should be kept by this window. The condition might also be improved by having the window placed on hinges to open out against the railing of the fire escape platform.

On the third floor of the main building is a small room, measuring 30' x 22', with a 12 ft. ceiling. This is used by the small boys and accommodates 16 beds. The beds were clean and nicely made. The room is provided with a toilet, bath-tub, and wash basins, all of which were clean and in working condition. The room has three windows, but no screens. The storm sash were still on, but were hung from the top and could be opened. The fire escape is through a window $3\frac{1}{2}$ ft. from the floor. This could be improved as suggested for the girls' dormitory.

The big boys' dormitory is 65' x 50', with a 10 ft. ceiling. There are 90 beds and all, I understand, are in use. Flannel sheets are used for the boys, instead of the cotton, and some of these were badly soiled. The sheets are only changed once each month, which I do not consider often enough. The boys are provided with towels, but I found no tooth brushes in use. A supply of new ones were on hand, but apparently the Vice Principal had neglected giving these out. The boys have no nightgowns, and sleep in their underwear. This dormitory has 14 windows, but only 4 are provided with screens. The outside windows are still
are still on, but could be opened as desired. I found the room well aired, and the floors clean. The wash basins and toilets were all working and in good condition. Two rows of beds, numbering about 30, have wooden frame springs, which are in poor condition. The springs sag badly, and the wire has given away in places.

The girls' hospital ward No. 1 has 7 beds, and measures 24' x 34', with a 12 ft. ceiling. It has two windows. The storm sash was still on. There are no screens. The room was very clean, and the beds neatly made.

The girls' hospital ward No. 2 is 16' x 34', and 12 ft. high. This opens on a sleeping balcony 12' x 24', with a 9 ft. ceiling. The ward accommodated 5 beds, and the sunroom had 4 all nicely made with clean white bedding. The balcony has 5 large windows with full size screens. It is painted white, and faces south, so that abundance of sunshine may get in. The two windows in the main ward need screening. I do not think these wards could be improved on, and the care and keeping of same was past criticism.

The hospital ward No. 1, for the boys, is 24 x 26, with a 12 ft. ceiling. Four beds were neatly made, and the room was clean. It has three windows all needing screens, as well as a door leading to the fire escape. The storm sash were on, but open.

Ward No. 2 is 24 x 26, with a 12ft. ceiling, and has 6 beds neatly arranged and nicely made with clean white linen. There are 2 windows. The storm sash is still on, and there are no screens for the windows.

The hospital dressing room is well provided with basins and medicine. The room was clean, and all utensils and medicines were neatly arranged on shelves.

The hospital
The hospital kitchen is about 14 x 24 in size, and is provided with a kitchen range, gas stove for sterilizing purposes, as well as dishes, and other necessary articles. The sinks were clean and in good working condition, and the entire room was in perfect order.

The operating room is 18' x 34' with a 12 ft. ceiling. This is furnished with a wheel table, operating table, cot, wheel chair, scales, ray lamp, screen, tables and stools. There are two windows, but no screens. The storm sash was still on, but open. This room appeared to be exceptionally well furnished, and was in A 1. condition.

The pharmacy appeared to be well stocked with medicines, all of which were neatly arranged on shelves and labelled.

The sunroom off the main hall is 12' x 24' with a 9 ft. ceiling. This is provided with 3 beds, and could be used for either the boys or girls in case of sickness. It is furnished, and in the same condition as the sunroom off the girls' hospital ward.

The small girls' playroom is on the ground floor, and is large and roomy. The floor is badly worn, as is also the floor leading to the playroom. The toilets were all clean and in good condition, except one. The bowl is broken, and a new one should be provided. These girls are supervised by a Sister when in the playroom.

The senior girls' playroom is practically the same, although the floor is in better condition. The toilets were all clean and in working order. A Sister also supervises these girls. There are no screens on any of the windows.
the windows, and I would especially point out the need for them on the windows of the lavatories. These windows should be kept open, and screens are essential.

The boys' playroom is very large. This, also, is on the ground floor. Some repair work has been done in this room during the past month, but there is yet need for more. V-Joint boards are needed on the wall, and the table and benches should be repaired or discarded. The cement has given way on one section of the floor, and should be renewed. This room has received hard usage in the past, but we must remember it is the only room for the boys, who number about 110. The room needs a thorough cleaning, and should be painted. I was informed it was last done in 1922. The shower bathroom, which adjoins the playroom, was clean and in good working condition. The lavatory was not clean. The bowls were all in working order, but had not been kept clean; in fact, the whole room needed a thorough washing. The urinal stalls were also dirty, and no water was running in them. I think if a proper float or trap were installed so that, at intervals, water would be flushed down the walls of the bowl, a big improvement would be found. The storm sash were all on and there are no screens for the windows. Here, again, screens are urgently needed, and the windows should be kept open to allow plenty of ventilation. I was informed by the Assistant Principal that the toilets could not be cleaned and made white, but in this he was wrong. I might add that under the Reverend Principal's instructions, this place was cleaned up before I left.

The kitchen I found to be clean, and in a very tidy condition. The sinks were clean, and all taps in working order. The pantry and store room connected with the
with the kitchen was tidy, and the supplies are well arranged. The frigidaire was in good condition, and well supplied with fresh meat. A quantity of milk was also kept in it. This is a heavy department of the school, and is in charge of two Sisters. The food appeared well cooked, and on all occasions there appeared plenty. The meals served while at the school were as follows:

May 27th. - Supper
Soup with meat & vegetables
Bread
Milk for the little ones
Tea
Hot Biscuits

May 28th. - Breakfast
Porridge with brown sugar
Bread & Lard
Tea

Dinner
Meat & vegetables (Mulligan)
Prunes
Bread & Tea

Supper
Meat (flour gravy)
Bread
Tea
Syrup

May 29th. - Breakfast
Holidays & Sundays - no porridge
Bread & Lard
Tea
Milk for the little ones

Dinner
Mulligan (Meat & few vegetables)
Bread
Tea
Apple Sauce

The Sister informed me that the potatoes are sometimes boiled, and the meat is sometimes chopped fine and baked with the potatoes on top.

No grease (lard) is served if meat is provided.

The desserts are made up of syrup, prunes, apples, rice with raisins, and often just hot biscuits.

My impression
My impression was that bread made up the main portion of the meal with plenty of tea, and yet I would not infer that a fair amount of other foods are not provided.

The dining room is about 75 ft. long and has three rows of tables the full length of the room. The boys occupy one half, and the girls the other. The meal is all served before the children come in, and is supervised by two Sisters and the Assistant Principal. I noticed that a number of children received Cod Liver Oil after each meal.

The sewing room is large and well lighted. It appeared to be well provided with sewing machines, and I found the work all neatly done. The girls are taught to make clothes for the boys and for themselves. The work is supervised by the Sister in charge, and I believe the girls are receiving an excellent training.

The laundry is situated in a building apart from the school, but is connected by a covered passage-way. The building is in good repair, and is equipped with a large washer, and extractor for drying the clothes, also necessary tubs. The upstairs has a specially fitted drying room, and is provided with a large mangle for ironing the sheets. The room is well lighted, but should have screens for all the windows as I found the place very hot and stuffy. The sewing departments are closed on Mondays, and all the girls assist in the washing. This does not appear to be a satisfactory way as, under this method, the bed sheets are only washed once a month, and the boys' clothes twice. The Sister explained that the washer would not accommodate all the clothes to enable the sheets to be washed twice a month, and the children to have clean clothes each week. She claimed another washer would be needed if this were to be done. Personally, I see no reason why part of the washing
could not be done on Mondays; this could be the girls washing and their sheets. The boys' could be done Wednesday, and the staff's on Friday, leaving Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday for the ironing. In this way the work could be carried on with the present equipment, and the laundry department would be in operation each day of the week, thus giving the girls a training in this, as well as in mending, sewing and cooking. However, if the work must be done in one day, I have no doubt another washer is needed, because at present I do not think the children's clothes are changed often enough, and the sheets should be washed at least once every two weeks.

The bakery is a fairly new building, and is equipped with a mixer and two large ovens. The place was clean, and the bread seen was good. The flour used is a standard second grade "Key Note", made by the Robin Hood Milling Co. A large supply of flour was stored in the storeroom attached to the bakery. I understand baking is done three times a week, and that 4 cwt. of flour is used at each baking. The number of loaves baked at one time was claimed to be 200, and that should equal 400 standard size loaves such as are sold in the cities. The baker claimed that some weeks he was obliged to bake extra in order to have sufficient. It will be noted that the girls receive no training along this line, which I consider is a mistake. Surely, after spending six to eight or ten years in a school, a girl should know how to bake bread and not have to return home and continue making bannock, as unfortunately is the case.

The garden is situated west of the girls' playground, and is an ideal spot for the purpose. All the seeds had been put in and the plants set out, some of which I found damaged by frost. This work is looked after by Mr. Dahl, and

I understand
I understand that, as a rule, they have abundance of all vegetables. The boys appear to have little part in this work, although at certain times they assist in the weeding. This branch of training I consider important, and feel that the boys should have more instructions along this line. Mr. Dahl, the gardener, is a man up in years and speaks very little English. He appeared to receive more assistance from his wife than from the boys.

The root cellar is built outside the school, and is underground. The walls are built of stone, and the roof is cement covered with earth. A few potatoes and carrots still remained, and these I found to be sound and in good condition. The Principal purchased a car of potatoes last fall, but as a rule they raise sufficient for their own requirements.

The carpenter shop is in good repair, and is well outfitted with tools. I found two men busy at work and one Indian boy. I understand that at times the boys are given some instructions in this work.

The shoe shop is in poor condition, and past repairing. Three men are kept busy repairing and making the shoes required for the children.

The horse barn was clean, but certain repair work is needed. The outside doors need to be renewed, and also the one leading to the feed room. I also noticed that a number of mangers needed renewing. Two carpenters are kept, and yet it seems strange that this repair work is left undone. The horses seen were in good condition, and appeared to be receiving good care.

The cow barn was clean and in good repair, except that new doors were needed at the north end. This barn is a fair
is a fair size and accommodates 24 cows. At present 16 are being milked, and from these they receive about 140 lbs. in the morning and 120 lbs. at night, a total of 260 lbs. or 26 gal. Some years ago, the Department furnished this school with a number of holstein cows, and I have no doubt that had proper care and judgment been used, the school could now have had 24 cows of high producing merits. However, this was not done, and today we have a herd of 45 females, some outstanding and others, no doubt, very ordinary. In order that these cows may be properly cared for, it will be necessary to have more barn room. The present barn could be enlarged to accommodate 40 cows, which would mean additional space for 16 head. A herd of this size, well selected and properly cared for, should supply each child with at least 1 pint of whole milk per day, leaving sufficient to be used in cooking, as well as enough to teach the girls the art of butter making, of which, at present, they know nothing. I feel this to be an important branch of training and one that should not be neglected.

A small shed, 18x30, was built some years ago to accommodate the calves and yearlings. This I found in good repair and suitable for the purpose for which it was erected.

The piggery is well built and in good repair. At present they have 9 sows and 25 small pigs. The fences about the pig yard are in poor condition, and will need to be re-built.

The crop this year amounts to - Wheat, 135 acres; Oats 110 acres; Barley 65 acres; Sunflowers 12 acres, with about 160 acres left to summerfallow.

The playgrounds
The playgrounds for the boys were tidy and free of all litter. They are supplied with a baseball outfit, and a football.

The yards about the old coal shed need to be cleaned, and the shed should be taken down as it is past repairing, and in a dilapidated condition. I would also mention the yard about the chicken house, which is very unsightly, and should be cleaned and made tidy. The chicken house is quite close to the school, but the Reverend Principal claimed that if it were away any distance, the boys and outsiders would steal both the eggs and the chickens.

The playground for the girls is south of the school. It is well drained and dotted with beautiful shade trees. The old swings are no longer safe, and new swings and teeters would greatly add to the enjoyment of the children.

I visited each classroom, and in all cases they were clean, tidy, and well aired, but in all cases screens are needed. The work is arranged as follows:

Senior boys in charge of Mr. J. R. Paquin.

All the children appeared well along in their grades, and some of the children speak out exceptionally well and clear. I found the registers all marked, and the attendance shown is excellent. The greater number of children attend school all day, and this especially applies to the boys.

The fire hose are in good condition, and I found all fire extinguishers filled and in convenient places. Some of the exits can be improved by a step ladder, as mentioned before, and the placing of the windows on hinges to open out. The fire gong rings at several different stations and appeared to be in good condition. Fire drill is not observed often enough as it had only been carried out on one occasion this year, previous to my visit. The children were just in bed on the night.
the night I rang the bell, and all were out in two minutes, except the senior girls who required slightly over four minutes. If the improvements suggested were made and more frequent fire drills observed, it would greatly lessen all danger, should a fire occur.

I am attaching to this report a time table, which outlines clearly how the time of the boys and girls is taken up, and I understand this is adhered to throughout the year.

The girls were neatly dressed and clean, all having their hair neatly cut and combed.

The boys were fairly well dressed, but one can readily understand that with only changing their clothes twice a month, by the end of two weeks, they are, to say the least, badly soiled and somewhat in need of repair. They appeared fairly clean in person, but their hair, in many cases, was ill kept and poorly cut. There was undoubtedly lack of care and interest.

In regard to the children's health, which subject will no doubt be dealt with by Dr. Corbett, I have only to say that of the 230 children, I did not see one who was really in poor health. The children were strong, and in good condition, and apparently ready for each meal. There were no bad glands and very little indication of eye trouble. The senior girls are an exceptionally fine lot of robust healthy children, some weighing over 160 lbs. I believe there are some cases of bad teeth needing attention, as well as some diseased tonsils, but no doubt these matters will be discussed by Dr. Corbett.

The work
The work over which the Sisters are in charge could receive little criticism, but I was not satisfied with the work of Mr. Leveque, the Vice Principal. As pointed out elsewhere, the boys are only bathed once in two weeks, and there is no reason for this as the shower bath is in good condition, and there is abundance of water. The toilets were unclean, and the stairway ill kept. The boys' hair was untidy and poorly cut, and tooth brushes were not in use. The supervising of the above, I understand, are some of Mr. Leveque's duties, but there is no doubt he had become careless and indifferent. I do not mean that the man is incapable of doing the work, but he undoubtedly needs checking up by the Principal. This slackness in the Vice Principal would indicate to me a slackness or indifference on the part of the Principal in checking up on those he employs.

The staff consists of the following members:

Rev. Father Leonard
12 Sisters
J. T. Leveque
P. L. Blanch
R. Paquin
E. Dahl
Miss M. Rinaude
J. Dahl
L. Plais
M. Simon
J. Condon
J. Z. LaFleur
J. Parisien
F. Dahl

a total of 25. This is undoubtedly a large staff, and gives every indication that an effort is being made to care for the children and give them proper supervision. There are, however, certain phases of the work which I feel...
feel is neglected and which I have touched on in this report, namely, the girls receive no instructions in making bread, nor in butter making, and the laundry work is all jammed into one day, instead of being spread out over the week, thus giving the girls the practice and instruction day by day which would fit them to do the laundry work required in the average home. It will be noted that only about six or eight boys work on the half day system; the majority attend school all day. It appeared to me as though the instructor did most of the work instead of instructing the boys and seeing that the work is properly carried out. I am inclined to think that some boys could be kept busy each day in the garden, and on the farm, as well as in the various stock barns, and if this were done and properly supervised, the garden and hoe crops would be well cared for, the stock would be in excellent condition, the barns nicely whitewashed and kept in good repair; the yards and fences would be in A.I. condition, all of which would be excellent training for the boys and should reflect on living conditions in later life.

I realize this report is length, and yet I would not wish to close it without mentioning the courtesy I received both from the Rev. Father Leonard and his staff. The Rev. Principal made it clear from the beginning that I was free to carry on my inspection as I saw fit, and any assistance needed, either from himself or staff, would be freely given. I found myself free to go throughout the building, and on all occasions my enquiries
enquiries were answered freely and to the point. I trust that in the above report, the Department will find all the information required.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Commissioner of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

In accordance with your instructions I visited the Qu'Appelle Indian School on May 27th. In company with your Inspector, Mr. Hamilton, and would report as follows:

General Hygienic and Housing Conditions

The playgrounds for the boys and girls were both clean and well kept.

The school buildings in general are in good repair, and scrupulously clean. I visited every part of the buildings and found the same ideal cleanliness and tidiness everywhere apparent, with the exception of the boys' lavatory in the basement, which, though of excellent structure, was not as well kept as it should be. There is a good terraza floor and the walls are of glazed brick; the compartments are steel, so the room should be easily kept in perfect condition. The closet bowls were coated at the bottom and up to the top of the water line with a brown scale which can easily be removed by scraping, and should not be allowed to collect again. The urinals were in a similar condition, and lacked automatic flushings. These conditions should be easily remedied, and should not be allowed to recur. The windows of this lavatory lack screens. The lavatories in all other parts of the building were in excellent condition. The taps are working, and water supply good.

The dormitories, with their beds, were all clean and well aired. The storm windows are still on nearly all the windows of the second and third floors. They open on hinges at the top, but should be removed and proper screens of wire netting put on to keep out the flies.
The hospital rooms and sun balconies were very clean, and well equipped.

The kitchen and dining rooms, the food storages, frigidaire and vegetable cellars, also the recreation rooms leave little to be desired in an institution of this kind. The laundry, bakery, carpenter shops and barns were in good order, and sanitary condition. The sewage disposal plant is in good working order, and very satisfactory.

I examined all the children in the school and found them in excellent condition. There were very few cases of enlarged glands or sore eyes, and these mild in character and receiving appropriate attention. I found very little evidence of head lice, and none of body vermin. There were no children showing signs of active tuberculous lesions, and the general health of the children is excellent, especially for the spring of the year. I believe they have come through the winter very well. All the children in the school have frequent physical examination, including X-Ray plates of their chests, so any unhealthy condition should be discovered early, and I believe receives appropriate care. I found several cases of enlarged tonsils and diseased teeth which require attention, but the number of these is not great. I find that the boys sleep in the same underclothing that they wear during the day, and that their underclothing is changed only once in two weeks. I would advise that the boys sleep in night clothing, and that the underclothing be changed once a week.

Regarding the food supplied, I found this in general to be of good quality, and sufficient quantity. In some respects, however, this might be improved. More milk should be used and a minimum of a pint a day for each child should be provided. Through the winter the amount supplied fell far below this requirement. Butter, too, has been used in very small quantity, being replaced by lard. However, cod liver oil is used quite freely and to some extent makes up for the deficiency of vitamins, but I would urge that butter be used much more freely in place of lard. With the adoption of these suggestions I believe an otherwise excellent school would be improved and brought to high standing.

Yours truly,

June 10, 1930.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 314-11 of the 5th instant, enclosing reports on the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School from Dr. Corbett and Mr. Inspector Hamilton. These are what is required at this time, and I am very pleased to have the report in such detail. Mr. Hamilton's constructive criticism is so useful in this case, that I am more than ever satisfied that our Inspector's time should be largely given to the important function of inspection.

I am enclosing copy of the official letter which is being directed today to Father Leonard. You will please arrange for screens on the main building where needed; for automatic flushing of the urinals in the boys' playroom; for stepladders leading to the windows at the fire escapes where needed and for the placing of these windows on hinges. In due course, you should let the Department have a recommendation regarding additional cow barn facilities.

I should like you to arrange another inspection of the Qu'Appelle School in the early fall, with a view to learning if the improvements and changes directed in the Secretary's letter to the Principal have been carried out. In this connection I am particularly interested in fire drill, boys' gardening, girls' bread and butter making and the general cleanliness of the boys.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, June 10, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of detailed reports on the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School from Dr. F. A. Corbett of Regina and Mr. Inspector Hamilton. There are certain improvements which must be made without delay, and, knowing your interest in the welfare of the pupils, I write, confidently expecting that you will make what changes are necessary, without delay. I may say that Mr. Commissioner Graham is being authorized to provide screens for the windows where needed and to make a change in the boys' playroom lavatory. Mr. Graham is also being authorized to arrange for stepladders leading to the fire escapes and to place hinges on the windows that should open easily. I am considering for future estimates your need for more cow barn facilities.

Fire drill must be practised regularly. The Department allows no exception in this important matter. More variety is needed in connection with the food supplied to the children, and further, larger quantities of milk and butter must be served. The boys should receive a thorough training in gardening. It is reported that the garden is looked after largely by Mr. and Mrs. Dahl. It is quite proper for him to supervise the work, but it should be done by the boys of the school, for training purposes, if for no other reason.

The girls should receive regular training in the baking of small batches of bread. At most Indian residential schools, it is the practice to have a few loaves made by the older girls, once a week. The work should be done in the kitchen and not in the bakery.

Rev. G. Leonard, O. M. I.,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Indian Res. School,
Lebret, Sask.

where there are facilities for baking bread on a large scale. Practice in this art should be given, using only that equipment which the girls will find in their homes upon graduation. The older girls should also receive training in making butter.

The sheets on the boys' beds should be changed at least once every two weeks and the boys' underwear should be changed at least once a week. They should not be allowed to sleep in their underwear—nightgowns must be supplied. Of course, this improvement will mean considerable increase in the laundry work, which will, of necessity, be spread over three or four days. A slight adjustment in the duties of the Sisters and elder girls will make this possible without the work becoming laborious.

The boys must be bathed at least once a week. Their hair should be kept neatly cut and brushed and their teeth should be cleaned regularly. The boys' playroom lavatory must be kept clean and sanitary at all times.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your No. 114-0-1 of the 10th instant, acknowledging receipt of the reports from Doctor Corbett and Mr. Inspector Hamilton on the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. I am glad to know that these reports are satisfactory.

I note in your letter of instructions to Father Leonard that you have said nothing about the milking of cows by girls in the school. This is, as you know, one of the most essential branches of training in the school. We are continually fighting with the Indians about the milking of cows. We have a splendid medical organization now, but I think that we are working from the wrong end. We should have health officers who would insist upon the Indians keeping and milking cows. If the Indian children are given this training at school, it will help somewhat in the matter.

I note that you state that it is the practice at most schools to have a few loaves of bread baked by the older girls. There are very few schools where the girls get this training regularly. In fact, some of the schools do not give any training along this line.

This has been pointed out from time to time by the Inspectors, and I have certainly done so often enough myself. Butter making is not carried out to any extent. However, I am circularizing the Principals of the various schools and requesting them to instruct their pupils in these matters, and I would like the support of the Department in this connection.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.,
April 14, 1932

Dear Sir:

Re: Agath Pascal - Pasqua Reserve,
Qu'Appelle Indian Agency

In reply to our telephone conversation I have the honour to submit the following report on the above named Indian girl who is at present a pupil in the Qu'Appelle Indian Industrial School, Lebret, Sask.

During the first week of January, 1932, this girl was admitted to the School Hospital for observation and treatment on account of her appearing very nervous. A diagnosis of St. Vitus' Dance, a condition very rare among Indians, was finally made. By the end of the month there was marked improvement, and she was therefore discharged to return to the dormitory and class room.

Lately, when it was noticed that there was a tendency for her nervous symptoms to return, Agath was asked to attend school for only part of the day, and to rest the remainder of the day in her own bed in the dormitory.

I am informed by the Reverend Sister Superior that recently Agath committed an act deserving punishment. The Reverend Sister in charge of the girls, instead of administering the usual methods of punishment, informed the girl that she would be denied the privilege of attending the school concert with the other girls, and must remain in her own bed in the dormitory. This, to me, was a very rational attitude to take. To have administered the usual method of punishment in her case possibly would not have accomplished the desired results, and might have left the school officials open to criticism because of Agath being a nervous case.

I have visited the School regularly and frequently, and at all hours, and I know of absolutely no grounds for the statement contained in the wire to the Department.
W. Murison, Esq.,  
April 14, 1932

Re: Agath Pascal

At present this girl is well nourished and appears healthy. Her nervous symptoms are aggravated by any excitement, and she will require further supervised rest and quietness.

Your obedient servant,

Medical Superintendent,
Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit.

W. Murison, Esq.,
Inspector,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

W. REGINA, SASK., 18th April, 1932.

Dear Mr. Williams:

Referring to my telegram to you of the 12th instant, with reference to a complaint telegraphed in by Mr. E. G. Craig, of Fort Qu'Appelle, that Agatha Pascal, a pupil at the Qu'Appelle School, was imprisoned in bed, I might inform you that I have made full enquiries into this matter and I am satisfied that the report was not justified. I am enclosing herewith a report which I received concerning this girl from Doctor A. R. Simes, Medical Superintendent of the Fort Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit, which speaks for itself.

I might also inform you that I endeavored to get in touch with Mr. Craig, but have not been able to. A messenger was sent asking him to call me up as soon as possible. This he has not done. When visiting the Pasqua Reserve on the 16th instant, the grandfather of this girl, an Indian named Keeneecoose, asked me if I had heard anything from the Government regarding a complaint he had got a white man to send in for him with reference to the treatment of his grand-daughter, Agatha Pascal, at the Qu'Appelle School. This old man is very deaf and apparently did not understand what the Sisters told him regarding the reason for placing his grand-daughter in the Hospital. I explained the matter fully to him and he expressed himself as being satisfied with the explanation.

I trust the foregoing will explain the situation to you.

Yours very truly,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

A. S. Williams, Esq.,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sirs;-

The above mentioned girl is a daughter of Henry McLeod, an Indian at the File Hill's Indian Reservation. On December 23rd last she was attending the Indian school at Lebret, which I believe, is under the supervision of the Roman Catholic Church. On that date she lost all the fingers of her right hand as the result of an accident while operating the Mangle or steam Clothes Presser. The accident occurred under circumstances which would indicate gross negligence on the part of the authorities in charge of the laundry and it would appear that compensation ought to be made. I may say that her father lost an arm or hand in a similar manner while attending this same school as a boy.

I am not quite sure who the proper party is to take this matter up with and would be glad if you would let me have this information.

Yours truly,

Letter # 10897.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 6th instant, No. 114-0-1, with reference to Florence McLeod's accident, I beg to submit the following report.

On December 23rd, 1935, Florence McLeod was working in the laundry. Sister Herman was in charge. Both she and the Sister were working at the mangle, one at each end. The mangle is equipped with a guard rail. The Sister noticed her putting her hand over the guard rail to push the clothes through and warned her twice against doing this. However she did it again and her hand caught in the mangle. When the Sister heard her scream she stopped the mangle immediately and called the engineer, who lifted up the mangle and released the girl's hand.

Nurse Oliver was in the school at the time and dressed the hand. The following morning Dr. Simes came and dressed it again and took the girl to File Hills Hospital where she remained about ten days and was then taken to the Grey Nuns Hospital, Regina, where her fingers were later amputated.

I might mention that this mangle has been in use at this school for several years and all the girls are familiar with its operation.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

FB.
Ottawa, May 18th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

In further reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, the Department is now in receipt of a complete report regarding Florence McLeod's accident. It appears that this girl was working in the laundry on December 23rd, last, and that a member of the staff was in charge. Both the member of the staff and the girl were working at the mangle - one at each end. The mangle is equipped with a guard rail. The member of the staff noticed the girl putting her hand over the guard rail to push the clothes through and warned her twice against doing this. However, she did it again and her hand caught in the mangle. The girl screamed and the mangle was stopped immediately, and the engineer released the girl's hand.

Nurse Oliver was in the school at the time and dressed the hand, and the following morning Dr. Simes dressed it again and took the girl to the File Hills Hospital, where she remained about ten days, and was later taken to the Grey Nuns' Hospital, Regina, where her fingers were amputated.

The mangle at this school has been in use for several years, and all the girls are familiar with its operation. You will note from the above that there is a guard rail on the mangle and that a member of the staff was in charge of the girls who were working and had warned Florence McLeod not to put her hand over the guard rail. The Department feels that all the necessary precautions were taken, and, while the accident to Florence McLeod is regretted, it was through no fault of the school management.

William Hall, Esq., LL.B.,
Barrister, Etc.,
Lemberg, Sask.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Father Leonard,

I received this morning your kind invitation to be present at the opening of the new Indian residential school at Lebret on May 28th.

CHURCH HEAD OPENS SCHOOL FOR INDIANS

Colorful Scene at Lebret As Villeneuve Attends Impressive Rites

(By Staff Reporter)

LEBRET, Sask., May 30—In a setting of great beauty, witnessed by the brilliant array of clerical robes, Lebret's new Indian school was officially opened Friday afternoon.

His Eminence, Cardinal J. M. Doder, attended the ceremony on the occasion of his visit to the west, joined by Bishop Monahan, Murdock of the department of Indian affairs in the official opening.

Historic Site

Last May, when the war blazed, Friday it was dedicated in brief ceremonies attended by heads of the Roman Catholic church in Saskatchewan, by fathers in the district surrounding the Lebret Mission and by Indians from the area.

The new school stands on the site of an old mission built some time ago. Behind it rise the hills of beautiful Qu'Appelle valley. Across the church grounds flows and in front lies Echo lake.

Centuries of freedom stand as the nation of Father Huguenard, pioneer missionary who spent his life among the Red Men.

Into this setting Friday went Cardinal Villeneuve, guest of a prince of the Roman Catholic church, accompanied by Bishop Monahan in his purple robes of office and others of the clergy.

Children of St. Gabriel's convent at Lebret and of the public school greeted the cardinal on his arrival, standing on the steps of Sacred Heart church. Flags in the pagan colors of gold and blue waved in the breeze and children sang "God Bless You."

Bells in the church steeple clang out a welcome.

Children Sing

"That's very fine," said the cardinal, commenting on the children on their singing. Standing on the church steps nearest the dome were the children of St. Gabriel's clad in red, and wearing a mantle of blue with white cross.

In front of these, dressed the same and wearing a green sash were girls of the Holy Angels Children of Mary.

Small boys in red caps stood in front of these, members of the society of Holy Angels. Others dressed in red and white and black.

(Continued on Page Two.)

Indians Honor Cardinal

Indian students paid honor to Cardinal Villeneuve on Friday when his eminence visited the new school at Lebret. The Indians, themselves, attended the distinguished visitor as he chatted with one of the sisters of the institution, Indian boys and girls grouped around them.

Cardinal Villeneuve spent the night at the Oblate residence near the school and the lake after attending a musical concert put on by the Indian students at the school.

FRIDAY morning, the address were given in Sacred Heart church by Mr. F. P. O. Murray, chairman of the school board in French and by M. Salomon, school teacher in English.

Guests at the banquet Friday night included Cardinal Car- dinal Villeneuve; His Excellency Archbishop Monahan; Regina; Bishop Murdock; Bishop Macdonald, Murr- der, Sask.; Mgr. Grandbois, Gravebourg; Fr. Saund, Osborne.

In the basement of the main portion of the building are located pupil and staff dining rooms, boys and girls recreation rooms, toilets, baths, shower baths, etc. The rear wing contains the kitchen, scullery, cold storage room, laundry and boiler room.

It is worthy of mention that the basement of all Indian residential schools is practically a ground floor as the level of the basement floor is only 12 inches below grade, thus providing a maximum amount of light and ventilation. On the ground floor are located the class rooms, sewing room, staff bed rooms, offices, and a large chapel. There is also a large room for the accommodation of Indian parents when visiting their children. The first floor contains principally the dormitories, the Sisters' living quarters, and a few offices for administrative purposes. The second floor is entirely devoted to dormitories and a few staff bed rooms for supervision. The building is heated by steam and water supply and sewage disposal systems have also been installed.

STREAM FLOW IN MANITOBA AND NORTHWESTERN ONTARIO

Ottawa, Canada.— Precipitation in Manitoba and northwestern Ontario during June was generally below normal as was also the run-off. In the southwestern portion of Manitoba the records of the Assiniboine river indicate that run-off was 36 per cent below the June average whilst in the area south of Winnipeg run-off, based upon the records of the Red river, was only 19 per cent of normal. The records of the Swan river indicate that in northern Manitoba run-off was 28 per cent below the average. The records of the English river indicate that run-off in northwestern Ontario was 3 per cent greater than the June average.

The mean outflow of the lake of the Woods during June was slightly greater than in May and the level of the lake lowered not quite two inches. The mean outflow from Lake Seul was only about one-third of the mean outflow for May and the lake level rose almost one and one-half feet. The average flow of the Winnipeg river in Manitoba was the same as during the previous month although towards the end of June the flow of the river was diminishing.

The levels of lakes Winnipeg, Manitoba, and Winnipegosiss were all from six to eight inches higher at the end of June than they were a year ago.
NET INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS COMPLETED

Modern Structures Erected by Department of Indian Affairs For Education of Indian Children

Ottawa, Canada.—Marked progress has been made in Canada in recent years in the extension and improvement of facilities for the education and vocational training of the Dominion's Indian population. New school buildings, modern in every respect, are replacing old structures and better qualified teachers and instructors are being attracted to the Indian schools. There are 79 residential schools, 276 day schools, and 10 combined Indian and white schools in operation under the supervision of Honourable T. A. Crerar, Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and Minister of the Interior. Eighteen thousand Indian children in Canada are enrolled in the schools and of this number 8,900 are in residential schools.

Two of the most recently erected buildings of the residential school system are those at Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, and Lebret, Saskatchewan. These, like other schools under the Department of Indian Affairs, are operated in co-operation with the various church authorities engaged in Indian work, a method of carrying on the education of Canada's Indian youth which has worked out most satisfactorily.

The Shingwauk Indian Residential School at Sault Ste. Marie is conducted by the Church of England in Canada. The new building was opened on October 3, 1935, under the principalship of the Reverend C. E. Rivers, M.A., replacing that built in 1875 and is one of the finest in Canada. The school has accommodation for 150 pupils and staff and is steam-heated and fireproof throughout. The new building is of steel construction, with re-inforced concrete floors, tile partitions, steel stairs, and fireproof connecting doors. The outside walls are faced with brick and trimmed with stone. The main building is H-shaped, the centre portion being 80 feet long and the end wings 65 feet by 32 feet. The centre portion contains accommodation in the basement for dining rooms for the pupils and staff, boys and girls recreation rooms, toilets, baths, wash rooms, shower baths, etc. There is a wing at the rear approximately 70 feet by 50 feet which contains the kitchen, store rooms, boiler room, laundry, and cold storage. On the ground floor are located the class rooms, sewing room, and staff living quarters, together with a spacious assembly hall. The first and second floors contain the dormitories, clothing stores, staff bedrooms, and a well planned infirmary for the boys and girls.

The Lebret Indian Residential school in the Qu'Appelle valley of Saskatchewan was officially opened on May 29, 1936. The Oblate Order is associated with the Department of Indian Affairs in its management under the principalship of Rev. M. DeBreugnons, O.M.I. This school replaces that destroyed by fire in November, 1935, and provides accommodation for 250 pupils and the necessary staff. The building is of re-inforced concrete construction throughout. It has a frontage of 246 feet, with a rear extension 115 feet deep.

Doctor Harold W. McGill, Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

Dear Doctor McGill:

When plans were being prepared for the Lebret Indian Residential school, we requested that it be built for 250 pupils. Our request was granted and plans were made for a school to accommodate that number. We were therefore painfully surprised when we were informed that instead of funds being provided for a pupilage of 250, only 235 were provided for. This means that since the school was opened it has been short of 15 pupils and has suffered in consequence an annual loss in revenue of $2,550.00. This loss has been felt all the more in view of the cut in the grant of 15%, 10% and finally 5%.

The overhead at Lebret is absolutely the same whether the pupilage is 235 or whether it is 250. The only difference in expenses for the extra 15 pupils comes from the amount of food and clothing required to keep the extra 15. For any one who has any experience in the management of educational institutions, this extra cost is known to be very small in comparison of the lost revenue. We therefore hope that provision will be made in the supplementary estimates to provide for the full pupilage for which the school was built.

Hoping that you will consider our request favorably, we remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
EDITORIAL

A special newspaper, however small, seems to be very badly needed by our Indian population. To support this statement I can bring the following reasons: First, our Indians are brought up in our schools, with the knowledge of the English language, the ideals of the white people, and therefore it seems necessary to devise some means of following up with the civic and religious education, the rudiments of which were given in the school: a monthly, or better still, a weekly news bulletin, answers this need in part. Second, there is a widespread belief among Indians must be counteracted by the spread of truth; here again a paper can have a great influence on its readers: the different movements of the day need analysis and explanations which only a paper can give, on account of its frequency and facility of distribution. Third, our Indians have not, generally speaking, a very well developed sense of culture: a bulletin or newsheet, regularly distributed to them, might help them acquire a desire for information, a platform to express their views, wishes, and opinions, a medium for the authorities to teach civics, health and sanitation, moral advice, etc., to suggest divers means of bettering their lives. Fourth: in a paper such as ours aims to be, we seek to create a link between the parents and their children who are away from them for the greater part of the year, a link which the parents appreciate very much indeed. Fifth: the distribution of a specifically Catholic paper in the Indian homes is intended to teach two lessons: (1) the need of Catholic literature in the home, (2) the need of supplementing secular reading on Sundays with religious and devotional reading. Not only children, but adult Protestants belong to Sunday School classes, and every one goes home with a religious paper, which he or she is expected to read as a pious exercise.

True Catholics, on the other hand, feel that they do not need a Catholic paper, because they attended denominational schools, where they had a course of religious instruction extending over many years. Yet they find themselves unable to answer questions asked about their religion by their friends, or about pagan practices which the Church disapproves, or about accusations directed against Catholics, occasionally, in secular papers or magazines.

Schools are growing rapidly among people who are interested in questions and problems of the day. Now, a short sermon, attended by a few, or a conference given occasionally, does not suffice to instruct the minds in a sufficient degree to enable them to counteract all the errors and all the evils which are brought to the homes by the non-religious dailies or magazines.

In every Catholic school the children are taught to be obedient to all authority, both as well as ecclesiastical, and to be reverent, and to love GOD above all things, to love his neighbor as himself, and to cultivate habits of prayer.

The Catholic Press, especially, brings to the homes these same teachings. It is therefore the duty of all Catholic people to patronize the Catholic Press, and to read it, in order that they may learn the truth of what is happening in the Kingdom of Christ, co-extensive with the world. It is certainly unpardonable to read, with a family, the daily happenings of a secular nature and to be indifferent about learning what is happening in the world of religion. In reading the daily press, Catholic news, whether international or local, are often unintentionally distorted by non-Catholic reporters who do not very often comprehend the things behind the news.

In conclusion, we might express the wish that in our paper, we want the whole-hearted co-operation of all those who are able to give to us. We want to make this little paper as interesting and as useful as possible to those for whom it is intended. Every field: educational, religious, medical, historical, and even scientific (such as agriculture or home economics), will be given attention. The news element will be taken mostly from happenings at the Boarding Schools, and in the Missions, because the daily press, and other means of information can bring other news much sooner than a monthly bulletin.

G. L., O.M.I.

Son of Old French Family Heads School for Indians

A chance meeting with a friendly churchman has oft changed the future course of a life. No better example could be found in Saskatchewan than the incident that brought the successor of Rev. J. Hugonard, O.M.I., the noted founder of the Qu'Appelle Indian School at Lebret.

The man is Rev. Fr. Maurice de Bretagne, O.M.I., a son of Old France, now the director of the Qu'Appelle Indian School.

Rev. Fr. Maurice de Bretagne

Fr. de Bretagne was not born in surroundings that would mark him for a future life of service among the Indians. He was born in circumstances that would send him to the priesthood of the church.

Born in Northern France, nurtured in an atmosphere of learning and tradition, the future priest attended school in Belgium and learned of the illustrious service of his forefathers in the magistracy and courts of France.

The time came for military service, and he joined the 43rd infantry regiment. The outbreak of the "Great" war met the advancing enemy that ravaged northern France. With Chateaubriand with the "Old Contemptibles," de Bretagne contested the great retreat at Guise in Belgium. There, the French made a

Hungry Indians Cut Off by Snow as Drifts Reach New Peaks

Robert W. Ogle, resident of the Wood Mountain area, in a letter to the Leader-Post told of aged Indian folk sitting in cold cabins with no kernels for food except last fall's hoarding and little wood. Ninety percent of the cattle are dead, 75 percent of the sheep gone.

"Indians in the Wood Mountain district are starving from lack of food. Since the drought and severe winter, the small game they had formerly lived on, have been very or have moved on.

"Their food rations are so insufficient that in a week they are entirely out of food. The aged people are forced sitting in the dark because of no kernels nor coal and very little wood. Keremeos coal and matches are not included in their rations as they have not been for them from the beginning, who are in need of relief and are unable to give a hand.

"An old squaw, known as the 'Criminal Woman,' who is 98 years old, goes out into the snow, cuts her own wood and hauls it on her back to her house. She gets her water from the creek. Many other aged people are doing the same."

Church Calendar for March

March 2—Ash Wednesday. Lent begins. Easter Wednesday and Friday this month are days of abstinence.

March 9, 11, 13—Ember days. The 12th is also a day of abstinence from meat.

March 17—Feast of St. Patrick, patron of Ireland.

March 19—Feast of St. Joseph.

March 24—The Annunciation by the Angel Gabriel to the Virgin Mary, telling her she will become the Mother of the Saviour.
Indian Religion

We are all well aware of the great religiosity of the Indians of America. It was not the wealthy civilization of the Aztecs which was destroyed and replaced in the XVIth century, when they came in conquest of Mexico. What impressed everyone at that time was the number of the two hundred or more temples of the Montezuma's city, dominated by the pyramidal temple of the sun-god, a pyramid which, according to its dimensions, red and thirty steps, were offered each year, thousands of human victims as a sacrifice. The whole life of the ancient, semi-pagan, spiritual and military, had religion for a dominating factor.

In the XVIIIth century, the first French missionaries reported carefully the beliefs, traditions and customs of the Indians of the prairies. Although their religious life did not allow them to build temples, but every detail shows that the old Indians were eminently religious. And this, in spite of many setbacks, the religious life was outstanding instance of what is called Tradition. As their languages, the beautiful and inflexible languages, the art of which is the astonishment of the white people, were kept from generation to generation without being written down, so their traditions were after thousands of years, still enlightened with the purity of natural religion and moral law and the last word of the primitive revelation made by God to the first man.

At least 5000 years before Moses ever wrote the first line of the Pentateuch, God gave to mankind a Revelation which was kept jealously by the Patriarchs. Yet, it is from that common treasury that all the nations have drawn their main lines of their religion. But, too often, History tells us that, with the exception of the Jews who had a special alliance with God, ignorance, breed, private interests, national pride and shameful passions had obscured and distorted the purest Revelation. God's holiness and immorality became the cancers of the religious, which, without the direct contact with God for the Jews, became what we call paganism.

The particular case of the Indians displays the antique beauty and the lamentable mistakes. They were sent in exile far away from the common Father of Heaven, sinful, yet longing for the lost Paradise in the longings for the land of their forefathers scattered over the world, differentiated in many races, under the variety of climates and ways of life, they remained bound by the same ideal and the same common belief. The white or the black, the red or the yellow possessed with their common origin the same common religiosity. But, only more among those who were in the best of the first Revelation are the Indians who kept a great deal of it. God, our Maker. Altruism, who provides, compassion who prophesies, need of prayer, of penance, of sacrifice; the cult of the dead; the necessity of morality and charity which have become overburdened with superstitious rites and magic, how it degenerated into bloody polytheism, how it lost the respect for the sacred, how it identified itself with immorality. Yet, the young Indians should respect their old peoples, pagan of the old type. If they do not laugh at them, they should explain to them what is right and what is wrong in their belief, and help them climb towards the Light. God, the Faith, the old pagan who is godly, who has seen the light, the Lord of Gods, but who through immorality, laziness, selfishness, a shameful and sinful life, has lost the faith, believes no more, has abandoned himself to paganism in his elders. The old dignity pagan is climbing the mountain toward the Light, the modern godless pagan is falling down away from God's spirituality.-Fr. Guy de Bretagne, O.M.I.

The Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.

A thoroughly modern hospital for 60 patients was built at Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask., two years ago, to replace the one at Lebret. Dr. A. B. Gibney, M.D., medical superintendent of the hospital, and also for the Qu'Appelle health unit, Miss H. Gibney is the matron.

The hospital has a fully equipped operating room, and an entire flat is reserved for T.B. patients. Much work has been done during past years in the care of T.B. patients, and in a few years it is to be hoped that the disease will be practically stamped out on the Indian Reservation.

Patients are taken in the Hospital from all parts of Saskatchewan. Dr. Wall, tract surgeon, has been working in our unit lately, and has made a good survey of the case, and has taken efficacious measures in fighting the dreaded eye sickness.

Dr. Gibney will be further intersted in our paper, and we will give him space every month in our columns for an article on Tuberculosis, its prevention and its cure.—O.L. O.M.I.

Josephine Reserve, Moscow, Sask.: Joe McDonald, aged 28, died at the Indian hospital, on Feb. 6th. He leaves his wife, Eva Thomas and three children.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA

LESTOGO, Sask.—Raw Fr. James Paradis, principal of the St. Philips Indian Residential School, writes to us that he is very pleased with the Indian Record and subscribes to 100 copies, every month. He will make every effort next year to bring his school up to date. Next month we will read about his school and his work among the Saukoux of Muscowequan and Poorman Reserve.

ST. PHILIPS, Sask.

These who have known and loved Sister Marjorie will be glad to learn that she has been very ill. We ask her old friends to kindly offer a prayer for her speedy return to health.

Valentine Party—Thursday, Feb. 17, the boys and girls had a party together which turned out to be an impromptu concert. Numbers varied from singing by the piano orchestra, dancing by the Intermediate and Senior Girls singing by the boys and girls, and a few numbers by the band. A group of 16 Senior Girls, Mr. Forrester also entertained with his guitar. A touch of comedy was added to the evening by the Lord of Misrule who made his way to the party and kept the gathering in laughs by his antics on his pony. After 3 hours of fun, the party came to an inevitable end. One of the girls, sporting for her companions, expressed to Father Principal the gratitude of the children for providing them with a night of enjoyable fun. The Junior Board entertained their girl classmates at a bingy party in their hall. It is said that the Lord of Misrule attended this party too, but that he had to leave because of the rough treatment "Dusty Ranger" gave his horse, received at the hands of the Junior Board.

Hockey News, Lebret: On Feb. 16th, our senior boys invaded Fort Qu'Appelle and defeated the combined Fort and Sanatorium teams with a score of 5-4. On Feb. 18th, in a return game, the School again defeated 3-0.

On Sunday, Feb. 20th, the Senior Board defeated a 4-3 victory over the Lebret Seniors in a hard fought game played at the town rink.

Radio Artists: The File Hills Redmen, an amateur indoor football quartet composed of M. Norman Kerstin, Willie Dunmont, Edwin Nokusis, and George L. Creely, was heard over CKCR, Regina, Feb. 19th, on an amateur program. Two numbers "College Hornpipes" and "My Blue Ridge Mountain Home" were well enjoyed by their friends—E.L.

Kinebikons or Little Snake

CHAPTER I

In the year 1902, was born in the woods of Northern Ontario, near Rainy Lake, an Indian girl called Kinebikons, Little Snake. Her mother died when she was only three days old; when the child was two her father departed for the happy hunting grounds three years later.

So the Indian girl was left an orphan. She lived on her old miserable looking grandmother called Tewegan—the Drum. This squaw was already seventy years of age, yet the great sorceress of the place.

Both of them, the child and her guardian, lived in an old shack, built some twenty-five years ago, on an elevation in the centre of the waters of Rainy Lake. Many others who escaped the fury of the waves were killed on the railroad track, running through the Couchiching reserve.

One winter afternoon, two Grey Nuns and the Missionary of the Fort Frances Indian Boarding School went out to visit the poor people of Scandijaming. It was in the middle of January, the weather was very cold and a heavy blanket of snow covered the forest and Rainy Lake. Everything looked dark there in the open space far away over the great lakes; a thick bush of poplar trees protected the village from the north wind. We could see a tiny streak of white smoke rising into the air from most of the houses. But one cabin seemed to be without smoke. The Indians were quiet. And what did we see there? In one of the corners of the old dilapidated shack, on a pile of green spruce branches, was lying a little girl. She cried when she saw us coming to her. With one hand, she covered...
Kitchitwa Joseph

Kekitch itai natose akimititi Nishapini- ke ki kitchikijilikitit mekitchitwa Joseph. Kakitywa Catholic oyatami- hawa miswe askil ikaayi kit kikithetwa. Kua Riwana siyowo na miyo, kitchi kikumikudhawaya.

To take care of them. The child, in its extremities of the shaggy, on a wooden box, sat on an old squaw; the figure of a person, who once wore a woman's dress but was just one wrinkle away from being just like an Egyptian pachnichie. The old woman was smoking, not real tobacco but "kilo"; it was reputed to bark the Indians find in the bush.

In the middle of the floor stood the silent stone, an object of another sort; it had no feet; It was wood, the child and the savage, shivering, as there wasn't a piece of wood in the house. We were in the presence of two pictured pictures: Sisters, white and brown. But not less, because, in my long missionary career, I had more than once witnessed such scenes, and that which I could read in the Sisters' minds. I simply said to them: "This is dire poverty. The only way to help these poor people is to take them both with us to the mission. There, we will feed them, cloth and heal them." Christian charity commands us to do so.

We hurriedly visited the other Indian houses; most of them were shabby looking huts, and in some cases, their occupants had very little food.

The hunters on the reserve were very few, so many of the men folks had died off. Generally, when a hunter had killed a moose or a caribou, the meat was immediately divided among all the members of the band; yet whoever was still for so many people! Most of them had only one "bannock" to eat.

Coming back to the lonely cabin of the sick girl, and looked at the two little sisters, went up to Kitchikons, wrapped her in a thick warm blanket and together brought her to the sleigh. The old woman, after feebly raising her eyes a pair of bear claws above her head, carrying the devil's drum and her medicine bag, started off for the mission. With a torn blanket thrown over her head, she smiled as she tried to get into our sleigh. At five o'clock that afternoon, our sleigh reach— ed the mission of Fort Frances.

The boys from the school had seen the two nonne carry out a mysterious operation. They noticed a once little girl under the heavy blanket; the pitiful sight excited their pity. A few of them started to Sisiq's carry Kictikons, the Little-Snow, into the school.

Tewagon and his grandmother Tewegen were brought into the infirmary of the institution, where they peacefully and happily spent the first night of their missionary ad—

venture.

A. JOSSE, O.M.I.

Rev. Sir:

We are in receipt of your letter of March 8th, together with a copy of the "Indian Missionary Record", for which thanks.

We must congratulate you on the neat clean appearance of your paper and we are satisfied that it can be made of great service to the Indians. We are very sorry however to see you have carried the article headed "Hungry Indians cut off by snow as drifts reach new peaks."

The success of our work depends entirely upon our securing the confidence and co-operation of the Indians.

The fact that this article was carried by a paper issued by the Church will be accepted as proof by the Indians that this condition does exist, and will certainly not tend to assist, but rather to destroy the confidence of the Indians in our Department. As to the amount of truth there is in the article, you can judge from the R.C.M.P. report attached.

Will you kindly return the report for our files when read.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Rev. G. Laviolette, O.M.I.,
